column2: ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Legislation designed to make the state law barring strikes by public employes more "fair and realistic" was prefiled today with the support of the Republican leader of the Senate.

THE holiday season, traditionally a time for togetherness, has revealed the infiltration of this cosy virtue into an unexpected quarter, avant-garde art circles as described in a new book, "The Artist's World."

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Fred W. Hooper's Kentucky-bred Bright Holly took the $23,450 Las Flores Handicap for fillies and mares at Santa Anita Park today. The Panamanian, Braullo Baeza, rode a fine race to win.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 29 -- Hope for a meeting of the three Princes who lead the rival factions in Laos collapsed today with the departure of Prince Souphanouvong, leader of the pro-Communist Neo Lao Hak Xat party.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 -- Sheik Abdullah, the "Lion of Kashmir," was formally charged yesterday in a trial that is nearly four years old. He pleaded not guilty to a share of plotting to overthrow the Kashimir government.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Republican legislators generally took a "wait-and-see" attitude toward the new school aid plan that was announced yesterday by a special state committee.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Geoffrey Pollard of Australia and Mike Belkin of the United States survived semi-final matches today and will meet tomorrow in the Orange Bowl junior tennis final.
OGALLALA, Neb., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A frugal wheat and cattle farmer who died in his unheated, unpainted house has left $250,000 to $300,000 to the United States Government.

You think you have troubles and expense parking your automobile in Manhattan? Consider for a minute the owner of a fifty-foot ocean-going cabin cruiser seeking a dry spot to leave his $100,000 creation until he can move it into the New York Coliseum for the National Boat Show opening Jan. 13.

Cincinnati's Bearcats, ranked close to the top among the country's college basketball teams, will meet a miracle-working band of Wisconsin Badgers tonight in the final of the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Dee. 29 -- (Reuters) A self-styled former white mercenary in the Katanga Army told tonight of "shoot and starve" orders issued for operations against the Baluba tribe. The Balubas have long been foes of the tribal groups represented in President Moise Tshombe's katanga provincial regime in the Congo.

The last trade of 1961 consisted of 700 shares of Douglas Aircraft carried on the New York Stock Exchange tape yesterday at 32 5/8. That compared with an opening price of 28 5/8 twelve months ago at the year's start.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Officials said today that Mount Vernon finally had got moving on a redevelopment program that had been delayed for thirty years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Two of the men who will be brought into the Secretariat to serve as principal advisers to Acting Secretary General U Thant have represented their countries here for many years.

MANILA, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- William Pomeroy, a former United States soldier serving a life sentence for participation in the Communist Hukbalahap uprising, has been pardoned by President Carlos P. Garcia, Government sources said today.
Sidney R. Siben, a Suffolk County lawyer, was cleared unanimously of unethical practices yesterday by the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Brooklyn.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Congress gave final approval today to a constitutional amendment establishing a provisional government ruled by a civilian council until 1963.
The shipping industry in this country is mounting a campaign against Federal economies in the field of shipping subsidies.
" MRS. KINARD, I can't make up my mind which hand to do which with," came the anxious voice of a student, as she juggled a pitcher full of batter and a crepe pan.

Mayor Wagner will be sworn into office for his third term this week-end. Only one other Mayor in the long history of the city, Fiorello La Guardia, has been elected to stay twelve years at City Hall. The burden and responsibility of this office do not grow lighter with the passage of time. La Guardia's third term fell off in quality of performance; so did Wagner's second.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A jump shot by W.C. Stroud with three seconds left enabled Mississippi State to score a 64 -- 62 victory over Maryland tonight in the first round of the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament.

The five-and-one-half-story building containing fifty-six apartments and eight stores at 1235-37 Woodycrest Avenue, corner of 168th Street, in the Bronx, has been bought by the 1235 Woodycrest Company for investment. It is on a plot 108 by 116 feet. The sale was arranged by Leonard, Levites, Schiller, brokers, for cash over mortgages amounting to $275,000. Alexander Spitzer was the lawyer for the buyer. The sellers were clients of Benjamin Geller.

The Transport Workers Union reached a contract agreement with five private bus lines here early today, narrowing the threat of a strike at midnight tomorrow to Fifth Avenue Coach Lines and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 29 -- The first signs of a break in the deadlock on agriculture products among the members of the European Economic Community began to appear tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, announced the appointment today of eight Under Secretaries to act as his "principal advisers on important questions."
DR. SUBANDRIO, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, was described by a Westerner a few years ago as "a man who speaks flawless English and always gives the impression of believing everything he says."

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 29 --The Hudson County Board of Chosen Freeholders voted this afternoon to guarantee $15,000,000 in short-term notes to establish a wholesale food distribution center in the Jersey Meadowlands.

President Kennedy's Administration is prepared to show its faith in the future of the United Nations by investing up to $100 million in the twenty-five-year 2 per cent bonds recently authorized by the General Assembly. This assurance is given by Assistant Secretary of State Harlan Cleveland. The loan will not burden us. It may set a precedent that will, to quote Mr. Cleveland, "frustrate the Soviet attempt to starve the United Nations into submission."

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of a twelve-member advisory council on alcoholism. He designated Dr. John L. Norris of Rochester as chairman and Arthur N. Seiff, New York City lawyer, as vice chairman.
The Assembly's Committee Ethics and Guidance, which investigating conflict of interest charges against Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino, of subpoenaed Mr. Carlino's abuser, Assemblyman Mark Lane.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Federal District judge today ordered two companies that had transferred most of their operation to Arkansas and Colorado to return their equipment here and rehire all laid-off employes.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union, seeking to alleviate its agricultural difficulties, decreed today that farmers who negligently abused their machinery would be sentenced to prison or forced labor.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 29 -- An extensive advertising campaign of Soviet goods has begun in the Ethiopian press.

Swelled by larger municipal and foreign refundings, the total of bonds called for redemption before maturity in December climbed to $49,191,000 from $26,984,000 in November, and $48,473,000 in December, 1960. This month's redemptions were the largest for any December since 1955, when $134,317,000 was redeemed.
Following is a translation of a broadcast by President del Gaulle last night, as made available by the French Information Service:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Needing 278 runs in four hours to beat South Africa on the last day of the second unofficial cricket test today, New Zealand fell 112 short and the match was drawn.
The value of new bonds offered the public here in December dropped from the year earlier level, while the value of new equity offerings in the month rose from the 1960 month.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The French Government has decided to recall 126 French citizens who are teaching in Egypt, it was authoritatively reported her today.

HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Led by Wilt Chamberlain, who scored 60 points, the Philadelphia Warriors rallied in the third quarter and beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 123 -- 118, in a National Basketball Association contest tonight.
Adlai E. Stevenson will appear as a commentator for a Columbia Broadcasting System television drama at 10 P.M. Wednesday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 29 -- The Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga and a Katangese official issued denials here today that the mining company had been involved in political or military activities against the United Nations.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Communist-built warships and submarines will strengthen this country's navy for the "liberation" of Netherlands New Guinea from Dutch rule, Indonesia announced today.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The New York State Historical Society has acquired one of the largest private historical libraries in the United States.
SEATTLE, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Five of Seattle's seven major banks announced yesterday they would increase interest on savings accounts to 3 1/2 per cent, effective on Jan. 1.

A two-story residence and studio building at 166 East Thirty-eighth Street, which has been occupied for many years by artists and sculptors, will continue its artistic tradition through the occupancy of William P. Katz, a young artist who has taken a lease on the house.
Al Sheridan, a fisherman, boat builder, truck driver and seal trainer of Island Park, L.I., said yesterday that that itinerant sea lion seen at Ocean City, N.J., was his pet Candy.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- St. Bonaventure, playing without its star, Miles Aikens, knocked DePaul from the ranks of the nation's unbeaten college basketball teams tonight with a 70-60 triumph in the semi-finals of the Motor City Classic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Air Force officials disclosed today that a $2,000,000 research contract was recently awarded to a West Coast rocket company headed by a retired Air Force general who also serves as chairman of the Air Force Scientific Advisory Board.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today reversed the conviction of John Cyril Hellman of Butte, Mont., charged with violating the anti-Communist Smith Act.

John T. Clancy, the Borough President of Queens, called on local Congressmen yesterday to give the Federal Aviation Agency "clear authority and responsibility for establishing and enforcing noise standard regulations for the aviation industry."

The nation's oceangoing merchant fleet -- passenger-cargo vessels, freighters and tankers of 1,000 gross tons and more -- totaled 933 on Dec. 1, the Maritime Administration reported yesterday. This was an increase of seven ships over the total on Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary of State Rusk declared today that Americans had "the nerve and the will" to protect their essential interests against Communist threats.

THE 1962 Downtown Lecture Series, sponsored by the Volunteer Associates of the New York Botanical Garden, will be given at 11 A.M. on four Thursdays in January at the French Institute Building, 22 East Sixtieth Street, New York City.

THERE are many names for mushrooms. Some people call them "mushrumps" and others, the country people of Ohio for instance, speak affectionately of "mushruins." Such colloquialisms, perhaps, attest to the popularity of a food that is admired the world around.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- The operettas of Gilbert and Sullivan will face the challenge of the twentieth century tomorrow with the lifting of the copyright on the lyrics of Sir William Gilbert.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30 -- President Kennedy has scheduled a series of high-level defense meetings next week, possibly as a preliminary to resuming the testing of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy will delay her trip to India and Pakistan until early March, it was announced today.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Secret negotiations with the Algerian Moslem rebels for a cease-fire and political settlement have made substantial progress recently, according to sources close to President de Gaulle.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Harold Wilson, the Labor party's spokesman on foreign affairs, and a leading Conservative newspaper joined today in an assault on Britain's Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, for his criticisms of the United Nation.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- Here in the nation's oldest city live hundreds of descendants stemming from certain families who can trace their origins in a common ancestry to the sixteenth century. This is through a long line of Spanish progenitors who remained here even during the English occupation from 1763 to 1783.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Britain's empire is scheduled to shrink still further in 1962.

I READ Leopold Stokowski's letter in your issue of Dec. 17 with great interest. I could not disagree with him more. I do not know how Maestro Stokowski in his few weeks at the Metropolitan gained such a profound insight into the workings of our house.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- A series of nine lectures on new directions in art, literature and philosophy will be offered at Sarah Lawrence College beginning Jan. 11.
The Green Bay Packers and the New York Giants appear evenly matched as they head into their play-off today for the National Football League championship.

IN the past few years about thirty different bromeliads have been grown in my New York apartment with gratifying results. The more I experiment with bromeliads the more I can appreciate their adaptability.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 30 -- Pakistan's decision to place the Kashmir dispute before the United Nations Security Council again next month was intended to forestall any military moves by India against Pakistan following India's victory in Goa, an official source said today.

Joseph Curran, chairman of the maritime committee of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, sounded a bleak note last week in a review of the outlook for the merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Diplomatic consultations on the conference on Cuba to be held by the Inter-American foreign ministers appeared today to be evolving toward a compromise.

CARLSBAD, N.M. -- Although the New Mexico desert rumbled for miles with the aftershock of the recent Project Gnome underground nuclear blast, every stalactite and stalagmite remained intact in Carlsbad Caverns, only thirty-four miles away.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A $300,000 defamation-of-character suit was filed yesterday in United States District Court here against the National Broadcasting Company and the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company.

IT is almost reassuring these days to read about war in its old fashioned, or pre-fifty-megaton, phase. In "Burn After Reading" the spies and counterspies, underground heroes and heroines, the psychological gambits, improvised plots and intricate plots begin to take on the charm of a period piece.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Ed Hippert paced Assumption to a 51-38 victory over Springfield in the Springfield invitation basketball tournament final tonight.

The answer is, when it is made to assume a place similar to that of the heavy-weight championship of the world -- or when it becomes simply one more political set-up by a government that is not even subtle about its intentions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Paul M. Butler, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, died today of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Unbeaten Villanova stole Iowa passes and turned them into field goals tonight for a 69-56 victory in the final of the Quaker City basketball tournament.
Two policemen were suspended early today on charges that they had tried to get money from a motorist caught driving into a street marked "do not enter."

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30 -- The Mexican Congress is finishing its annual session with what appears to be a record of having passed more reform legislation than any Congress since that in President Lazaro Cardenas' administration in the Nineteen Thirties.
HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -- Observers expect the coming year to be a critical one in South Vietnam's war with the Communist guerrillas.
Fancy wrinkles in latter-day ship design are making it difficult for shipmasters to observe centuries-old flag customs.

FOR families, as for the world of which they are part, the year now ending has been a year of tension. In some, the tightening has been barely perceptible, only a slight puckering of the mouth, metaphorically speaking, as the cloying sweetness of the Era of Affluence was cut by the astringent reality of world affairs.

THE Frick Collection is not frequently in the news, having made the only news it ever need make when it was opened to the public in 1935. Since then it has been a very nearly static institution, in spite of its lecture and concert programs.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 30 -- In India's view, the world situation has deteriorated considerably this year.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The average British family spent a pound ($2.80) more a week in 1960 than it did in 1959, a survey showed today. The 1960 weekly outlay averaged $46.20.
CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- The ninety-member Eastman Philharmonia of Rochester has received an enthuiastic welcome here this holiday season, and its two concert have drawn large audiences.

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) announced last week that major first steps had been taken in its $4,000,000 emergency program for the development of education in Africa, Three centers to promote a continent-wide information program, textbook production and school construction have just been opened and plans are gathering momentum.

THIS story about the family of Sir Thomas More, the saintly scholar-statesman executed for denying Henry VIII's claim to be head of the Church. will interest serious teen-agers well-grounded in the history of the Reformation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Ron Petro scored 32 points tonight to pace Manhattan to a 80 -- 77 victory over Northwestern and Illinois defeated Colgate, 88 -- 50, in a Chicago Stadium basketball program.

HONG KONG, Dec. 24 -- The year 1962 is expected to be critical for Communist China following setbacks at home and abroad during the last twelve months.

NEWARK, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Bob Gardner, a member of the Walker Cup and America's Cup golf teams, and Bill Skowron of the New York Yankees were named New Jersey's outstanding amateur and professional athletes for 1961 by the Newark Athletic Club today.

The Eastern team of Dick Miles, Bob Gusikoff and Bernie Bukiet scored a 6 -- 3 decision over a Western trio in a table tennis tournament that was completed at 2 A.M. yesterday at the New York Table Tennis Courts.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Expanded medical benefits for the aged will be recommended by Governor Rockefeller in his annual message to the Legislature next Wednesday.
Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears, an end, was voted yesterday rookie of the year for the 1961 National Football League season in a United Press International poll of writers.

THE number of states requiring compulsory inspection of motor vehicles continued to increase in the past year, even though slowly. Three more states joined the ranks in 1961, making a total of eighteen states and the District of Columbia carrying on active inspection programs.

Mayor Wagner named a new city Traffic Commissioner yesterday. He is Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Transit and Traffic in Baltimore.

Councilman Eric J. Treulich of Queens was selected yesterday to replace Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn as majority leader. Mr. Sharkey was replaced at the insistence of Mayor Wagner, who broke with him during the primary election campaign.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- In a campaign of badgering and harassments the Communist authorities have steadily chipped away at Western rights of access and movement in East Berlin during the last two months. At the same time, East German and Soviet officials have gradually increased pressure on Allied and West German traffic using the land routes to West Berlin causing delays for trucks and trains.

Now the question of how long the fare can be kept at 15 cents has been underscored as a result of a wage boost won last week by the 29,000 employes of the Transit Authority, which operates city-owned systems -- the subways and some of the bus lines.

There were signs of tension and doubt on all sides -- in the United Nations command, in the national Congo government, in the secessionist regime of Katanga province and among its foreign supporters.

The discovery contributes to a gradually clarifying picture of our atmosphere. This picture, in turn, leads to a greater understanding of the effect events on the sun have on earth.

If the Yankees do not swing another trade between now and the opening of the season next April, it will cause no great concern at 745 Fifth Avenue. And with good reason--a reason that may spell bad news for the rest of the American League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) --The House Committee on unAmerican Activities issued today a point-by-point reply to criticisms against its film, "Operation Abolition."

The Postgraduate Center for Psychotherapy has purchased the eight-story state officebuilding at 120-124 East Twenty-eighth Street at auction for $282,000. It will move there in March from its present quarters at 218 East Seventieth Street.
A new policy of curtailing week-end burials was introduced yesterday by a number of cemeteries in the metropolitan area.
Negotiations to avert a strike of 9,000 electrical construction workers were renewed yesterday under a second extension of the agreement that expired Sunday.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, the first of the nation's railroads to report its 1961 results, announced yesterday a net income for the year of $30,000,000, equal to $3.60 a share. This compared with the 1960 profit of $42,228,910 or $5.15 a share.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2-- The Lebanese Army announced tonight that it had shelled part of the village of Deek el Mehdi, where insurgents are still holding out.

Three pickets were arrested on disorderly conduct charges yesterday during a union demonstration at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, Fifth Avenue and 106th Street. A police sergeant was injured slightly while escorting a nurse through the picket line.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 2--Two top officials of the Planned Parenthood Center here were convicted today of violating Connecticut's eighty-three-yearold birth-control law.

HAVANA, Jan. 2--Premier Fidel Castro voiced defiance today of a Jan. 22 meeting of the Organization of American States' foreign ministers, convoked to discuss the Communist threat to the Western Hemisphere represented by Cuba.
MIAMI BEACH, San. 2 (AP) --The United States squeezed past a fired-up French team, 2 to 1, today to enter the semifinals of the Orange Cup junior tennis matches.
The city announced yesterday it had started charging fees for commercial still photographers using Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) --The Post Office Department submitted to the Interstate Commerce Commission today a plan that could raise parcel post rates 6 per cent, catalogue rates 13.8 per cent and revise size and weight limits of parcels.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., Jan. 2 (AP)--Representative John J. Riley, veteran Democratic Congressman from South Carolina's, Second Congressional District, died during the night of a heart attack at his near-by beach cottage.

The giant Bell System--American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal telephone subsidiaries combined-- cleared more in the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, 1961, than any other company has ever done in any single twelvemonth period.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The public school classroom shortage has eased, but only temporarily, the Office of Education reported today.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 2-- A special edition of the official newspaper Diario da Manha said today that eighteen persons were arrested in Beja and Tavira following yesterday's abortive attack on the military barracks at Beja. The paper said that not all the rebels had been caught.

BERLIN, Jan. 2--An interpreter has been assigned to the United States military police unit checking on the occupants of cars at the Friedrichstrasse border crossing to assist the servicemen in identifying Col. Andrei I. Solovyev, the Soviet commander in East Berlin, and his political adviser, Lieut. Col. A. Alekseyev.
ALGIERS, Jan. 2--The French Administration searched a waterfront district today as part of a hunt for the huge arms caches in Algerian cities.

The Amoskeag Company, holding concern of the Frederick C. Dumaine family of Boston, is negotiating the sale of its controlling interest in Avis, Inc., the second largest car rental agency in the country.

Mayor Wagner warned the strikebound Fifth Avenue Coach Lines yesterday that it would lose franchises for many of its routes unless it agreed "forthwith" to settle its contract dispute with the Transport Workers Union.
PARIS, Jan. 2--The new year begins with fresh signs of trouble in the traditionally nervous eastern Mediterranean, with anxiety centering on Egypt and Albania.
The Securities and Exchange Commission up to last night still was refusing to identify by name the so-called "hot issues" about whose underwriting it is questioning...

LONDON, Jan. 2--The Cunard Line disclosed today a sharp drop in the number of passengers its ships carried across the Atlantic last year. The total of 177,547 passengers was 30,000 below the 1960 figure.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)--Fires killed nearly 1,000 persons a month in 1961, the National Fire Protection Association reported today.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 3 (AP)--Paul Dietzel, football coach of Louisiana State University, today brushed aside questions whether he would go to West Point to become Army's coach.

Edward Teller, one of America's leaders in nuclear development, draws on his personal knowledge and experience to tell of the events and decisions in regard to this country's position in world affairs.
Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich ruled yester day that Hunter College must treat alike all organizations that ask to rent its facilities for meetings.
The American Stock Exchange announced offically yesterday the nominating committee's selections for filling nine places on the thirty-two-member board of governors, at the annual election on Feb. 12.

ALGIERS, Jan. 3--At least forty-one persons wore killed and seventy-eight injured in violence in Algerian cities today. The toll will probaby rise when complete reports are available The number of Moslem victims was given as thirty slain and seventy injured. The remaining casualties were Europeans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--New friction has developed in the Federal regulation of national banks.
The International Shoe Company, said to be the world's largest shoe manufacturer, had record sales of $152,100,000 for the six months ended on Nov. 30, Henry H. Rand, president, reported yesterday.
The Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases here has received a grant from D. Morgan Firestone, 29-yearold grandson of the founder of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.
Governor Rockefeller starts the final year of his term with an annual message to the Legislature that is both a program for action and a platform for re-election.

The City Council opened its new year and its new term yesterday by discarding its Democratic majority leader, Joseph T. Sharkey. By this action, Mr. Sharkey, also lost his title of vice chairman and reverted to the status of plain Councilman.
The police raided a telephone answering service in lower Manhattan yesterday and charges that in addition to taking calls for 500 legitimate clients the agency was taking bets for twenty bookmakers.
HASTINGS, England, Jan. 3 (AP)--Lisa Lane, who withdrew from the Hastings chess tournameat yesterday because she was lovesick, said today that she never would play competitive chess again.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3-- Unbeaten Villanova University sent Seton Hall to its first basketball loss of the season tonight. The Wildcats won, 99-- 67, before 4,000 fans at the Villanova field house. Seton Hall had scored four victories.

At a special meeting yesterday in Hartford, Conn., stockholders of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company voted approval of a recently announced plan to acquire the Aetna Insurance Company.

"THE INHERITOR," by R.C. Hutchin son, is a novel about the natural history of a man called Selborne. He chooses or is given various other names in the course of his search for true identity in the modern world. But Selborne is at the heart of the strange heritage he finds in his immensely complex odyssey.

The Metropolitan Chapter of the Women's League for Israel will hold the first of the league's seven theatre parties in the New Year next Monday at the St. James Theatre at the performance of the musical. "Subways Are for Sleeping." Mrs. Joseph Solovei and Mrs. Jim Pack are co-chairmen for the evening.
LONDON, Jan. 3--With buying tapering off following yesterday's burst of activity, price movements in the stock market here today were limited.
Pension funds and other institutional investors resumed yesterday the aggressive purchase of prime corporate debt securities.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 3--In a speech highly critical of the United States, President Fran ois Duvalier said yesterday that he had concluded that only Haiti could help Haiti.

Gaspar (Indian) Ortega, a welterweight from Tiajuana, Mexico, is known in the boxing world as "the matchmaker's delight." The 25-year-old Mexican will fight anyone at any time and at any place. In fact, he's the busiest man in the business today.

HOUSTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)-- The new team in the National Baseball League, the Colt 45's, broke ground for the world's first air-conditioned ball park today by using 45-caliber wax bullets instead of shovels to splatter a few cubic inches of earth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The United States has told the Inter-American Peace Committee that Cuba "represents a bridgehead of Sino-Soviet imperialism and a base for Communist agitation and subversion within the inner defense of the Western Hemisphere."
The new French luxury liner France has proved herself capable of matching the speed of the superliner United States.

THE producers and authors of "Fortuna," which opened last evening at the Maidman Playhouse, apparently are trying to emulate "The Threepenny Opera."

The Wellington Fund, Inc., ended its fiscal year with net assets of $1,422,513,478 equal to $15.67 a share on 90,749,409 shares outstanding, on Nov. 30. All figures were new highs for the giant Philadelphia-based fund.

But then the Army made him the involuntary shepherd of a flock of jeeps and light trucks.

Dr. George Frederick Mc Cleary, long a public health leader in Great Britain, died Monday in London at the age of 94. His family here has announced his death.

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 3--The Watchung Mountains in north-central New Jersey, long a favorite observation area for ornithologists, may soon become a "no man's land" for many species of birds now found there.

The United Nations Charter specifically outlaws the use and even threat of force except in self-defense and in United Nations action to suppress aggression. The National Motor Boat Show here is pre-empting extra time this year. Although the general public will not get inside the Coliseum until Saturday, Jan. 13, the two largest cruisers to be on display were moved into position yesterday, a week early.

Net operating earnings of the Chase Manhattans Bank were $70,533,320, or $5.05 a share in 1961, the bank reported yesterday. This was a decrease of 5.04 per cent from the $74,276,783, or $5.32 a share, cleared in 1960.

THE French novelist Jean Bruller, who calls himself Vercors, has long looked on the moral nature of mankind with a questioning and sardonic eye. Some years ago his savagely satirical fantasy, "You Shall Know Them," disturbed about as many readers as it delighted. Today a new Vercors novel, "Sylva," is published in this country and it is equally loaded with food for thought and with provocative complications.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--A telephone engineer has invented a circuit that can trace "nuisance calls" such as anonymous bomb threats. The person called presses a button that alerts the telephone central office and keeps the switches from being released until the source of the call can be determined.

THE flow of guest conductors at the New York Philharmonic continued yesterday afternoon, when Georg Solti conducted his first concert. He will hold the podium for two weeks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP)-- Feed grain futures lost a little ground today in quiet dealings on the Board of Trade. The market otherwise was steady to firm with distant rye months moving up more than a cent.

Wilson Co., Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries showed a sharp increase in sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Oct. 28, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

THE distinguished career of Evelyn Waugh falls neatly into two periods-- before and after World War II. When Mr. Waugh was young he was the most reliably comic of English novelists. His exuberant high spirits, his delirious comedy, his cheerful satire combined to make his cautionary tales irresistible. Mr. Waugh could be malicious in a feline way and cruelly savage in spurts, but his books were gay.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 7 (UPI) --General Manager Edwin Anderson of the Detroit Lions added two proposals today to playing-rule changes to be considered at the National Football League's three-day annual meeting opening here tomorrow.

The blockfront on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets has been purchased by an investor. Clark Wilcox was the broker.
Makers of environmental test equipment--devices that bring outer space down to earth--did an estimated business of $225,000,000 last year.

In terms of earnings, the railroads of the United States in 1961 suffered their leanest year since 1946. The results were particularly disappointing in view of the more than $15,000,000,000 expended during the fifteen-year period for such improvements as Diesel locomotives, pushbutton switching yards and centralized traffic control systems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7-- Wilbur Daigh Mills, who presides over one of the power centers of Congress, is a hard man to know. Members of the House Ways and Means Committee, of which he is chairman, found that out long ago. President Kennedy is doubtless finding it out now.

Store executives gathering today for the fifty-first annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association expect sizable increases in both sales and profits for the first half of 1962. This optimistic view was indicated by an association survey of 250 heads of department, specialty and variety stores representing almost $6,000,000,000 in total volume each year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7--Representatives of four hundred businesses with interests in trade between the United States and Japan estimated today that this country's sales to Japan provided almost 200,000 Americans with jobs.

ALBANI, Jan. 7--Governor Rockefeller plans to push his first major bill through the Legislature tomorrow or Tuesday.

WASHINGTON--This is the centennial year of the Department of Agriculture and of two laws of major importance to American agriculture. They are the Morrill Act, which created the national system of landgrant universities and colleges, and the Homestead Act, which opened vast acres of the public domain to settlement and agriculture.

Fire caused the deaths of nearly 1,000 persons a month in the United States last year, according to the National Fire Protection Association.

Alexander Brailowsky canceled his New York recital last season because a physician, told him he should rest his heart. This meant that his admirers, who assembled last night at Carnegie Hall for the only appearance he is making here this season, greeted him with especial warmth.

TRENTON, Jan. 10--Governor-elect Richard J. Hughes today received recommendations on how New Jersey might best collect up to $38,000,000 in income taxes withheld last year by New York from the pay of Jersey residents employed there.

The State Rent Commission ruled yesterday that the Devonshire Hotel, which Columbia University wants renovated to provide housing for its staff, was not really a hotel and was subject to rent control.

Two men were accused by the State Rent Commission yesterday of having made a business of obtaining rent increases through harassment and intimidation. They and twenty-two landlords, who paid for their services, face criminal and civil actions on four fronts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Following are the highlights of President Kennedy's State of the Union Address today:

More catamarans and trimarans than have been shown before reflect the continuing interest in the types and the production to meet it at the Coliseum. The multihulled craft are in both sail and power and range in size from 10 to 20 feet.

Cocoa futures prices continued to decline yesterday, joined by potatoes, which broke from their recent steady pattern. Both commodities were heavily traded, in sharp contrast to the dull pace of other commodities dealt in here.

Undaunted by the conspicuous absence of ski slopes and wooded trails in the vicinity of Broadway and 116th Street, Columbia's undergraduate athletic council will stage its own version of a winter carnival this week-end.

SOMEWHERE warm winds blow, the sun gives heat and fish fin happily in water that is not filled with ice. That somewhere is south of here and those anglers now succumbing to the impulse to show their heels to the North Star are not cowards. They have common sense.

IT is wonderful to have an original, ever youthful and increasingly wise writer like Thornton Wilder back in the theatre. It is especially good to welcome him back at the start of what may be his consummative adventure in the theatre.
The Transit Authority yesterday assigned a second motorman to its automated train on the Times Square shuttle, thereby giving the automated train one more motorman than an unautomated train.
The formation of a Citizens Advisory Committee for Federal Participation in the New York World's Fair was announced yesterday by Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges.

The Industrial Tractor Parts Corporation, an American subsidiary of an Italian company manufacturing tractor parts, has bought the block bounded by Fourteenth Street and Dutch Lane, Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Avenues, in Long Island City, Queens.

ALBANY, Jan. 11--State Controller Arthur Levitt today backed Governor Rockefeller's view that the state's school needs militated against a continuation of the 10 per cent rebate on personal income taxes.
Ever since Schenley Industries, Inc., parted company with Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., in mid-November, the $5,000,000 account has been eagerly courted by a number of important Madison Avenue agencies.

NEWPORT, R. I., Jan, 11 (UPI)--Frank Packer, the head of the Australian syndicate that will make a bid for the America's Cup in races off Newport next September, said today that Australians "regard this challenge as more demanding than the Davis Cup."
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest supermarket chain, operating about 4,350 stores, announced the declaration of three dividends for common stockholders yesterday.
New York's first major strike in the electrical industry in forty years began yesterday, but the initial impact was slight.

Senator Barry Goldwater announced yesterday that he had become a sponsor of the American Committee for Aid to Katanga Freedom Fighters. The Arizona Republican, a leading conservative, contended that the recent United Nations military action in the secessionist Congolese province of Katanga had given some Americans reason to regret the United States' "blind support" of United Nations policy.

Friends of the Manhattan School of Music are making plans for their theatre party at the Jan. 25 performance of "Subways Are for Sleeping" at the St. James Theatre. The evening's proceeds will go to the music school's scholarship fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) --Seven Senators introduced a bill today to aid American businesse and workers injured by import competition.

AMONG the new crop of eligibles this year for candidacy to the Hall of Fame is Philip Francis Rizzuto. Although he doesn't have the overpowering credentials of a Bobby Feller or the solid claims of a Jackie Robinson, the Scooter was a shortstop of rare distinction and rates the careful consideration of the voting members of the Baseball Writers Association.
Senator Barry M. Goldwater attacked the Administration's fiscal policies last night. He charged that the nation was bieng led to a "massive program" of economic regimentation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--A group of United States and British officials began today a review of the problems facing their countries in the United Nations. In both Britain and the United States, there has been increasing debate--inside the Government as well as in the press--over some of the activities of the United Nations, particularly in the Congo.
The United States Court of Appeals held yesterday that a civilian employe who enters military service while in a lay-off status is entitled to seniority rights on return to his job.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11--King Gustav VI Adolf opened the 1962 session of the Swedish Parliament today in a glittering ceremony attended by the royal family.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 11--An avalanche entombed the Andean village of Ranrahirca last night, killing all but fifty of its 500 people. The tiny community was buried under forty feet of ice, boulders and mud.
Technology apparently has begun to catch up with municipal power plants, and as a result the once-strong trend toward more city-owned electric companies has turned into a downtrend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The State Department will announce tomorrow new regulations that bar passports to Communist party members but allow anyone accused of party membership to confront and cross-examine his accusers.
Julian H. Singman, acting deputy maritime administrator of the Maritime Administration, called for some "rugged individualism" in the executive ranks of the maritime industry last night.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that "European predominance" outside Europe "can no longer be tolerated."
The Cott Beverage Company plans to diversify through the proposed acquisition of a controlling stock interest in Nedick's Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of about eighty-six luncheonettes.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 11-- A plan by United States officials to "defoliate" trees and bushes in South Vietnam with a chemical sprayed from planes as a means of combating Communist guerrilla operations has been delayed.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 11-- Elmer Adler, former curator of graphic arts at Princeton University and founder here of La Casa del Libro, a museum of fine books, died today at Pavia Clinic, Santurce after having suffered a heart attack on New Year's Day. He was 77 years old.
A study indicated yesterday that youths arrested in the "swastika epidemic" of 1960 had a common background of "family instability, psychological weakness and extreme personality rigidity."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- Civil rights legislation drew more attention from President Kennedy today than had been expected, but it was still doubtful that he would press Congress for action this session.

The long-awaited details of the Fifth International Food Congress, to be held here Sept. 8-16 in the New York Coliseum, were disclosed by officials of the event yesterday at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel.

New York and New Jersey officials reported "very satisfactory" progress yesterday on a plea for the Port of New York Authority to get into commuter railroad operations and to build a World Trade Center on the lower West Side.
The establishment by the Pentagon of a panel of distinguished citizens to assess troop-information programs meets one of the recommendations made in the now famous Fulbright memorandum.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 11 --Important progress was made today in the Common Market farm talks, but the negotiators found themselves confronted with a new deadline, Sunday. The Italian delegation has said that it cannot remain beyond then because of needs of internal politics in Italy.

THE technique of Dsuipainting--a collage made of numerous pieces of rice or bamboo paper stained with different colors--is employed most effectively by Tseng Yu-Ho, a Chinese-Hawaiian artist showing semi-abstract pictures at the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street.

Stockholders of Miles Laboratories, Inc., cleared the way for a 200 per cent stock distribution by approving an increase in the authorized common stock at a special meeting in Elkhart, Ind., yesterday.

In the final phrase of his message on the State of the Union yesterday President Kennedy referred to "the burden and the glory of freedom." This was not, however, a fighting speech. It had more burden than glory in it, and none of the sense of urgency about which we were hearing so much a year ago.

PARIS--The rage for kart racing--about 150 kart tracks for these little motor racers have sprung up in France in the last several years--has spread to the water with the "invention" here of the Sea Kart.

An official of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists explained yesterday why his organization declined to grant a waiver permitting its members to appear without pay on shows produced for WUHF-TV (Channel 31).
Dependability, ease of maintenance, low fuel consumption and low weight-to-power ratios are stressed in the Diesel engines at the show.
Joseph T. Sharkey was questioned for an hour yesterday about a reported offer of $60,000 made to him in 1958 to advance the political fortunes of Assemblyman Stanley Steingut.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP)-- Liquidation and hedge selling burdened the wheat and corn futures trade today and both grains added further steep losses to their recent declines.

The New Jersey Public Market Commission yesterday closed a financial transaction with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Hudson County banks assuring that $15,000,000 would be available to the commission to develop a public food center in Hudson County on a borrow-as-youbuild basis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--In his message to Congress today President Kennedy likened the militant acts of the United Nations in the Congo to those of a policeman who "uses his stick to restore law and order on his beat." But the order of the...
Nikita S. Khrushchev, when a youth, considered emigrating to the United States to earn higher wages, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday.
The increased interest in boats among women is leading to additional refinements and higher costs, says Drake H. Sparkman, president of Sparkman Stephens, New York yacht designers and brokers.

New boats had a big time yesterday at the New York Coliseum. Boats were inspected, measured, praised, even criticized. Boats were bought and sold. Most of the 6,000 persons who paced up and down the five floors of Coliseum aisles called it a boat show. But it was not.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The emphasis and melody of President Kennedy's second State of the Union message were significantly different from his first.
ALBANY, Jan. 11--The Long Island Rail Road was denied the right today to raise fares in advance of approval by the Public Service Commission.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $277,000,000 to $64,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Plans for a thorough overhaul of the Army Reserve forces, but without major reductions in their total strength, will be made known to Congress next week.

ROSETTE Pennington at its spring showing yesterday turned the bride into a quickchange artist. One basic white satin sheath became five different costumes. It was a sophisticated wedding dress with the addition of an elbow-length cape of satin and a formal train.
GROUCHO MARX returned last night to the Colum bia Broadcasting System in a television show little different from the program he formerly did for the National Broadcasting Company.
Renewed pleas for permission to build a bowling center in Grand Central Terminal are being made in the State Supreme Court here and in the United States District Court in New Haven.
Having had a brush with Broadway, earlier this season, the Second City players are now happily settled into a new cabaret called Square East, at 15 West Fourth Street--which is where they belong.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 11 (AP)--Three perfect games were rolled on the same pair of lanes at the $100,000 all-star bowling tournament today.

THE two men weren't brothers-in-law, but they had married sisters. There is no word in English for their relationship. Kent Warner, executive engineer of the Fullington Chemical and Pharmaceutical Corporation, was a successful industrial designer and business man. Arthur Scheuer, Professor of Biology at Rowley University, was a distinguished geneticist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) --The Treasury said today it would borrow a billion dollars of new cash next week through an offering of 4 per cent bonds maturing in seven years and nine months.
ALGIERS, Jan. 11--Top French officials here asked the army today to move additional troops into the seething cities of Algeria.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11--Soviet assessment of President Kennedy's State of the Union Message emphasized his expressed belief that "a resolution" of the problem of West Berlin "can be found, and with it an improvement in our relations with the Soviet Union."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- President Kennedy asked the Eighty-seventh Congress today to give him new authority to reduce tariffs, cut personal income taxes in an economic emergency and strengthen the welfare programs of the nation.
BERLIN, Jan. 11--The United States Ambassador in Moscow, Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., has received new instructions for his next round of talks with the Soviet Union on the Berlin problem.
NAPLES, Fla. NOTHING said here should be taken as criticism of the climate of New York. In a democracy every region is entitled to its own arrangements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The State Department agrees with Honduras that the National Labor Relations Board has no jurisdiction over 500 seamen employed by the Honduras Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the United Fruit Company.

CRUNCHY but flavorless iceberg lettuce is virtually the only food to cost less this week. It dropped 4 cents a head to a general price of 19 cents, and is offered at some stores for as little as two heads for a quarter. With the exception of green peas (down 6 cents, to 29 cents a pound) this is the only bright spot in a cold vegetable world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 --Congressional investigators heard testimony today that the operators of the airliner that crashed Nov. 8, killing seventyfour military recruits and three crew members, had a record of making false and misleading statements to civil air authorities.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, was honored on his seventieth birthday last night by more than 700 persons at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel marking his achievements in the health field.

Wall Street waited all morning yesterday for President Kennedy's State of the Union message. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange held about even until the noon hour. Then, with the possibility of unpleasant surprises removed, they moved steadily upward and closed at the best levels of the day.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11--The United Nations Special Fund approved a $42,800,000 program today to aid forty-eight new economic projects in thirty-eight "less developed" countries and territories.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- Newton N. Minow said today that the country urgently needed more television stations to give the public a greater choice of programs.
The United States Rubber Company announced yesterday the reorganization of its tire division as the United States Rubber Tire Company.

Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald reported yesterday that he had found no substantiation for charges that Newtown High School in Queens was disrupted by racial tensions. The charges were made last fall by two ministers in the community.

Some of the most adventurous and truly modern music that has been heard in New York this season was performed last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum. That it was composed by Claudio Monteverdi, who is now 300 years dead, doesn't matter in the slightest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)--Senator George A. Smathers said today that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was finished as a political factor in Central America.
One of the busiest doctors in town never gets a telephone call from a patient day or night and never has to listen to a complaint.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 (AP) --The Canton Company of Baltimore announced plans today for a $30,000,000 center for research, commerce and industry on a 200-acre site in the city's highly industrialized port district.
Baseball's New York Yankees were named the 1961 team of the year yesterday by 156 sportswriters and broadcasters participating in the annual Associated Press year-end poll.
ALBANY, Jan. 11--Joseph Zaretzki, minority leader of the Senate, suggested today that public hearings on conflict-ofinterest charges against Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino be televised.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- House Speaker John W. McCormack unwittingly wandered into a women's luncheon honoring Mrs. John F. Kennedy today.

The French Consul General, Raymond Laporte, boycotted a presentation of awards at Columbia University last night. He said he was apprehensive that one of the recipients might express views objectionable to the French Government.
It was no fit day in New York yesterday for a symbol of summer, but she went outside anyway.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP)--Bob Goalby, who led off the Los Angeles open golf tournament last week with a sevenunder-par 64, almost matched that performance today in the first round of the $25,000 San Diego open.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the time indicated in parentheses:
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 11 --President Sukarno disclaimed today any territorial ambitions for Indonesia beyond the transfer of the administration of West New Guinea from the Netherlands to Jakarta.
The Housing and Redevelopment Board has directed that sponsors of all Title I projects here clear publicity and advertising for their programs with the agency before releasing it.

Events today: "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Georg Solti, conductor, Irmgard Seefried, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Nathan Milstein, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; Peter Bornstein, violinist, Town Hall, 5:30; Samuel Baron, flutist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 6; Handel's "Jephtha," St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, 7:30.

WILMINGTON, Del, Jan. 11 --E.I. Du Pont de Nemours Co. announced today that it had awarded grants totaling $1,693,300 to 161 American universities and colleges in the company's annual program of aid to education.

A small Elmira, N.Y., departnent store that sent its emaloyes and executives out to start painting an unsightly railroad viaduct in the center of town was among three stores honored yesterday for outstanding community service.
HIGH POINT, N.C., Jan. 11 (AP)--The president of the Amateur Athletic Union charged today that a group within the National Collegiate Athletic Association was attempting to destroy the A.A.U.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (UPI) --The Montreal Canadiens, behind the spectacular goaltending of Jacques Plante, scored in every period to down the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4--2, tonight and regain first place in the National Hockey League.
A flurry of phone calls from shivering tenants in the present cold snap caused the Health Department yesterday to decentralize its system for receiving heating complaints.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) --The National Labor Relations Board ordered the Cone Brothers Construction Company of Tampa, Fla., today to quit threatening to shoot down employes "like a covey of birds." The board held that such threats were made during a union organizing strike in 1960.
MADRID, Jan. 11--A United States Air Force B-52H superbomber equipped for launching missiles broke a world record today by flying 12,519 miles non-stop from Okinawa to Madrid without refueling.
The New York Mets rolled up their sleeves yesterday. They signed four players and revealed that work on refurbishing the Polo Grounds had started.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 11--Vice Premier Antoine Gizenga reversed his position today and informed the central Government that he would return to Leopoldville from Stanleyville as soon as possible.
The head of a state inquiry on bingo will ask Governor Rockefeller to seek legislation requiring the licensing of both bingo hall owners and the suppliers of bingo equipment.
Wage increases were ordered yesterday for the city's laundry workers by the industry's impartial chairman.
Mr. Vice President, my old colleague from Massachusetts and your new Speaker, John McCormack, members of the Eighty-seventh Congress, ladies and gentlemen:
Frank D. Gilroy's play, "Who'll Save the Plowboy?," originally scheduled for a run of three weeks, will stay on at the Phoenix Theatre for an additional week, until Feb. 4.
Louis E. Stern, art collector, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 75.
Failure to redevelop and rehabilitate the part of Downtown Brooklyn that centers on the intersection of Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues can lead to chaos, the city was warned yesterday.
DENVER, Jan. 11 (UPI)-- Frank Filchock was dismissed today as head coach of the Denver Broncos, who set an American Football League record last season by losing seven games in succession.

Sales and earnings of Deere Co. rebounded sharply for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. The farm equipment producer registered an 80 per cent increase in profits on a sales gain of 9 per cent, according to the annual report issued today.
LONDON, Jan. 11--A little selling late in the session left most sections ragged on the stock market here today with net changes small.
Ratsey and Lapthorn, Inc., the 172-year-old City Island sailmaking firm, has devised a special auto trailer rig on which to study wind-flow on sails.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--A special study group called today for a national policy for development of educational television. The suggestion was made by the Educational Media Study Panel after more than a Year of study. A report was released by Dr. Sterling M. McMurrin, Commissioner of the Office of Education.
LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 11 --There are indications that Portugal is weighing a sharp shift to the Left in her foreign policy, including eventual recognition of Communist China.
At least fifty persons will climb aboard $20,000 cruisers during the Motor Boat Show and ask whether they can "go downstairs and take a look at that cute kitchen."

SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11 (Reuters)--The second violent earthquake in five day's rocked Yugoslavia's Dalmatian coast today and unloosed mountain slides of boulders as heavy as seventy tons onto villages.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) Jan. 11--A test of strength between religious and civil authorities of Israel was averted in the High Court today when the parties to a divorce case reached a settlement.

The steel-making furnaces of the United States produced 98,016,538 net tons of metal in 1961, the industry's seventh highest yield for a year, according to preliminary figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 11 (AP) --Ten countries have entered the world bobsled championships at this famous German resort, but unseasonably high temperatures, resulting in a big thaw, have prevented construction work along the mile-long Olympic bobsled course.
Yesterday's high-grade bond market did little more than mark time while awaiting disclosure of the Treasury's plan for a $1,000,000,000 cash borrowing in the public market.
Another challenner for Archie Moore's light-heavyweight title posted a $2,500 forfeit check with the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.
Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Economics Minister and Vice Chancellor of West Germany, defended yesterday his country's contributions to the economic development of the new countries of Africa and Asia.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 11-- Dr. Albert L. Weiner, 44-yearold osteopathic physician found guilty of transmitting hepatitis to twelve of his patients, who died, was sentenced today to State Prison for two to four years and fined $12,000.
Inboard-outboard engines, a novelty at recent shows, now power at least twenty-five of the craft at the Coliseum. In addition, two companies have boats with water jet engines.

A charge that it was engaging in "bossism and backroom politics at its worst" kept the F.D.R.-Woodrow Wilson Democrats from voting an endorsement for Congress in Manhattan's new Twentieth District last night.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 11-- Dr. William Pratt Graham, the first alumnus to become chancellor of Syracuse University, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 90.

THE problem in cooking for one is that by the end of the week the refrigerator is likely to be cluttered with a half-filled milk carton, a few slices of dry, hard bread and several small bowls. The bowls hold about half a serving of cooked vegetable, left-overs from a pan-broiled steals and other odds and ends that it seemed a crime to throw away.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- President Kennedy asked Congress today for authority to combat recessions with quick, temporary cuts in personal income taxes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11-- Authorities in Sao Paulo carried on their investigation today into the operations of the Bates Bag Company of Brazil, which requested receivership after losing about 600,000,000 cruzeiros (about $1,700,000) in credit dealings.
ROME, Jan. 11--The Central Committee of the Left-Wing Socialist party approved tonight a resolution that makes the party's inclusion in the Government a practical possibility.

COLUMBUS, a city so typically American that large corporations use it to mass test new soaps, detergents, toothpastes, shortenings and food stuffs before introducing them to the rest of the country, often ignores the decrees of the New York tastemakers, preferring instead to pick and choose among big-city ideas.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11-- A Federal grand jury indicted two more officials of the Teamsters Union today in the sale of $100 tickets for a legal defense fund dinner.
GENEVA, Jan. 11--The three rival Princes of Laos have accepted an invitation to come here to resume their talks on the formation of a coalition government.

THIS is the time of decision for parents who intend to send their children to camp this summer. While a few camps have already posted "No Vacancy" signs, most camp directors are approaching the peak season for camper enrollment.

LE HAVRE, France, Jan. 11 --The great ship France, possibly representing the last challenge of the superliner to the ascendancy of the airplane. was officially inaugurated here today in oratory, foie gras and champagne.
Business loans at the fourteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks declined during the week ended on Wednesday by $146,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

The Realty Collateral Corporation, a new real estate securities company sponsored by George W. Warnecke, opened to professional investors yesterday an offering of $40,000,000 of collateral trust notes secured by one-family dwelling mortgages approved by the Federal Housing Administration.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP)--The Riverside Farm's Buoy closed with a rush along the rail to win the feature at Tropical Park today. Pony Tracks was second and the favored Lay Aloft third.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11-- The program of the Alliance for Progress got under way in Brazil today with the signing of a third specific agreement this month between this country and the United States.

Frigid temperatures had ski area operators working overtime yesterday in an effort to prepare their slopes and trails for the week-end invasion by skiers. In New England's more northern areas, operations were concentrated on breaking down frozen surfaces with heavy machinery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Members of Congress viewed much of President Kennedy's enlarged legislative program today as a glittering prospectus of goals that were unlikely to be achieved this year, if ever.

THAT gayest of operas, Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro," returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night in a drab and spiritless performance. It was just one of those nights. Neither the orchestra nor the singers managed to get off the ground; and it cannot be said that the staging improves as time goes on.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP)-- A cold wave swept across New England today and set records in the shivering South.
THE Suffolk County championships will be played this week-end at the Malibu Beach Club in Long Beach, L.I., beginning this afternoon. The usual schedule for week-end tournaments will be followed.
One of the eighty donations received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases fund was a check for $225 from students of John Jay High School in Brooklyn.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 11 (AP)--Pierre Bougrat, a convicted murderer, who escaped from Devil's Island and became the unlicensed physician to the pearl fishermen of Margarita Island, is dead at the age of 72.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- The President's Committee on Labor-Management Policy submitted its first recommendations today. It called for compensation, education and retraining for workers to cushion the unemployment arising from automation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- Freight traffic last week was substantially above the levels of both the preceding week and the corresponding 1961 period, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.

There is a force at work beneath the Pacific Ocean whose nature is unknown, but whose annual toll in human lives is formidable. It manifests itself in exploding volcanoes, earthquakes, tidal waves, the upthrust of high coastal mountains and the downthrust of parallel trenches deep into the ocean floor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)--Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, promised today to wage a vigorous fight to head off Senate action on what he called a "private relief bill" for E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. The measure is the first legislation slated for debate in the new session.
A Bronx garage manager who refused on Wednesday to testify at the departmental trial of police Capt. Vincent J. Mansfield on extortion charges said yesterday that he had given $5 to the captain.

Mr. and Mrs. John F. Dryden 3d of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Atwood Dryden, to James Allen Carney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carney of Norfolk, Va.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission voted today in favor of a New York architectural firm's design for a memorial to the thirty-second President.
Another former registered representative of Sutro Brothers Co. testified yesterday that he had arranged for stock market loans to customers beyond the margin rules while at the brokerage concern.
The United Federation of Teachers recommended to the Board of Education yesterday that substitute teacher licenses be abolished.
Netherlands New Guinea, one of the most inhospitable and, as Samuel Eliot Morison puts it, "least wanted" parts of the earth, is after centuries of isolation the focus of an international crisis.
International airline sources said yesterday that proposed trans-Atlantic promotional fares had been rejected in a worldwide mail ballot among some ninety carriers.

Just before the turn of the century, a Michigan man with the appropriate name of Christopher Columbus Smith decided that the small wooden boats he built for hunters could be improved. He attached a small naptha-gas engine to one of his boats and went tooling down the St. Clair River.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP)-- The Council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association punished four colleges today for violations of the athletic code. The colleges were New Mexico State, Utah, Humboldt State of California and Whitworth College of Washington.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11-- As a result of an attempted coup that was suppressed just before New Year's Eve, the Lebanese Government is engaged in a national security campaign.
LONDON, Jan. 11--The Times of London will say editorially tomorrow that there was little "excitingly new" in the program President Kennedy outlined today, "apart from its plans for expanding trade."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) --The National Agricultural Advisory Commission outlined today a comprehensive approach to farm problems built around tough new controls for surplus crops.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 --Beauty alone may be enough to bring movie stardom to humans. But seals need talent.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan, 11--Mr. and Mrs. John S. Parker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Merrill Parker, to Le Howard Yearley. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard C. Yearley.
A leading drug company executive accused Senator Estes Kefauver yesterday of "distortion, evasion and bias" in a two-year investigation of the drug industry.
ALGERIA is being administered in these days of crisis by an expert in the game of calculated risks who is classed as one of the ten best bridge players in France.

The rejection of Mayor Wagner's fact-finding proposal by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers has shattered four decades of industrial peace and brought a strike that threatens to force idleness on all the city's 200,000 construction workers.

If the so-called "horse" race in outboard motors abated last year, it appears to have been resumed for 1962. The Kiekhaefer Corp., a leader in big power packages, has come out with the industry's first 100horsepower model.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city was drafting a local law setting up its own rent-control machinery.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 (AP)--Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., scored in both women's and mixed doubles today and kept alive her hopes for a triple slam ih the Australian National tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The Administration's "crisis center" is going out of business--not for lack of crises around the world but because of continuing dissatisfaction with the mechanics of handling them.
HARTFORD, Jan. 11 (UPI) --Governor Rockefeller suggested tonight that the United States should join the nations of Western Europe in a political "union of freedom."

The market for United States Government securities made a speedy adjustment yesterday to the implications of the Treasury's decision to raise $1,000,000,000 in cash by borrowing on 4 per cent bonds due in 1969.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 15-- The Rev. Dr. George Mair, for thirty-four years pastor of the Bedford park Presbyterian Church, Bedford Park Boulevard and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, died here today in Princeton hospital after a month's illness. He was 76 years old.

THE move of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to oust the Ama teur Athletic Union from three international federations is a cold, calculating and greedy grab for power by men unqualified for the assignment.

ALBANY, Jan. 15--The Democratic leader of the State Senate indicated today that his party's position on an income tax rebate would hinge on Governor Rockefeller's generosity in meeting Mayor Wagner's demands for more state aid.

ALBANY, Jan. 15--The State Judicial Conference filed a report today with Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature urging authorization for thirtyone new Supreme Court justices and seven new county judgeships. All but three of the thirty-eight judges would be in New York City and Long Island.

A report on the recent shutdowns of two Los Angeles newspapers and a discussion of the continuing disappearance of metropolitan papers will be televised by the Columbia. Broadcasting System on Jan. 25 from 10 to 11 P. M.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 15--A first step toward the removal of Michael Prendergast as Democratic state chairman was taken today at a meeting attended by Mayor Wagner and a half-dozen upstate Democratic chairman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15-- Several thousand women from Eastern cities picketed the White House today to protest against nuclear fall-out.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15-- "Growing concern" over the "inadequacy of the supply of scientific and technical manpower" in the United States was expressed by President Kennedy today.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 15--A drive to obtain a larger share of state school aid for the six largeest cities in the state was begun here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15--The state's new nonresident tax bill was passed by the Legislature and signed into law by Governor Rockefeller tonight. It is designed to protect New York against the loss of up to $45,000,000 a year it collects in income taxes from people who work in the state but live elsewhere.

ROME, Jan. 15--Premier Amintore Fanfani today laid the cornerstone of a $30,000,000 "Cinema Center" to be built near Rome, partly financed by the Government and under the direction of the noted moviemaker Dino De Laurentiis.

WESTBY, Wis., Jan. 15-- The East's ski-jumping fortunes continue to decline. Any doubt as to the status of the Atlantic states in this department was erased here yesterday when the seven places on the American team went to skyriders from the Midwest and Far West.

TRENTON, Jan. 15--Richard J. Hughes will be inaugurated as Governor here tomorrow. He will be the state's first Roman Catholic Governor, and the first Democrat since World War I to succeed another Democrat.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Jan. 16--An Indonesian military commander denied today that the naval craft involved in a clash with Dutch warships off Netherlands New Guinea yesterday were the vanguard of an invasion force.
WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 15--Since 1930 nothing had ever stopped the Lauberhorn ski races until last week-end.

THE jetstream hair dryer, introduced by John Fonder in New York, means that women will no longer have to waste endless minutes sitting beneath the dryer. The new machine, which is now in use in both his salons, can dry a set in seven minutes.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP)-- New-crop soybean futures posted their third successive moderate advance today on the Board of Trade, but the market otherwise tilted toward weakness.
A stolen car hit a liquor store clerk on a sidewalk and dragged him to his death here last night.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15--Mr. and bars. Nelson H. Howe have made known the engagement of bars. Howe's daughter, Miss Sallie Lawther Adams, to John Munroe Jr. of New York. He is
The St. Nicholas Society of the City of New York will hold its twelfth annual ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Jan. 26.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 15-- Mayor Thomas Gangemi presented to the City Council today a proposed 1962 budget calling for the expenditure of $43,402,000. This is $5,096,000 more than last year's appropriation and could result in a $12 increase in the municipal tax rate.

I have just one announcement. I am sure you are all familiar with the story in the morning papers of the documentation on the study of comparisons of those in our schools and universities and the kind of subjects which they study, which was published by the National Science Foundation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 15--New York city members of the Women's International Strike for Peace picketed United Nations headquarters to day, protected from a drizzle by placards reading "Peace Is the Only Shelter," "Peace or Perish" and "Stop Bomb Tests."

Many bomlers from the metropolitan area, New Jersey. Connecticut and Massachusetts have been shooting for and will continue to shoot for the right to compete against some of the nation's best at Madison Square Garden this spring.

Mrs. Marie Stokes Bostwick Gilbert, widow of Fitch Gilbert, lawyer and farmer, died yesterday in her home at 778 Park Avenue. She also had residences at Gilbertsville, N.Y., where her late husband resided, and at Aiken, S.C. Her age was 84.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 --The long and tortuous path of a famous Balzac short story through television and theatre is now entering what may be its final phase as a movie.

The sentencing of three defendants found guilty of the hold-up killing of a United Parcel driver was adjourned yesterday when it developed that a key prosecution witness had perjured himself on the witness stand.
PEOPLE who live in Greenwich Village know well the shopping advantages of their community and many seldom venture above Washington Square for clothes.
LONDON, Jan. 15--For the first time, responsible sources took a preponderantly gloomy view today of the prospects for progress in the Moscow talks on Berlin.

Wall Street indicated yesterday that it had serious doubts that the proposed merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads would receive a fast "green light" from the Government. Unconfirmed reports said the Justice Department was considering intervening on antitrust grounds.

THE Beethoven cycle of the Symphony of the Air, with Alfred Wallenstein conducting, continued last night at Carnegie Hall. There were no soloists; just music. The "Egmont" Overture and the Fifth and Sixth Symphonies made up the program.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 15--The Congolese Chamber of Deputies censured Antoine Gizenga, the absent First Vice Premier, today. The vote was 67 to one, with 4 abstentions.

Sent the annual Civil Service Commission report to Congress; sent to Senate proposal to provide "more equitable representation" for Africa and the Middle East on the board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency; held news conference; named Robert McClintock as United States Ambassador to Argentina.
Any further sharp increases in silver prices "would appear unlikely for the near future," according to Handy Harman, leading New York-based refiner and fabricator of precious metals.

THE practice of offering more than one kind of dessert at one meal seems to have faded in direct proportion to people's proportions, But even the most figure-conscious female has been known to fall for a hot pudding on a cold day.
Jose Gonzalez, a Puerto Rican middleweight, won an exciting slugging match from Kelvin Scott of Trinidad in the tenround main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
