A decisive turn of the tide appears to be developing in the Congo, promising success for the most massive executive action the U.N. has taken since the Korean war.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 15--The Dutch Cabinet held an emergency meeting tonight to discuss the clash of Dutch and Indonesian naval craft off the coast of New Guinea. Information available here indicated that the engagement did not presage an invasion by the Indonesians.

LONDON, Jan. 15--The London Stock Exchange Council decided at a meeting today not to put into force a rule barring the exchange's brokers from dealing in foreign shares with the London agencies of overseas concerns.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP)--A cold wave stung portions of the Midtwest today after the second major snowstorm in eight days. Many schools were closed and highway travel was slowed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15-- Cyrille Adoula, Premier of the central Congolese Government, will come here soon, officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)--The Kennedy Administration will ask Congress for authority to set up a new program to help turn unheeded farmlands into recreational areas.
ALGIERS, Tuesday, Jan. 16 --French administration and military leaders appealed to the population of Algiers last night to "say 'no' to murders and terrorism."
TELEVISION'S library of filmed biographies was further expanded last night with the presentation on Channel 4 of a portrait of Robert E. Lee. The study of
BERLIN, Jan. 15--East German Communist authorities released two United States Col. lege students today.
A former Kingfish of the "Amos 'n' Andy" radio show, accused of fraud in the sale of shares in an African development concern, has been barred from the securities business in New York State.

JEAN DE RIGAULT, the French producer who has been making tours of United States universities since 1958 with French classics, is back again. M. de Rigault was here last April and May with Moliere's "L'Ecole des Femmes."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 15--Brazil urged Portugal today to acknowledge the principle of self-determination for Angola. She also urged Portugal to prepare basic legislative and administrative reforms that would help Angola achieve selfgovernment.

In describing his plans for a bold revision of this country's tariff laws President Kennedy assured Congress that he did not intend to "neglect the safeguards" provided by "peril points" or "an escape clause." What does this mean?

AMERICANS in the very near future will be able to have their pie in the sky. Two model apartments, shaped like pie wedges and typical of the 896 apartments that will be the spectacular Marina City, went on view to prospective tenants in Chicago last Tuesday.
A BRAWLING, laughing, bitter sense of life courses through "Moon on a Rainbow Shawl."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) --The National Labor Relations Board eased restrictions today on the locations of picketing in certain circumstances.

Pleasure-boat folk--who learn to navigate in all kinds of weather, fair and foul--didn't mind the rain yesterday. They found the five floors of the New York Coliseum just as exciting as ever for the National Motor Boat Show.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 15-- Virginia's new Governor, Albertis S. Harrison Jr., recommended today a detailed program stressing industrial development and improved education.
The patience of the pilots negotiating with Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines is "wearing thin," C. N. Sayen, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, said last night.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said yesterday that it was dissatisfied with the way the port's shipping industry was reporting cargo losses and cooperating in the agency's efforts to combat pilferage and theft.

Arthur Hailey, author of "Runway Zero-Eight" and "The Final Diagnosis," has won the 1961 Doubleday Canadian Prize Novel Award for his third story "In High Places."
BONN, Germany, Jan. 15-- The Soviet Government was reported today to have demanded that its troops be stationed in West Berlin as part of any settlement of the Berlin problem.

The Ascension-St. James Bridge and Ferry Authority, La., yesterday financed the construction of a proposed bridge across the Mississippi River by the sale of $30,750,000 of revenue bonds to a banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Ins. and John Nuveen Co.

Milton Dammann of Bedford Hills, N.Y., who headed the American Safety Razor Corporation for many years, died on Sunday at his New York apartment, 150 Central Park South, after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

Somewhat late in the game in view of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's decision to organize a new controlling federation, the local college track coaches filed a ringing endorsement yesterday of the Amateur Athletic Union's conduct of their sport.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI)--An official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today he hoped that President Kennedy "has not forgotten" his civil rights promises.
Building contractors, hampered by a five-day strike of electrical workers, yesterday ordered a general shutdown of construction work in the city, effective Thursday morning.

VENCE, France, Jan. 15-- Edward Gordon Craig, one of the outstanding figures of the international theatre--actor, writer, stage-designer and theoretician--who has spent most of his life in voluntary exile, celebrates his ninetieth birthday tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan.15--The European Economic Community has agreed to make tariff concessions on United States agricultural exports that last year had a value of from $600,000,000 to $700,000,000, official sources said today.
The 1961 Club of Champions Medal, highest award of the Catholic Youth Organization of New York, has been won by Lieut. Gen. Edward J. O'Neill, commander of the First Army.

Toby Berman Co., manufacturer of women's sportswear and knitwear, has leased 10,000 square feet of space on the eighth floor of 525 Seventh Avenue for its office, showrooms and stockroom. Nilo Kleinberg, architect, will redesign the quarters.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP)--More than 120 specialists in internal medicine submitted conditional resignations from Blue Shield today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 15--The Finnish people voted in unexpectedly large numbers today at the start of the two-day Presidential election.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 15 (AP)--The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision in an anti-trust case that required a Los Angeles local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to expel "grease peddlers" as members.

MIAIMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15 (UPI)--An eleven-point report presented to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee today, included three proposals for improving safety on the field.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 (UPI)--Leonard Homel, the founder of the National Bowling League, today withdrew his Los Angeles Toros from further competition because of continued financial losses.
JAKARTA, Wednesday, Jan. 17--At least twelve prominent Opposition political leaders have been arrested by Indonesian military authorities on unspecified charges.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 16--Paul-Henri Spaak, Foreign Minister of Belgium, told the United Nations today that the Belgian trust territory of Rwanda-Urundi would receive independence "as rapidly as possible after the end of April."

There was a period in history when the people of New Jersey seemed content with a state government negative in nature and limited in action. But in recent years a new philosophy, a new role of government, has begun to take shape--government unafraid to act in the peoples' service.
A section of Louis Nizer's belt-selling book, "My Life in Court," will be made into a play scheduled for Broadway next season.

Stockholders of the Punta Alegre Sugar Corporation, whose Cuban assets were taken over by the Castro regime in 1960, were told yesterday that efforts were being made to overcome that loss by acquiring other companies.
Commissioner Frank J. Lucia of the Sanitation Department declared yesterday that the city was 85 per cent "clean."
GENEVA, Jan. 16--Prince Boun Oun, the Right-wing Premier of Laos, defied today the pressure of three major powers to make him give way in the negotiations for a new coalition government.

The city Board of Education was accused yesterday of having a "racial quota" high school policy that had resulted in assigning aprpoximately 90 per cent of the Negro pupils to 20 per cent of the city's high schools.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 16--The Dutch Government stressed today its continued willingness to negotiate with Indonesia about Netherlands New Guinea, despite the clash yesterday of naval forces of the two countries off the southern coast of the disputed territory.

NONG, Laos, Jan. 16--The Laotian neutralists and proCommunists, acting in conjunction with several units from Communist North Vietnam, are moving men and equipment into positions from which they could try to smash through central Laos to the Mekong River.
A series of feature films about opera will start Jan. 28 on WOR-TV.

The New York Central and New Haven Railroads are again petitioning for permission to build bowling alleys in Grand Central Terminal, a proposal that was turned down by the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals a year ago to the applause of many architectural and civic groups.
A Kings County grand jury will meet today to investigate the charge that a $60,000 bribe was offered to Joseph T. Sharkey, the outgoing Brooklyn Democratic leader.
ALGIERS, Jan. 16--Louis Joxe, French Minister for Algerian Affairs, was reliably reported tonight to have indicated that the chances for an early cease-fire in Algeria were imimproving.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 16 --Miss Katharine Simmons Jarratt and Alfred John Law 3d plan to be married here on Feb. 3.
A total of 741 persons were hurt here last week in car crashes, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was a decline of ten compared with the like 1961 period.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16--A Lithuanian Roman Catholic priest accused of illegal currency and commodity operations was said to have admitted today the sale of dollars and goods received in parcels from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan.16 (AP) --Industrial production increased one point further in December to a record of 115 per cent of the 1957 average, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DETROIT, Jan. 16--Automobile sales got off to a slow start in the first ten days of January but were better than in the 1961 period. New car deliveries from Jan. 1 to 10 totaled 141,347 domestically built vehicles, or the equivalent of 17,668 units a day, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, trade publication. WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- President Kennedy sent to Congress today a drastic and possibly controversial plan to reorganize the Army's headquarters.
Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union reported substantial progress yesterday in its campaign to organize the clerical and reservations personnel of Air France.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The White House told questioners today that President Kennedy had accepted honorary membership in a Washington country club that had a discriminatory admissions policy.

A few years ago Premier Salazar of Portugal referred contemptuously to what has been happening in Africa as "the so-called winds of change." This week, in the U.N. General Assembly debate, Dr. Vieira Garin of Portugal spoke of "the so-called situation in Angola."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 16--The Dutch sinking of an Indonesian naval craft near Netherlands New Guinea constitutes a "challenge and war provocation," a military spokesman declared today.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday postal rates being considered by Congress would increase postal costs for some newspapers 100 per cent or more.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--Trans-Way upset the form players today when he won the $62,200 Tropical Park Handicap in a driving finish. Aeroflint was second and Vapor Whirl third in the field of ten.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--Jim Fisher of Belmont, Mass., today hit a holein-one that was worth $50,000 to him. It came on the fifteenth hole of the Professional Golfers Association club and quarter-century championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- The new chairman of the House Committee on Science and Astronautics predicted today that the multi-billion-dollar race to the moon would more than repay its cost by stimulating new technological advances on earth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)--Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today that President Kennedy was requesting a $10,000,000,000 increase in the national debt limit.

A Tennessee fall-out shelter manufacturer charged last night that Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino and Some of his associates were trying to "ruin" him because of an affidavit he gave to New York State Assembly investigators.
ALBANY, Jan. 16--Speaker Joseph F. Carlino declared today that an affidavit implicating him in conflict-of-interest charges was "obviously false and fraudulent."
Sales and earnings of the General Foods Corporation for the quarter and nine months ended on Dec. 31 were the highest for those periods in the history of the big food and grocery concern.
Ron Petro scored 28 points and Alex Osowick 25 in leading Manhattan to a 75-58 basketball victory over Adelphi in Alumni Gymnasium last night.

President Kennedy has indicated that his delay in signing his long-promised Executive Order forbidding racial discrimination in Federally aided housing stems from a belief that he should not get too far ahead of public opinion in pressing for civil rights. If this means that the President believes the surest way to move ahead...
ALBANY, Jan. 16--Mayor Wagner was told tonight that strong opposition had developed to his plan to have a committee of three replace Joseph T. Sharkey as Democratic leader of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The nation's largest defense contractors have agreed to meet with President Kennedy to sign nondiscrimination pacts guaranteeing equal opportunity to all employes.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 16 (AP)--Prof. Ivan Mestrovic, resident sculptor at the University of Notre Dame, died tonight of a massive stroke. He was 78 years old.

Rails managed to hold a little better than even yesterday as industrials fell on the New York Stock Exchange. The market opened with a decline and went downhill in every hour except the fifth, when there was a slight rally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)--Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, called the du Pont Corporation the "biggest monopoly complex in the world" today. He asserted its control of the giant General Motors Corporation would be continued under a pending tax relief bill.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 16-- The Jackson State Times, an afternoon and Sunday newspaper that would have been seven years old Feb. 28, ceased publication today.

KON BRAI, Vietnam, Jan. 15--Dead calm has enveloped the central area of Communist-harassed South Vietnam. The Government is using the breathing spell to regroup its forces and try to shift from static to mobile warfare.
BERLIN, Jan. 16--The United States Army has begun withdrawing its armored guard, including fifteen tanks, from a camp on the Friedrichstrasse on the border between West and East Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- Arthur Schlesinger Jr. has become the first Harvard professor on leave to make a choice between academics and the Administration.
The sixth annual Frostbite Rally of the Sperry Sports Car Club has been scheduled for Sunday, Jan. 28. This one will be run regardless of weather conditions.
The City University has been granted fourteen fellowships under the National Defense Education Act for study in the doctoral programs it will undertake next fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The long ban on photographing, broadcasting and telecasting of House committee hearings remained unshaken by a floor test today. Speaker John W. McCormack in a ruling requested by a persistent advocate of rules changes, stood by the prohibitions imposed by the late Speaker, Sam Rayburn.

AN artist, like a bandit, is often more valuable dead than alive. After his death, prices go up. Some artists refuse to so accommodate the demands and necessities of business and live on and on and on.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--Dario L. Toffenetti, owner of the Toffenetti restaurants in Chicago, New York and St. Petersburg, Fla., died today in Henrotin Hospital here. He was 72 years old.

James E. Patrick, formerly executive vice president, has been named president of the Valley National Bank, Phoenix, Ariz. He succeeds Carl A. Bimson, who was named chairman of the executive committee. Walter Bimson continues as chairman of the board.
ALBANY, Jan. 16--The two top Republican leaders in the Legislature endorsed today a proposal to set up a special commission to revise the state's per capita aid formula.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 11 points off today on the New York Cotton Exchange.
LONDON, Jan. 16--Prices moved narrowly and irregularly on the stock market here today in a quiet session. The industrial leaders remained firm.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 16--A two-day hearing got under way today to determine the future of the abandoned Mitchel Air Force Base.

HELSINKI, Finland, Wednesday, Jan. 17--President Urho Kekkonen was virtually assured of a second six-year term today after a two-day election in which the only unresolved issue was how many would turn out.
A youthful group from all the continents of the world has been having a tennis ball in the United States and will start the homeward trek tonight with fond memories.

Roger H. Lewis, former promotion executive at United Artists, and Philip Langner, associate producer of "Judgment at Nuremberg," have announced their partnership as a new independent production team. A MICROSCOPE club, a nature club and an anthro pology club are among the clubs open for members at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Other clubs include a pet club, a pottery club, an actors' workshop and a chemistry club. There is no membership fee. For information, call PResident 4-2900.

An American edition of the autobiography of Emlyn Williams, the actor-playwright-director, will be published April 11 by Random House. In it Mr. Williams tells of his first twenty-one years--how he grew up, won an education and found a place on the London stage.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 16--A beautiful princess saved the day for Italian fashion. Vivacious and charming Princess Irene Galitzine, whose throaty and seductive voice always. 'Sounds as if she has a case of laryngitis, is one of the Italian couture's most admired and popular designers.
The Citizens Union proposed yesterday the nonpartisan election of judges to the new citywide Court of Civil Jurisdiction, set up by a state constitutional amendment last fall.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 16-- Concern was voiced here today over what was described as the "increasing secularization" in the nation's institutions of higher learning and in general campus life.
Twenty-two public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration plan to sell bond issues aggregating $79,550,000 on Feb. 7.

THE crowds thronging the National Motor Boat Show at the Coliseum are sprinkled with fishermen who, on the whole, are easy enough to spot. One looks for twitchy hands, a vacant stare and an uneasy demeanor, as if the angler were contemplating doing something he shouldn't. Something like buying a boat he doesn't need or can't afford.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP)--A New York horse, John William, surprised a crowd of 21,500 at Santa Anita today by upsetting Ole Fols in the $12,000 Arcadia Exchange Club Handicap.

LONDON, Jan. 16--Hannen Swaffer, one of Britain's bestknown and most flamboyant journalists, died here today in University College Hospital, He was 82 years old.
A judge here reported yesterday that he would require a all foreign-language defendants given suspended sentences to attend night school English classes.

Mrs. William G. Cahan and Mrs. Stephen Van Rensselaer, co-chairmen, and their aides have chosen the March 5 and April 2 performances of "No Strings" as benefits for the Museum of the City of New York. The musical is scheduled to open at the Mark Hellinger Theatre on March 1.
Mary Jenson, who says he has "always wanted to manage a heavyweight champion," is undertaking a far-reaching talent search to obtain one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- The Internal Revenue Service warned for the first time today against abuses of income tax regulations concerning the donation of works of art to museums and other institutions.
Most commodity futures declined in trading yesterday on the New York exchanges, with cocoa again leading the way.

THE program presented by the Composers Group of New York City in Carnegie Recital Hall last night came to a close with Charles Haubiel's "In Praise of Dance," for oboe, violin, 'cello and piano. The program also came to life at this point.

The Hughes Tool Company and the General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that they had reached agreement on "all matters" surrounding the tool company's purchase of Convair 800 and 990 jet transports.

The introduction of automated procedures to the fabrication of electronic microcircuitry was announced yesterday by Lear, Inc. The company displayed a new, high-vacuum deposition system at its Santa Monica, Calif., solid state physics laboratory.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP)--Three Navy airmen were killed today in the flaming crash of their two-engine Beechcraft while practicing landings.

Kenneth MacKenna, noted stage and screen actor and former editorial director of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studio, Culver City, Calif., died Monday of cancer in St. John's Hospital, Santa Monica, Calif. He was 62 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 16 (AP) --The tickets for the National Collegiate basketball semi-finals and final at Louisville were all gone today after being on sale one day.
Harold H. Helm, chairman of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, cautioned bankers yesterday against paying excessive interest rates for deposits.

ALVIN ROTH and Tobias Stone conduct a department in the magazine Bridge World in which they quiz advanced players on the most difficult bids and plays. They require contestants not only to find the correct answer but also to tell why it is best.
A general leveling-off process in harness racing is evident despite the record year the sport enjoyed here in 1961, the New York State Harness Racing Commission said yesterday in its annual report.

Within forty-eight hours after the European Economic Community established itself as a virtually unbreakable entity in world affairs, the United States concluded its first trade agreement with the Community as such.

Because a retired New York furrier went out without his overcoat in Jerusalem about a year ago, Israel is well on the way of developing a mink-raising industry. Herman E. Meltzer, the retired furrier has been a busy man since Jersalem's winter breezes made him think that Israel would be a good place for mink breeding.
Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., has lost nearly $4,000,000 in billings as a result of two account shifts, it was disclosed yesterday.

IN the seventeentn century, so much salmon was caught in the rivers of England, Scotland and Wales that the fish was considered too common for aristocratic tables. Today, the fish is both scarce and costly everywhere. In this country, even canned salmon is so high in price that its use is reserved for special occasions.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18 (AP) --Warren Spahn, the highest salaried pitcher in baseball history, signed for his eighteenth season with the Braves today. The 40-year-old left-hander is believed to have received a token increase over his 1961 figure of $75,000.
GENEVA, Jan. 18--The three contending princes of Laos finally met today, but their meeting ran against the stone wall put up by Prince Boun Oum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Freight volumes last week were higher than in the preceding holiday week, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 18--An African who was seized by the South African police in Basutoland and forcibly taken across the border is to be freed and returned to the British-administered enclave.
LONDON, Jan. 18--The stock market closed on a firm note today, although turnover remained small.
Robin Roberts, once an exclamation point among pitchers but now a question mark on the mound staff of the Yankees, signed his first contract with the world champions yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 18--The Earl of Snowden, Princess Margaret's husband, has been hired as artistic adviser to The Sunday Times "for his ability," the newspaper's publisher, Roy Thomson, asserted today.

LICIA ALBANESE sang her first Cio-Cio San of the season in last night's "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera. A capacity audience cheered her vociferously at many points during the performance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) --A $438,000,000 increase in current health and welfare programs and another $1,170,000,000 for new activities--including general aid to education-- were requested today by President Kennedy in his budget message.

Roger Maris went to the plate officially last night for the eighth time since the baseball season ended last October. The offering was served up on a silver platter, and Maris tooks is small cut.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21--Steel officials said their market was strong but orderly last week.

The Cherry Lane Theatre, 38 Commerce Street, will be an unusually busy showcase between Feb. 11 and March 11. During those four weeks, the house will cater to "The Theatre of the Absurd," a recent development in contemporary drama. The producing team of Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder will put on, in repertory fashion, ten representative works by avantgarde dramatists.
The far-reaching effects of the building of the Aswan Dam and the High Dam in Egypt are discussed in "High Dam Over Nubia," by Leslie Greener.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21-- Cross winds are swirling about the bay area. In contrast with the capricious eddies that harass the baseball Giants and their rival National League clubs at Candlestick Park, these winds are not meteorological.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 21-- Two American nurses bravely continue their roving assignments in South Vietnam despite rising activity by communist guerrillas.

THIS is the season for department stores to present model rooms, and Gimbels today takes the wraps off its seven room settings. The rooms were designed by members of the store's recently revitalized Decorating Studio, and are composed of furnishings available on the ninth floor.

In former years, advertising agencies wishing to establish footholds overseas normally went about it in one of two ways. Either they simply opened a branch office abroad or they established some sort of loose "association" with a foreign agency.

Dr. Mark C. Schinnerer's report on New York City's schools went far beyond the recommendation that the Board of Examiners be abolished; but that is the proposal on which some of the city's school administrators are concentrating their fire. In doing so, they are skirting the real issues.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 21-- Iranian security forces put down today a demonstration by supporters of former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, arresting 300 students in a threehour clash at Teheran University.
The election of a New York County Democratic leader stood as the first item on Mayor Wagner's political calendar last night as he returned from a busy week-end in Washington.
PROGRESS came to television last night under trying circumstances.
NINE upper-echelon members of the Milwaukee Braves recently concluded a five-day promotional tour of the Wisconsin hinterlands. The first stop was Racine.
IT was the turn of the conservatives once again at the Donnell Library Saturday night. The fourth concert of the Composers' Forum offered music by H. J. Koellreutter and David Cohen.
A Los Angeles lawyer who was "bumped" from a Trans World Airlines flight in October, 1959, has been awarded $5,000 in damages by a Federal District court in Southern Califorina.
I MUSICI, the excellent, elegant Italian string group, was back in Town Hall Saturday night with a finely textured program of chamber orchestra music.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes declared yesterday that diplomats of lower rank than Ambassador should not get immunity from tickets for illegal parking.
What do Soviet children dream of? "Our children dream of conquering space, of going to the moon and Venus. They want to become builders, designers, to grow bumper crops. They ardently desire peace."
Columbia College yesterday joined the increasing number of colleges and universities that are casting doubt on the importance of entrance-examination scores.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has asked the Federal Maritime Administration to determine promptly whether it plans to provide differential subsidies for building two giant ore carriers in United States shipyards.
ALGIERS, Jan. 21--Raiders of the outlawed Secret Army Organization overpowered a French Army detachment at a military post near Oran at dawn today and made off with many weapons and other equipment.

Governor Rockefeller is receiving these days what amounts to a windfall profit from the strife within the Democratic party. Leaders of the various Democratic factions are so busy with past, present and prospective battles with one another that few can spare the time to take on Mr. Rockefeller.
NEWARK, Jan. 21--Puerto Rican leaders in northern New Jersey are planning to revitalize organizations interested in weaving the Spanish-speaking minority group into the pattern of urban living.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 21--Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the success of the Alliance for Progress program depended on the security of the Western Hemisphere against outside interference.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 21-- The rift between two rival blocs of African nations was substantially widened today when members of the so-calied Casablanca group announced their refusal to attend a foreign ministers' conference called here for tomorrow.

ALGIERS, Jan. 21--The general "mobilization" decreed in Algeria by the outlawed Secret Army Organization is regarded as a move to strengthen the extremist movement's control of the European population.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21-- Jon Douglas scored a 5-7, 3-6, 6-1, 6-2, 7-5 victory over Ron Holmberg today and won the first annual Philadelphia invitation indoor tennis tournament.
A solemn mass was offered in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A.M. yesterday for the conversion of all non-Catholic Christians to Roman Catholicism.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 21--Schnapps by the fireside in the Bear Mountain Inn lodge, skating on Hessian Lake and the ski-jumping competition off the 50-meter hill today attracted a crowd estimated at 35,120, the largest in the history of winter sports at this State park area.
TWIN LAKES, Colo., Jan. 21 --An avalanche crashed down Colorado's highest mountain before dawn today, engulfing three ranch homes and a cabin.

Legislative proposals for the reform of New York City's schools will be discussed by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, and the State Board of Regents in conferences Wednesday and Thursday.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI)--The final round of the $50,000 Bing Crosby national pro-amateur golf tournament, hit by the worst weather in its history was postponed today until tomorrow.
GEN. VICTOR LUNDULA, who commands Congo lese military forces in Eastern Province, once told a departing European: "When you return home, tell your people we are not Communists."

Is there a wiser, more warmhearted musician anywhere than Andres Segovia? This question was pleasantly answered for a capacity audience in Town Hall last night, where the great Spanish guitarist made his first appearance of the season.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art's three famous but fraudulent terra cotta Etruscan warriors have been removed from their large gallery to a kind of morgue. For decades they were labeled "5th Century B.C." Last year the museum dated them properly--modern.

ALTHOUGH the program presented last night in the Kaufmann Auditorium of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association was called "The Elizabethans," it also could have been called "A Literary and Musical Excursion into the Golden Age."
ROME, Jan. 21--The pilot of the Bulgarian MIG fighter plane that crash-landed near Bari yesterday afternoon has asked for political asylum in Italy.
The Metropolitan Chamber Orchestra made its debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall under the direction of Julius Grossman.

E. F. Hutton Co.'s quarterly analysis of portfolio changes by mutual funds showed no clear-cut trend in the final quarter of 1961.

National Motor Boat Shows in New York have come and gone fifty-two times. They make January a gala occasion for families thinking of summer vacation days. The exhibition that ended last night in the Coliseum made the heaviest impact of all.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21-- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon said today that reducing the large number of unemployed was the nation's most serious economic problem this year.

MANILA, Jan. 21--President Diosdado Macapagal restored a free economy in the Philippines today with a sweeping order abolishing controls that have been in force for thirteen years. In effect, the peso was devalued.
BELLMORE, L.I., Jan. 21 --An unknown author and chocolate cigars that melt are among the trappings of a play to be given in Freeport tomorrow night.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP)--Declines far outnumbered advances on the grain futures market last week and prices on the Board of Trade extended their general downward ...
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 21--A program to promote speedier integration in Northern schools was outlined today by the American Jewish Committee.

The Fifth Avenue Hotel has been sold. The eighteen-story building at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street has 644 rooms, three ballrooms, a sidewalk cafe and the Amen Bar, which was well known years ago as a gathering place for politicians.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21 (AP)--Premier Boun Oum and his deputy, Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, returned today from Geneva. They reported they had reached no final accord there for the formation of a coalition government.
Walter Hagen, the fabulous match-play golf champion of the Twenties, believes the professionals should revive the match-play championship.
RACINE, Wis., Jan. 21 (AP) --J.I. Case Company reported today a loss of $32,339,000 in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1961, compared with a loss of $39,815,000 in 1960.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 21--Former President Joaquin Balaguer has sought political asylum with the Papal Nuncio here, an announcement from the Presidential palace said today. Military Chief Faces Trial

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 21--Cuba's delegation, led by President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado, was in selfimposed isolation at a beachside hotel today while diplomats from other American republics consulted on how best to deal with the Cuban problem.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 --Joseph Conrad's "Lord Jim" will be made into a movie as a result of an unusual deal: Columbia Pictures did not know that Richard Brooks planned to make this picture when it signed a multiple-film contract with him.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (AP)--Jim Beatty had nothing but praise for Michel Jazy of France, whom he defeated in a thrilling mile at the Los Angeles invitation indoor track and field meet last night. Beatty way named the outstanding athlete in the meet.

CARMEL, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP)--Robinson Jeffers, one of the most honored of American writers and poets, died late last night at Tor House, his home here. His age was 75. He had been ill for many months.

OFFICIALLY, Alfred Sheinwold is the co-author with Edgar Kaplan of the Kaplan-Sheinwold bidding system, which includes such devices as weak no-trumps, forcing no-trump responses, inverted minor-suit raises, and similar bridge esoterica.
FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., Jan. 21--The New Jersey Audubon Society today expressed "cautious optimism" that breeding bald eagles might be staging a slight comeback.

A plan for the purchase of the Cosden Petroleum Corporation by W.R. Grace Co. was announced over the week-end. The plan is subject to a reserve production payment and the necessary favorable tax rulings by the Internal Revenue Service. Also, it is subject to approval of directors and stockholders of Grace and Cosden.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 21--Chuck Ferries, a 22-year-old skier from Aspen; Colo., and Denver University, won the Hahnenkamm slalom race today and finished second in the combined to Gerhard Nenning of Austria.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21--More than twenty Navy ships were steaming to posts across the Atlantic today in preparation for Wednesday's first attempt to put an American astronaut into orbit.

Faced with spiraling operating costs and with the prospect of another rise in postal rates, the magazine industry is quietly making some important changes in circulation policy that will directly affect the ordinary subscriber.
Edwin L. Posner, 71 years old, was elected top executive of the American Stock Exchange at a special meeting late yesterday afternoon.

LIKE all great violinists, Isaac Stern makes violin playing sound the easiest thing in the world. His stubby, iron fingers fall easily and unerringly on the strings, and it appears impossible for him to hit an off-pitch note.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Following are the highlights of today's Economic Report by President Kennedy and of a report by his Council of Economic Advisers:
State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh sought yesterday to have his trial on charges of obstruction of justice separated from that of one of four other co-defendants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- The House Republican Policy Committee agreed unanimously today to insist that any bill to increase postal rates include a ban on handling propaganda mail from behind the Iron Curtain.

Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, proposed yesterday that consideration be given to extending the Federal Reserve System's operations into the field of foreign exchange.

The President's Economic Report and the associated report of his Council of Economic Advisers deal with three key subjects: evaluation of the economy's recent performance and its prospects this year; the economic philosophy of the Administration; and the measures the President requests to put that philosophy into effect.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 22 (AP)--Johnny Antonelli announced his retirement from baseball tonight.

ROME, Jan. 22--The Defense Ministry declared today that it could not state positively whether the Bulgarian pilot who crash-landed Saturday was a spy or a defector, but the ministry's statement indicated that military authorities believed the incident represented "a true and real case of air espionage."

A streamlining of its organization and a realignment of executive responsibilities were announced yesterday by the House of Seagram, Inc. The company is the sales subsidiary of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., wholly owned American subsidiary of Distillers-Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision upholding the validity of a Washington state law requiring state employes to declare under oath whether they are members of the Communist party or any other subversive organization.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the nation's largest chemical producer, had the third highest net income in its history, last year, 10 per cent above the 1960 level. Sales set a record.
LONDON, Jan. 22--Paul Scofield will return to the Royal Shakespeare Theatre after a fourteen-year absence to play the title role in "King Lear" this season, it was announced today.

ONE of the most ambitious and flowingly melodic scores of the season graces "The Banker's Daughter." In addition, the new musical, which opened last night at Jan Hus House, has a company with the voices and skills to sing it.

A CASUAL lover of baroque music who might have wandered into the Sonata da Camera concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall most certainly would have been thunderstruck.
Directors of American Airlines and of Eastern Air Lines have been called to special meetings this morning.

BENNY FRIEDMAN is as ardent a football man today as he was thirtyfive years ago when he was an all America quarterback at Michigan. The game has changed considerably since then, but Benny has kept pace. Changes to the contrary, though, he still is convinced that fundamental principles he learned from Fielding Yost, his coach at Ann Arbor, are as valid today as they were then.

PARIS, Jan. 22--Today this city was sun-splashed, its sky an azure blue rather than winter's usual slate gray hue. This mantle was altogether appropriate, for today the couturiers of Paris began their week-long parade of new fashions for spring and summer.
Prices barely moved in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange and ended barely changed in both The New York Times average and Standard Poor's index.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP)-- Moderately heavy selling drove the grain futures market into general retreat today on the Board of Trade. Numerous contracts of wheat, corn and oats lost a cent or more a bushel.

Prices of United States Government securities and other prime-rated debt obligations were firm and stable yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 22-- An increase in the state's allowances to counties for the care of mentally ill persons was requested unanimously today by the Westchester Board of Supervisors.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Jan. 22--Julius K. Nyerere, Prime Minister of newly independent Tanganyika, resigned today and handed the office to his own nominee, Rashidi Kawawa, former Minister Without Portfolio.
DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP)-- The General Motors Corporation is supporting its optimistic 1962 sales forecasts with its highest automobile production rates in two years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy rejected tonight an informal invitation to visit the Soviet Union.

YONKERS, Jan. 22--A gentle white-haired craftsman is preserving in wood some of the heritage of his native Armenia.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 22--A group of Central American nations proposed to the United States today a regional Caribbean defense pact.

A founder and executive of the Revlon, Inc., cosmetics company has given $1,000,000 to the Lenox Hill Hospital. The hospital said yesterday that the gift, from Charles R. Lachman, would be used in the construction of a new community health center.
Hartford Beaumont, a retired lawyer who spent his early career in the Philippine Islands, died Friday at his home, 24 West Seventy-sixth Street, while writing his memoirs. He was 90 years old.

Thomas F. Patton, president and chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corporation, was elected yesterday to the new post of chairman and chief executive officer of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

TABLES that look like flowers are the newest idea of Henry Robert Kann. The contemporary furniture designer, whose office is at 165 East Eighty-third Street, sees customers by appointment only. His work is made to order.
A widower with fourteen children was arrested yesterday after he allegedly had tried to hold-up a midtown bank. The attempted robbery was one of three unsuccessful hold-ups at banks in the city.

NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 22 (AP)--Boston College signed Jim Miller tonight as its head football coach.

The fiftieth annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases reached a new high of $573,342.98 in contributions yesterday. Last year's appeal closed at the end of February with $572,816,the previous record.

News that the Japanese textile industry had resumed its role of aggressive buyer at the Australian raw-wool auctions caused prices of wool futures to soar here yesterday. Wool led in activity in local commodity trading.

BELIZE, British Honduras, Jan. 22--Twenty armed Guatemalan soldiers were reported today by the Punta Gorda police to have staged a demonstration yesterday in Pueblo Viejo, a village in the Toledo district of British Honduras.

Detroit, Mich., announced plans yesterday to borrow $25,345,000 in the public bond market on March 27. The city will offer two bond issues for sale. One will consist of $15,345,000 of obligations to finance various public improvements. The other offering will consist of $10,000,000 of city school district obligations.

PARIS, Jan. 22--On the opening day of the Paris summer collections, a new soft wave was in the air. Pierre Cardin fell under its spell, Jean Desses had royal visitors, and Patou and Yorn, a new designer, made their bid for the private customers.

SINCE so many new art movements start in France, it is appropriate that William Saroyan is living there now. He has a cold flat in a high place near the Opera. In dusty splendor he is conducting a personal renaissance. One amazing product of his post-Dantean voice of the middleaged generation is before us today. It is called "Here Comes There Goes You Know Who."

WASHINGTON, Jan, 22 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, today that a Federal prisoner might not challenge his sentence on the ground that he had not been asked before sentencing if he had anything to say.

LONDON, Jan. 22--Conservatives criticized Prime Minister Macmillan, the Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, and the Government tonight on the eve of the reassembly of Parliament for twelve active and contentious weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)--A leading Protestant magazine said today that President Kennedy, during his first year in office, "has compiled a better record on the issue of separation of church and state than any other President we have had in the past thirty years."

BOSTON, Jan. 22--The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority signed a contract today for the sale of $180,000,000 of bonds to construct an extension into downtown Boston.
TRENTON, Jan. 22--New York and New Jersey have reached agreement on legislation to take over the Hudson Tubes and to build a World Trade Center.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 22--Edward North Jenks, director of administration operations of The New York Times International Edition in Paris in 1960 and 1961, died today in New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived at 900 Palmer Road, Bronxville, N.Y.

Studies that are elucidating the mysterious but vital role of vitamin B-12 in human nutrition were discussed here yesterday at a regional meeting of the American Chemical Society at the New Yorker Hotel.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 --A center to promote international understanding and amity through study, research and exchanges of ideas was inaugurated here today.
John. F. English, Nassau County Democratic chairman, ruled himself out as a possible candidate for Democratic state chairman in a talk with national party leaders in Washington on Saturday.
The men who run the National Collegiate and National Invitation basketball tournaments have agreed to live in peace. They will wait until Feb. 19 before issuing tournament bids.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--A strong warning against speech-making by military men that might involve them in politics came today from former Secretary of Defense

"Carnival in Rio" is the theme chosen for the 1962 Beaux Arts Ball, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 16. Proceeds will support the work of the National Urban League.
The first clash last week in the long-threatened "little war" between the Republic of Indonesia and the Dutch emphasizes the importance of sea power in the control of New Guinea.

A letter on this page by George M. Shapiro, a distinguished Republican lawyer, defends New York's recent realignment of Congressional districts by virtually ignoring the gerrymandering and pointing to the one respect in which proper standards did rule--relative equality of population.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22--Although the number of daily newspapers in the nation's major cities has declined, the resulting single ownership in an area has meant an "impulse to greater fairness in news presentation and commentary."
Oren Root, State Superin tendent of Banks, predicted yesterday that no legislation of broad significance would be recommended to or enacted by the present session of the Legislature.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 --Animal trainers in Hollywood usually guard their trade secrets as jealously as magicians. But one of them revealed some of the tricks today, along with stories to illustrate.
PARIS, Jan. 22--A bomb exploded at the French Foreign Ministry today, killing one man and injuring thirteen. The terrorist Secret Army Organization was blamed.

Hearings that start today before a Senate Armed Services subcommittee will deal with the censorship of military speeches; the case of former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker; troop information and education allegations of "Communist or Left-Wing influence" in government; and the cold-war seminars on communism sponsored by the military.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)--Two labor leaders charged today that President Kennedy was not doing enough to help the 4,000,000 unemployed.
The Board of Higher Education approved a $500,000 plan last night to purchase air rights over tracks of the Long Island Rail Road for new buildings for Brooklyn College.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- Following are excerpts from President Kennedy's Economic Report, as transmitted to Congress today:

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 (Canadian Press)--The Government will introduce legislation to prevent importation of magazines containing advertising directed primarily at the Canadian market, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker announced today in Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- President Kennedy reported confidently today that the economy was responding well to his Administration's efforts to foster its growth. He proposed new measures to prevent too fast or too slow a pace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) --The president of the New York Stock Exchange said tonight that "tough self-regulation" was the most effective means of policing securities markets.
Stockholders of Lanolin Plus, Inc., and Hazel Bishop, Inc., approved a merger of the two cosmetics companies under the name of Hazel Bishop at meetings yesterday.

Grace Line, Inc., was chosen yesterday by the Federal Maritime Administration to be operator of what is expected to be the nation's fastest commercial vessel: the hydrofoil ship Denison, designed to travel the equivalent of sixty miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--The Supreme Court rejected today a Securities and Exchange Commission effort to extend to investment banking concerns the absolute statutory

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)--Representative James J. Delaney, who cast a key vote against President Kennedy's education program last year, offered a $1,700,000,000 bill today for aid to students in public and parochial schools.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- Following is the text of the section of a report to the President by the Council of Economic Advisers entitled "Guideposts for Noninflationary Wage and Price Behavior":

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 22--Sujarwo Tjondronegoro, President Sukarno's special envoy, met today with U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, for the first time on the dispute over Netherlands New Guinea.
PARIS, Jan. 23--The O. A. S terrorist campaign against France's Government aims to frighten General de Gaulle into accepting its solution to this country's greatest problem, Algerian peace.
The directors of American Airlines and Eastern Air Lines approved yesterday the merger of their systems into the world's biggest airline.
GENEVA, Jan. 23--The United States told the Chinese Communists today not to hope that they could provoke for their own ends a Soviet-American war over Laos.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that its estimated net income for 1961 was $338,500,000, or $3.21 a share on the 105,404,018 shares outstanding at the year-end. This represented an increase of 2.5 per cent from the $330,311,000, or $3.13 a share, cleared for 1960.

Three men described by Federal authorities as major figures in an international narcotics ring were seized yesterday in Spain. The ring was said to have smuggled more than $150,000,000 worth of heroin into the United States in the last ten years.
LONDON, Jan. 23--The decline in stock market prices continued here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- The House tentatively approved today the Administration-sponsored bill to increase first-class letter mail from 4 cents an ounce to 5 cents and airmail from 7 to 8 cents.

St, John's University fought off a determined second-half rally by Canisius last night and won, 81--68, for its fifth consecutive basketball victory. The triumph was the eleventh in fourteen starts for the Redmen.

MELBOURNE, Australia Jan. 23 (AP) The Soviet Union, which has boasted it will win the Davis Cup by 1964, was included in the first round of this year's European Zone competition in the draw announced today by the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--The Assembly gave final approval today to a bill increasing the membership of the State Commission Against Discrimination from five to seven members, but not before an angry political squall blew up over the issue.
Spirits were low in Wall Street yesterday and prices moved downward most of the day, reacting to the bashfulness of buyers rather than the urgency of sellers.

A leading Russian film company and an independent Hollywood producer are discussing plans for co-production of a feature motion picture, combining actors, technicians and financing from the United States and the Soviet Union.

The Regents Examinations and the traditional methods of preparing students to pass them deter educational changes in New York State's public schools, the State Commissioner of Education was told yesterday.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said yesterday that 8 per cent fewer longshoremen were hired last year in the Port of New York than in 1960.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23--William D. Phelps, retired designer and manufacturer of hand-made leather belts and handbags, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home. He was 71 years old.
The National Foreign Trade Council, the leading organization in the foreign business field, forecast yesterday that United States commercial exports would set a record this year of $20,500,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- Both the Eisenhower and Truman Administrations followed a policy of reviewing, clearing and, at times, curbing the foreign policy speeches of military and other officials.
The city must take immediate action to end the perpetual crisis in child welfare, James R. Dumpson, the city's Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, Commissioner of Hospitals, proposed widespread improvements in the operation, staffing, security and supply for the city's hospitals yesterday.

As conductor of Clarion Concerts, Newell Jenkins is constantly dredging up novelties to freshen the repertory of this admirable series. Last night in Town Hall, in the second concert of Clarion's fifth season, this was again the case.
It would be nice to leave the National Collegiate Athletic Association-Amateur Athletic Union squabble, but how can it be done when so many questions remain unanswered?
A civil antitrust suit against three trade associations and a union local in the blouse industry was filed in Federal Court yesterday by the Department of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--A massive food and agriculture program for the Nineteen Sixties has been drafted by the Administration. It is aimed at reshaping the farm economy in the next decade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) --The Washington Redskins signed Penn State's quarterback Galen Hall, today, opening the door for trades in their drive to escape the National Football League cellar.

AN exhibition of sculpture, paintings, musical instruments, sputniks and models of comic intent, made in the Soviet Union by children 3 to 18 years old, may be seen at the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway. Admission is free. The exhibit will continue through Feb. 11.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 23 --New advances toward cracking the chemical code of inheritance were described by leading scientists in the field at a special meeting here today.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 23--The United States fought for votes today on a new formula for the Cuban problem that would suspend Premier Fidel Castro's regime from membership in the Organization of American States.
Queens Republicans nominated Thomas F. Galvin of Flushing last night to run for Congress in a special election in the Sixth District Feb. 20.

At least seven major New York commercial banks have been asked for information by the antitrust division of the Department of Justice in connection with changes in the prime rate, it was learned yesterday.
CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 23-- The role played by American shipping lines in opening foreign markets for United States products was praised here today by Donald W. Alexander, Federal Maritime Administrator.

Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday. They declared a dividend of 75 cents a share for payment on March 10 to holders of record of Feb. 9.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23-- An 18-year-old secondary-school student was shot and killed today during clashes between anti-Government demonstrators and security forces.
At the year's start many commercial banks raised the interest rates paid on savings. Now the question arises as to the effect on their rivals, the savings and loan associations.

BERLIN, Jan. 23--The British commandant in Berlin has received Allied approval for a proposal to his Soviet counterpart that relations between the occupying powers be ... normalized. The proposal would restore freedom of movement in all parts of Berlin for the four commandants and their political advisers.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 23--Fourteen persons were reported to have been killed today as new disorders raged through Caracas.
The city was accused yesterday of failing to prepare adequately two of its cases against a Yorkville landlord.
Tiros III, the weather satellite put into orbit to hunt hurricanes, spotted fifty tropical storms of all types last summer.

THE discriminating person who justifiably refuses to have any part of warmed-over coffee may, however, put the left-over liquid to use. Coffee that is good and strong makes an excellent flavoring for many a dessert and is by no means limited to use in coffee ice cream.

THE publishing concern of Grosset Dunlap, which goes back more than a century and established itself on the firm foundation of the Bobbsey Twins, Tom Swift and Pollyanna, has brought out a bridge book by Richard L. Frey called "How to Win at Contract Bridge."

Fred H. Hill, realty investor, has contracted to buy the fivestory store, office and apartment building at 560 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street. Bernath Co., women's wear, is the seller. It will vacate the space it uses in the building upon passing of title to Mr. Hill.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI) --John Roseboro, who overcame the Coliseum handicap for lefthanded hitters last season, received his reward today when the Los Angeles Dodgers raised his salary for 1962.

To make something out of nothing is an achieve ment. Financial transactions involving the Commonwealth of Australia and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) in borrowings totaling $230,000,000 were announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--The most closely guarded political secret in the Capitol tonight was whether Governor Rockefeller would testify before the Assembly Committee on Ethics and Guidance next week.
THE last show made for television by Ernie Kovacs ran on Channel 7 last night. It was an especially good one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--A detailed account of soaring profits of television networks was presented today by a spokesman for the Federal Communications Commission.

A NOVELIST who starts with ordinary people in ordinary circumstances has a built-in problem: how to make them appear extraordinary. They may be without distinction within the covers of the book, but they must fascinate the reader on the outside. It is not easy. Hurstwood in "Sister Carrie" is, I suppose, a prime example of a ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- Representatives of American maritime unions today presented a four-point program to Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg for greater participation by American flag ships in the transportation of Government-financed cargoes.

Allan Connell of Fort Worth, Tex., the winner of the Sports Car Club of America national championship race at the Daytona International Speedway in 1959, will be seen in action there again this Saturday and Sunday.
Trading was generally featureless on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday, ending with prices up for only three commodities and down or mixed for the others.
Two Senators, a State Department official and two prominent observers will discuss the United States' role in the future of the United Nations on Columbia Broadcasting System television Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Federal Power Commission proposed today a nation-wide survey of demand and facilities as a first step toward providing cheaper electricity to consumers.
Astronomers appear to be abandoning the idea that cataclysmic collisions between galaxies account for the extremely strong radio signals from points in distant space.
GONE are the days when furniture shoppers found only left-overs of last year's inventory in January sales. Today, factory-fresh chairs, chests and tables also appear among the markdowns.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday struck down a lower court order that had enjoined the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc., from ending business relations with a former customer.
Mayor Wagner asked yesterday that the state agree to a "bedrock minimum" sum to pay for the first year of city administration of rent control.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)--The passports of an undisclosed number of top members of the Communist party of the United States have been revoked by the State Department. officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)--The Republican National Committee said today it had pledges indicating seat sales of $1,500,000 for its nation-wide fund-raising program Feb. 1.
The Georgia Rural Roads Authority borrowed $15,600,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 3.37979 per cent.

Now 62, became president of American Airlines for the first time in 1934, when line was formed to succeed American Airways. Resigned in 1942 for key World War II role in building Air Transport Command.

PARIS, Jan. 23--France has offered a new draft of a treaty to link the six members of the European Economic Community politically. The plan, which avoids any semblance of supranationality, was rejected by France's partners.

The First Boston Corporation and associates offered to the public yesterday $25,000,000 of 4 5/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Shamrock Oil and Gas Corporation due in 1987 and priced at 99 to yield 4,693 per cent. A spokesman for the manager said that the bonds had an excellent reception and that the deal was virtually completed.
The imminence of large borrowings by United States Government agencies and other public bodies threw a cloud of distraction around the highgrade bond market yesterday.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad Company registered a net loss of $26,488,759 for 1961 on gross revenues of $211,024,845, the Eastern carrier reported yesterday. For 1960, the railroad had a deficit of $19,995,614 in 1960 on revenues of $220,419,579.

LONDON, Jan. 23--The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Selwyn Lloyd, announced in the House of Commons today new and improved arrangements for providing financial credit for British exporters. These arrangements will, in turn, enable the exporters to offer better credit terms to their customers.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, the nation's seventh largest steel producer, reported yesterday that net earnings from operations for 1961 were $22,654,741, equal to $6.49 a share. This compared with earnings of $25,719,166, or $7.38 a share, for 1960.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 23--The Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union turned down today a proposal for merger with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The preliminary report for 1961 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., showed yesterday new highs in sales of gas, electricity and steam, total operating revenues and net income.
PARIS, Jan. 23--The dazzling world of high fash ion, with its spectacular swirl of feminine raiment and endless parade of equally spectacular models, might seem to some an Olympian heaven for a man.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower suggested today that leading military men assume a major role in warning the public of the dangers from international communism.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 23 --The local chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality said today it would attempt to shut Southern University if the Negro state institution did not readmit all students.
Eastern Air Lines first got off the ground on May 1, 1928, when five airmen took off at night in a tiny, 200-horsepower Mailwing plane to fly 300 pounds of mail between New York and Atlanta.

The fur industry heard a prediction last night that sales gains recorded last year were likely to continue during 1962.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (Reuters) --Sir Roderick Jones, former chairman and managing director of Reuters, died today at his home in London of a kidney ailment. He was 84 years old.
The New York knickerbockers did a turnabout last night in losing to the Chicago Packers at Madison Square Garden.

Governor Rockefeller, weary of a political issue on which the Republicans--who have to deal with it biennially in the Legislature--can never win, wants to turn rent control over to New York City. In fact, he would even have the state pay the costs of administration, an act of excessive generosity.
A new attempt is being made in Congress to re-create a postal iron curtain around the United States. It should be defeated.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23-- The Pennsylvania Railroad asked the Federal District Court here today to block a strike threatened by the Transport workers Union for 12:01 A.M. Sunday, Feb. 4.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23--Australia has altered her attitude and now accepts the probability that Indonesia will soon get control of Netherlands New Guinea in one way or another, it was reliably reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- President Kennedy has suggested to the Governments of India and Pakistan that they ask Eugene R. Black to serve as mediator in the Kashmir dispute.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP)--L.P. Guy's Pointer, the 9-to-10 favorite, shook off Weatherton on the stretch turn and drew out to a four-length victory in today's Hobe Sound Purse at Hialeah. Weatherton, a 15-1 shot, was second, with Misty Day third.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (UPI)-- Henry Cooper, the British and Empire heavyweight champion, scored a technical knockout tonight over Tony Hughes of Cleveland. Hughes retired after the fifth round because of cuts about his eyes.

William Zeckendorf has been elected chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., making way for his son, William Jr., to assume the post of president. The elder Zeckendorf remains chief executive officer of the realty concern.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23--U Thant, Acting Secretary General, has informed nations with combat troops in the Congo that additional forces would be "highly welcome."
LONDON, Jan. 23--For the sixth year in a row Japan was the world's leading shipbuilding nation last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)--Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today that he believed a broader foreign trade program was necessary. But he said Congress would want a lot of assurances before it was ready to adopt President Kennedy's plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- A Senate inquiry that began today has the potential of arousing the sensationalism, emotionalism and personal vituperation that marked the investigations in 1953-54 in which the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was the central figure.
The State Rent Commission opened hearings yesterday to determine whether the tenants of the Devonshire, at the corner of West 112th Street and Broadway, could be evicted.

PARIS, Jan. 23--Mme. Natalia Ivanova Sedova Trotsky, widow of the Russian Communist revolutionary leader, died in a physician's house in suburban Corbeil today after a long illness. She was 79 years old.
El Jefe de los Bomberos de Nueva York, Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson, attended a Spanish class yesterday, but had to sneak out less than halfway through to go to a fire.

PARIS, Jan. 23--The belt is back. Pierre Cardin made sure of that yesterday, and Nina Ricci and Pierre Balmain reiterated it today. Is this now an international agreement? Norman Norell, one of America's most influential designers, established the wide belt worn with the twirling skirt just a month ago at his spring showing in New York.

Mayor Wagner asked the City Council yesterday to repeal the so-called Lyons Residence Law which requires three years of residence in the city for appointment to city jobs. The law also requires a large number of city employes to live in the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, said today he would "slow up" most of the bills for Federal aid to education in his committee until a Congressional study determined how much waste there was in existing programs.

WHEN an orchestra engages an unusual instru mentalist as a guest artist, the audience generally has the added advantage of hearing unusual concertos. And so it was last night when Joseph Eger, French horn-player, was the soloist with the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall.
The Metropolitan Opera had a new Bruennhilde in last night's "Die Walkuere:" a Finnish soprano with the singularly appropriate name of Anita Valkki.

ROGER MARIS peeked at his hole cards and stared thoughtfully at the ceiling of the club car. This was on the train to Rochester, where the other night the Yankee slugger received the Hickok Award, the $10,000 diamond-studded belt, as the outstanding professional athlete of the year. The game was a friendly time-killer known as seven-card stud, which demonstrates how ridiculously friendly it was.

Roy Hamey, the forthright front-office boss of the Yankees, conceded yesterday that within the past twenty-four hours he had met with Cletis Boyer, Bill Skowron and Elston Howard, He said he had discussed contracts with all, but wound up signing none.

The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that it had dismissed appeals by two Queens College faculty members who had charged that discrimination against Catholics at the college had blocked their promotions to full professorships.
NEW VERNON, N. J., Jan. 23--Army engineers today announced plans for a flood-control reservoir in the Great Swamp in Morris County, on the site of the proposed jet airport.
ATLANTA, Jan. 23 (UPI)-- The long-standing football rivalry between Georgia Tech and Alabama, marred last fall by a controversial injury, will end after their 1964 game.
Arthur Penn, who has an impressive list of credits as a Broadway director, is planning to produce and direct an untitled musical comedy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- The House Ways and Means Committee backed farther away today from President Kennedy's proposal to abolish income tax deductions for business entertainment.
ALGIERS, Jan. 23--The Right-wing extremist Secret Army Organization urged Europeans in Algiers, Oran and Bone today to demonstrate tomorrow against the regime of President de Gaulle.
LONDON, Jan. 23--The Prince of Wales will receive his secondary education at Gordonstoun, an austere boarding school in Scotland where his father was a student.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)-- Bob Feller and Jackie Robinson were elected today to the Baseball Hall of Fame.

The conservative coalition in Congress is getting a fast start this year on its Alliance for Reaction. It is out to scuttle President Kennedy's proposal for a new Federal Department of Urban Affairs and Housing, and the chances are substantial that it will succeed.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--The State Education Commissioner declared today that the amount of additional aid recommended by a special legislative committee was "far below what is needed to make a sufficiently significant improvement in the quality of our school system."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--There is a marked change here in the atmosphere of the Republican party. With former President Eisenhower in retirement, and former Vice President Richard M. Nixon preoccupied with a political comeback in California, attention is now focused increasingly on the conservative wing of the party in general and on Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona in particular.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) --President Kennedy today chose Harold C. Woodward, Chicago lawyer, to fill a Republican vacancy on the Federal Power Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23--Forty African and Asian states proposed today that the General Assembly call on Portugal to "desist forthwith from repressive measures against the people of Angola" and release all political prisoners immediately.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 23--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd announced today that one of South Africa's largest non-white areas would be granted internal selfgovernment early next year.

PARIS, Jan. 23--The murder by bombing of a minor employe of the French Foreign Ministry and the kidnapping of a Gaullist Deputy yesterday were moves in a deadly game of "intoxication" of public opinion being played in France.

CHICAGO, Jan, 23--Invention of electronic controls to allow unrestricted use of preprinted pages was described today as "one of the most important technological advances for the newspaper industry of this century."
ALBANY, Jan. 23--A bill mandating the direct election of party district leaders in New York City was approved unanimously in the Assembly today. It now goes to a committee in the Senate.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 23 --An attempt to assassinate King Mahendra was made yesterday at Janakpur in southeastern Nepal, where the King is on a tour.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 --Lieut, Col. John H. Glenn Jr. tried out his Mercury space capsule today, following replacement of apparently defective parts in the oxygen system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- The Senate passed and sent to President Kennedy today a bill to soften the tax consequences of the antitrust decision against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--Governor Rockefeller has submitted the name of Bernard Newman, New York county Repubican leader, to New York City bar associations as a prospective appointee to the Supreme Court.

PARIS, Jan. 23--Frenchmen in Algeria and even metropolitan France have been throwing bombs as never before in the last few weeks. There has been vague talk of civil war. Although the action had no connection with Algeria, the country even changed finance ministers last week.

FEZ, Morocco, Jan. 23--The foundations for a union of North African states were laid tonight by agreement between Morocco and the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government.
Noonday crowds near Grand Central Terminal will have their first chance at uninhibited street crossing tomorrow when the "Barnes dance" has its premiere here.
Now that the dust of battle has settled in New Jersey with the final setting of next Wednesday as a oneday, either-sex deer season, hunters are able to make plans.

In April, 1926, a young St. Louis aviator, Charles A. Lindbergh, stowed a bag of mail in his DH-4, waved to bystanders at Lambert Field and took off for Chicago. This was, in effect, the "birthday" of American Airlines.
Newspaper reading may be a habit to millions of people, but to about 800 men and women it is a business.

Walter Hagen, who won the Professional Golfers Association championship five times, was accorded top honors at the dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association last night. Hagen, a star of the Twenties, received the Gold Tee award for his contribution to the game. There were 900 persons at the dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- House Speaker John W. McCormack appealed today for Republican help in the Rules Committee to save the President's bill for creating a Cabinet department for urban affairs.
LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP)--The dispute over who is the world middleweight boxing champion probably will be settled by July, with the winner of a Terry Downes-Paul Pender fight taking on Gene Fullmer.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 24--Seven LatinAmerican countries, including the largest ones, issued a memorandum today denouncing "the incompatibility between the present regime in Cuba and the inter-American system." But they opposed sanctions.

A Government research scientist proposed yesterday the development of a "subsonic-supersonic" airliner that could serve both on short routes flying at a speed near that of sound and on long routes flying two or three times as fast.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24--Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky, Soviet Defense Minister, declared in an interview published today that "shelters against atomic and hydrogen bombs are nothing but coffins and tombs prepared in advance."

A WOMAN violinist, a living composer and a com poser born a hundred years ago had heartening successes last night at Carnegie Hall when the Boston Symphony opened its third New York visit of the season.
