LONDON, Jan. 24--Stock market prices drifted downward again today, but selling was light and net losses generally small.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The House completed passage today of a bill that would increase first-class letter mail to 5 cents an ounce and airmail to 8 cents. But a new battle was expected in the Senate.
A radically new way of energizing a crystal to produce intense, coherent light was described here yesterday to members of the American Physical Society.

AS reported last week, the next world-championship match in chess will be exhibited Before spectators by the device of having live chessmen move from square to square, reflecting the moves of the players.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 24 (UPI) --Only one of the two American teams will compete in the international four-man bobsled championship this week-end, Stan Benham, the United States coach, said today.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (UPI) --ElRoy Face of the Pittsburgh Pirates signed his 1962 contract today.
The Police Department "motorized" the Astoria precinct in Queens yesterday in an experiment to improve protection in an extensive, outlying area.
The Lynchburg, Va., branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has protested against the exclusion of Negro school children there from the National Spelling Bee.
Stocks moved down on relatively light volume yesterday morning, found the day's low early in the afternoon and then moved vigorously upward, ending with a slight gain.

The rousing, knock-'em-fora-loop performance of "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera last night was the responsibility, largely, of the two persons new to the cast, mattiwilda Dobbs and Anselmo Colzani, who were making season's first appearances, and of the conductor, Fausto Cleva.
ALGIERS, Jan. 24--The European population of Algeria's big cities demonstrated today its support for the Secret Army Organization.
ALBANY, Jan. 24--Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino charged today that his political enemies were carrying on "a concerted drive" to discredit him and destroy his reputation as a legislator.

Sales of the St. Regis Paper Company reached a new high in 1961 but earnings fell below the 1960 level, the company reported yesterday. It is the country's third largest producer of paper and paper products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- Following is the text of a Statement made today by Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, before the Special Senate Preparedness Subcommittee:

In its continuing campaign to reduce accidents on the waterfront the New York Shipping Association in cooperation with New York University, will conduct the tenth annual course of instruction in waterfront safety.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24--Britain's chief United Nations delegate said emphatically today that his Government continued to support the United Nations.
ALBANY, Jan, 24--Four bills designed to improve the efficiency of public welfare administration were filed in the Legislature today under Republican sponsorship.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 24--An effort to put five satellites into orbit with one rocket was thwarted today by trouble in the vehicle's upper stage. It was the first time that as many as five satellites had been sent up with one rocket.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Justice Department is investigating reports that gangsters have been planting illicit profits in the stock market, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--President Kennedy brushed aside today former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's criticism of the requirement that military leaders submit their speeches to civilian authorities for policy and security clearance.

A new method of transmitting news copy at high speed over special telephone circuits will be used by The New York Times to send copy to Los Angeles for its new Western Edition. Publication is to begin later this year.

BERLIN, Jan. 24--Twentyeight East Germans, including a 17-year-old paralyzed woman and an 8-year-old girl, fled to West Berlin early today. The group was the largest to escape from East Berlin since the Communist regime closed the border last August.
MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press)--G. Arnold Hart, president of the Bank of Montreal, said today the Bank of Montreal had bought the Newfoundland Savings Bank. The price was not disclosed.

Wesley Associates, Inc., which serves such clients as Shulton, Inc., and Conde Nast Publications, Inc., is understood to have acquired Mann-Ellis, Inc., an agency specializing in European companies. Combined billings of the two agencies would be about $10,000,000 a year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24-- Gov. Edmund G. Brown formally become a Democratic candidate for a second term tonight with an attack on former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
A lawyer and seven other men were indicted here yesterday in the theft of $800,000 in stocks from an 85-year-old widow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A network president testified today that he did not cancel a controversial episode in a television show because he feared his action might discourage creative talent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) --Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that any attempt to put an anti-discrimination clause into a bill to provide training for more doctors and dentists would kill the bill.

As redrawn by the State Legislature, with the cheerful assistance of the Republican county organization, the new Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx resembles a slightly tattered gingham dog. Except for a scrawny neck, its head is separated from its body by a narrow sliver of the adjoining Twenty-third District. Its tail wags feebly in Long Island Sound and one ear juts into neighboring Westchester County.

CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 21--The Right Rev. Nelson M. Burroughs, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Ohio, and Mrs. Burroughs have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Gorham Burroughs, to Joseph Day Morris. He is the son of Mrs. John S.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--So far the Senate subcommittee hearings on restraints which have or should be applied to public statements and speeches by military professionals have produced these broad agreements by the distinguished witnesses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) --A.D. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers District 50, died today at his home here. He was 72 years.
ALLENDALE, N.J., Thursday, Jan. 25--Two desperate convicts, one of whom had threatened to kill a judge and two lawyers, escaped from two guards in Paterson yesterday morning.
Marguerite E. Jones, former chairman of the Speech and Dramatics Department of Hunter College, died Monday in her home at 1225 Park Avenue. She was 73 years old.

Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, who administers the Government-owned majority stock of General Aniline and Film Corporation, met here yesterday for the first time with directors and executives of the company. He informed them there would be no Government interference with management.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Kennedy vigorously defended two State Department employer today against a newspaper woman's statement that they were security risks.
New York City plans to sell $89,400,000 of serial bonds at public bidding on Feb. 15, it was disclosed yesterday.
The New York Telephone Company had a record year in most categories of its operations in 1961, according to the preliminary annual report issued yesterday.
An elaborate version of the peddler's cart took to the road yesterday.

A few days ago in all major Soviet newspapers there appeared articles marking the fiftieth anniversary of the Prague Congress of the Bolshevik party. In these articles, one point was stressed above all: Lenin showed in 1912 that the Bolshevik party strengthens rather than weakens itself by purging opposition elements. In world Communism's present time of troubles, no theme could have a clearer contemporary import.

FOR a long, long time, authors of cookbooks have been intrigued with the Mediterranean appetite for dishes made with salt cod, a form of dried fish that is widely available in Manhattan. One reason for their interest may be the wonderment that any food so humble can be turned into a dish as exalted as the famed brandade de morue-an excellent, garlicspiced specialty of southern France.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- The Food and Drug Administration has barred the use of "whole fish flour" in the United States.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 24-- The proposed union of Morocco and the Algerian Provisional Government raised hopes, doubts and suspicions today in North African political quarters.
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation had record sales in 1961, but profits were below those of 1960, John E. Bierwirth, chairman, reported yesterday.

THE homemaker who wants to give her bedroom a dainty snow-white look might head for Bonwit's new At-Home Shop where an extensive collection of white embroidered fabrics drape beds, windows and tables. The shop opens today on the second floor. Everything on view was made by Ottavia, Craig and Lovely Lady.

Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a 38year-old lawyer, was nominated on the tenth ballot last night as the Democratic candidate for Congress in the special election to be held Feb. 20 in the Queens Sixth District.

A full-length biography of Cardinal Spellman has been written by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, educator, pastor, lecturer, author and president of Fordham University for thirteen years. Father Gannon had access to the Cardinal's personal files and diaries, and his book...

The American Spaniel Club this month managed to give away $500 that had been lying around without a claimant for four years. The recipient was Adelaide L. Arntsen of Spring House, Pa. She received the money at the club's national specialty in the Hotel Roosevelt. In 1958, the club put up...
One of our local merThose chants spoke out lately Russian about what the man in

The marriage of Miss Caralisa Hallonquist Pollard, daughter of Mrs. Barry Pollard of Austin, Tex., and New York and James Joseph Pollard of Lexington, Va., to Thomas Hastings Hughes took place in Palo Alto, Calif., on Jan. 7. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Hastings Hughes of Garden City, L.I.
Chester J. LaRoche of New York was re-elected president of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of directors at the Yale Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Kennedy has invited Premier Khrushchev's son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mme. Aleksei I. Adzhubei, to have lunch with him at the White House next Tuesday.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 24 --Thomas B. Gilchrist, former special guardian of Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, now Mrs. Sidney Lumet, died today in his home on Lawrence Park West here. He was 76 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, predicted today that television would develop its own "classics" in the next ten years.
Directors of the American Bank Note Company authorized yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting on April 24.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- Among Washington's current daytime serials the confrontation of the Federal Communications Commission and the television networks is not likely to finish among the top ten. The Government's inquiry into the housekeeping habits of the broadcasting chains stands in no danger of becoming a national spectator sport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 17:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)--The Army assigned its youngest general today to responsibility for directing the ground force's expanding world-wide efforts in the field of guerrilla warfare.
The New York Rangers dropped their eighth straight National Hockey League game last night and fell to fifth place as they bowed to the Detroit Red Wings, 3--0, at Madison Square Garden.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Shelley McMillon, a substitute, and Larry Foust sparked the St. Louis Hawks to a 135-123 victory over the Boston Celtics in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight.

EARLIER this year there were doubts that Max Pollikoff's Music in Our Time series could get under way. To put it briefly, in three words, money was lacking. But a groundswell began, people chipped in, and last night the first concert of this season's five was given at the old stamping grounds--the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
PARIS, Jan. 24--Andre Lhote, French cubist painter, died here today of a brain hemorrhage. He was 76 years old.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 24-- Dr. Lothar Bolz, East Germany's Foreign Minister, made the first public Communist assessment today of the SovietUnited States talks on Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21-- Republicans and Southern Democrats teamed up today in the House Rules Committes to kill President Kennedy's bill for creating a Department for Urban Affairs.

Two five-story commercial buildings at 167-69 Canal Street, northwest corner of Elizabeth Street, have been sold by the 167-69 Canal Street Corporation, Howard Hollinger, president. The parcels on a plot 42 by 75 feet, were bought by the Canbow Realty Corporation. The Irving R. Raber Company was the broker. The property is assessed at $100,000. E. 30th St. House Taken Investor Buys Dwelling 2 Sales in 'Village' Sale on E. 117th St.
Several members of the executive committee for the Diamond Ball to be held next Wednesday at the Plaza will give cocktail parties that evening preceding the fete.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 24 (AP)--Two Tennessee cities, Chattanooga and Nashville, were accepted for 1962 membership only by the Class A South Atlantic Baseball League today. Their admittance signalled the death of the Class AA Southern Asosciation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- Powerful Congressional opposition and a strike threat by the Transport Workers Union today confronted the proposed merger of American Airlines and Eastern Air Lines.
New Yorkers were advised yesterday by Arthur J. Benline, Air Pollution Commissioner, to take a tip from Los Angeles and set up a private air-pollution foundation.

NO one in France, least of all Hubert Beuve-Mery, could have been surprised yesterday when a plastic bomb exploded outside his apartment at 107 Boulevard Raspail, on the Left Bank of the Seine in Paris. It was the second time that the terrorists who oppose a peace set

The Alan Hood Steel Company had a $279,000 net loss on sales and operating revenues totaling $55,677,000 in 1961, the Conshohocken, Pa., concern stated in a preliminary report. In 1960, sales of $62,805,000 yielded net income of $1,437,000, equal after preferred dividends to $1.72 a common share.
CARE and MEDICO, two voluntary relief agencies that furnish food and medicine to foreign lands, announced yesterday that they were merging.
The Military Order of the Loyal Legion will mark Lincoin's Birthday with a dinner dance Feb. 12 at the Plaza.

Efforts to bring "The Shop Around the Corner" to the stage have not been abandoned. Lawrence Kasha and Philip C. McKenna are now planning to present a musical version of the Miklos Laszlo comedy that formed the sinews of two Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films.

STEPHEN WATTS was in the Cafe de Paris in London when he was wounded by shots fired in anger. The shooters were German World War II airmen. After some of the debris had been cleared away, Mr. Watts and the girls and the men in his party made plans for a week-end in Hampshire.

The largest middle-income rental project in the state's limited-protit housing program will be built in the East New York section of Brooklyn. It will be a $33,114,000 development containing 1,914 apartments and will be called Fairfield Towers.

The breezes blow strong these January nights. Last Sunday it was the Aeolus Quintet, and last night an unrelated group called the Aeolian Chamber Players made its New York debut in a Town Hall concert. Names are unimportant; what...
DETROIT, Jan. 24--The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would seek two new outlets for its common stock in West Germany in an attempt to increase European interest in Ford and its products.
United States Steel Corporation's Oliver iron mining division has announced that prices for its Mesabi Range natural blast furnace iron ores will be reduced about 7 per cent.
American Export Lines, the nation's fourth largest subsidized steamship operator, appeared yesterday to be headed for a major labor dispute.

Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, said yesterday he would make a fresh attempt to settle the dispute between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union. He expressed optimism that a compromise would be reached within the next thirty days.

In recent weeks, New York's fur district has been looking very much like an American woman's vision of paradise. The height of the annual fur-buying season falls in January and February, and warehouses and auction rooms in the West Twenties have become inundated with seas of mink and pools of seal, beaver, otter, sable and other luxurious skins.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 24 --The Hofstra College quintet snapped Army's home-game winning streak at twenty-two by defeating the cadets, 57 to 45, in the field house today.

Governor Rockefeller charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner was trying "to slide away from the responsibility" of administering rent control, and the Mayor replied that the Governor should "stop playing political tennis with rent control."

Gus Bell, the father of seven children, all of whom will accompany him to spring training at St. Petersburg, Fla., next month, can almost organize his own baseball team. For the time being, though, the 33-year-old outfielder plans to make it on his own with the New York Mets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Administration plans to issue a code of conduct governing the activities of scientists serving as advisers to the Government.
MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP)--The Darby Dan Farm's Bramalea sprinted to a two-and-a-quarterlength victory in the $33,500 Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah today.
With cocoa leading the way, the majority of commodities traded on the New York exchanges dropped yesterday. Wool futures, which had advanced on Monday and Tuesday, also dropped somewhat.
POMPTON PLAINS, N.J., Jan. 24--The children in Miss Gail Herman's third-year class at North Boulevard School went home today glowing with a sense of great accomplishment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that Aerojet General Corporation had been selected to develop the most powerful liquid-hydrogen fueled rocket engine yet built.
Teachers at New York University will get raises Sept. 1, and students will be charged $5 more a credit to help meet the bill.

DUBLIN, Jan., 24--Dr. Paul Singer, prominent philatelic dealer, who was convicted on charges of fraudulent conversion and sentenced to fourteen years in jail, won his freedom today in a retrial. His case was the longest legal battle ever fought in the Irish courts.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 24 (UPI)--The Government brought 2,000 more troops into Caracas today to help restore order after three days of Leftist bombings, gun battles and bloodshed.

PARIS, Jan. 24--A plan that would radically alter the present system of world trade in wheat, and later probably in many other foods, is under study in the main Western capitals, including Washington.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Further liquidation took grain futures prices down again today on the Board of Trade and carried some to within small fractions of season lows.
The "Bob Newhart Show," which made its debut last fall, is undergoing changes in its production staff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- The Indian Government apparently plans to tell President Kennedy that it cannot consider negotiating with Pakistan on the Kashmir question until after the Indian Parliamentary elections in the latter part of February.
DAVID BRINKLEY served as "Our Man in Vienna" on Channel 4 last night and came up with a filmed splitlevel view of a Mittel Europa never-never land.

LONDON, Jan. 24--Courtaulds, Ltd., gave a forecast today of rising profits that was believed to be aimed at discouraging its shareholders from accepting a bid by Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., for their shares.
BOSTON, Jan. 24--The America's Cup candidate Easterner will be handled by George D. O'Day and C. Raymond Hunt in her 1962 campaign to be named the defender of the historic trophy.
PARIS, Jan. 24--Today might be the calm before the storm in the couture showings. No new trends appeared, but tomorrow promises to be a day of excitement with the opening of Dior.

The Nelson Fund, Inc., the socalled "fund for millionaires," announced yesterday that it would seek "a somewhat wider distribution" of shares by asking stockholders to approve a two-for-one split. Approval for the split will be sought at the annual meeting on Feb. 27, and if voted the split will become effective the next day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Kennedy expressed regret today over the fivehour day that construction electricians in New York have won in their new contract.
Federal agents will start enforcing a new law on Feb. 1 requiring the proper labeling of household products whose use is hazardous, unless Congress meanwhile amends the law.

The amazing development at the recent jumping trials in Colorado and Wisconsin was the failure by Ansten Samuelstuen of Boulder, Colo., to make the American squad. Ansten, now 32 years old, had been considered the mainstay.

PARIS, Jan. 24--Government security officials regard the extremist Secret Army Organization in France as a headless monster capable of hit-and-run bomb outrages and assassinations but not of serious challenge to the regime.
The retirement of two top officers of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company was announced by Charles J. Stewart, chairman, at the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday.

The bond market was occupied mostly yesterday with the distribution of $504,000,000 of debt securities of the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May), the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Banks for Cooperatives and Australia.

AMERICANS have grown so accustomed to the insult from abroad that a kind word from a citizen of another country seems as welcome as fresh strawberries in January. Especially when the flattery concerns fashion and is uttered by a woman from Paris.
Unusually cold weather throughout the nation resulted in a drop of 9,607,000 barrels in stocks of light fuel oil in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 --The plea by the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences to the movie industry to show restraint in its campaign for Oscar votes apparently has been ignored.
Efforts to "mass produce" scientists are bound to fait, no matter how much money is poured into such programs, the American Association of Physics Teachers was told here yesterday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 24 (AP)--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd's plan to give local self-government to the African tribes in the Transkei area was attacked today by opponents of his racial segregation policies.
IQ.--Mr. President, the House Rules Committee, I understand, has just voted down your urban affairs bill. I wonder if, in that view, you plan to send--submit it again?
STONY POINT, N.Y., Jan. 24 --The people of this country have "a sacred task" to build up a world community under world government and world law, a State Department official said today.

THOSE jealous guardians of Hall of Fame admissions, the voting members of the Baseball Writers Association, were entitled to be proud of themselves yesterday. They elected Bobby Feller and Jackie Robinson to the Cooperstown shrine and thereby displayed rare discernment and even rarer unanimity of opinion. Rapid Robert made it by a landslide and Jackie by four votes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Ap) --The White House said today that President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan undoubtedly would see each other when the British leader visits this country next spring.
Cotton futures declined 2 to 10 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Kennedy urged the American public again today to put its faith in the American cow and keep on drinking milk. lots of milk.

A modest exhibit among thousands of heralded items at the Winter Antiques Show has turned out to be one of the most valuable. It is the first log of the U.S.S. Constitution --Old Ironsides--first flagship of the United States Navy.
According to the principals themselves, speed will be the determining factor in Saturday night's fight between Federico Thompson of Argentina and Luis Rodriguez of Cuba at Madison Square Garden.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 24--The Joint Legislative Committee on School Financing was put under heavy pressure today to increase substantially the $96,500,000 rise in state aid to schools recommended in its recent staff report.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) --President Kennedy today named eleven more members to his Committee on Youth Employment, including two Cabinet members.
Four publishing houses became embroiled yesterday in a Supreme Court dispute over two books about President Kennedy's wartime exploits as a PT-boat skipper.
About 1,000 art patrons last night jammed a handsome Georgian-style mansion at 41 East Sixty-sixth Street for a house-warming and an odd kind of auction.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 24 (AP) --Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg advised employers today that unions might ease demands for a shorter work week if President Kennedy's plan to strengthen the unemployment compensation system was enacted.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24-- As expected, sustained good business in the last seven months of 1961 enabled the Pennsylvania Railroad to show a profit for the year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24--The Soviet Union has asked that Soviet nationals be given eighty key positions on the United Nations staff and that promotions be given to at least twenty of its citizens already employed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Kennedy was in his glory today. He was back fighting Republicans, after a year of sparring with Communists, and he obviously loved the change. This was, in a way, the start of the political campaign of 1962. The old conservative coalition on the House Rules Committee struck the first blow.

An offering to the public of $35,000,000 of 4 per cent sinking fund debentures of W.T. Grant Company was made by Lehman Brothers and associates yesterday at par. The bonds were quickly sold and late yesterday were quoted at 100 1/8 bid, 100 3/8 offered.

Agents of the Food and Drug Administration and United States marshals seized more than $30,000 worth of safflower seed oil capsules and copies of the best-selling book "Calories Don't Count" yesterday in Brooklyn.
The Tennessee Valley Authority borrowed $45,000,000 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 4.522174 per cent.
A Protestant theologian, they Rev. Ralph D. Hyslop, suggested last night that Protestants might have to give serious consideration to the doctrine of papal authority.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 24--Governor Rockefeller accused the Kennedy Administration tonight of seeking to police and Coerce agriculture.
The play will still be the thing in the Space Age, but the playhouse will be more dramatic than ever before, in the view of eight designer-architect teams.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 25 (AP) Boston's College's hockey team completed a sweep of its season's series with Providence College tonight when it blanked the Friars, 2-0. The Eagles' goalie, Charlie Driscoll, turned in a spectacular performance.
The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday the long-projected $150,000,000 commercial development on the site of the old Washington Street Market.
Do advertisers have any respect for the laws of logic or the rules of semantics?
The Right Rev. Charles Francis Boynton, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will return to his former role as jazz pianist.

LOCAL weather may be springlike, but fruit and vegetable stands are not taking part in this make-believe. They still show effects of the season and the cold spells in the South. Poultry, too, has been affected by freezing conditions.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) Cincinnati, with renewed hope of a share of another Missouri Valley Conference basketball title, crushed North Texas State tonight, 89-61.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 (AP) The United States Open champion, Gene Littler of San Diego, today shot his finest golf since winning the 1961 national title, taking the first-round lead in the $50,000 San Francisco international open tournament with a 6-under-par 65.

Farband, the labor Zionist group with a membership of 37,000, will sponsor a double bill of a Yiddish musical, "Hershel from Ostropol," and a concert program Saturday night at the High School of Fashion Industries, 225 West Twentyfourth Street.
A second-floor office where dreams come in wholesale lots and millions of tender memories have begun is soon to lose its venerable and famous look-to the sorrow of no one.

POINT MUGU, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI) An Army Nike Zeus missile successfully intercepted today a simulated enemy intercontinental ballistic missile headed toward the United States at a speed of 14,000 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Members of the Senate Banking Committee called today for Congressional hearings on proposals for a Federal fallout shelter program.
Robert Moses, president of the New York World's Fair 1964-65 Corporation, said yesterday he had "no thought of leaving" his present residence and responsibilities for another job.

A taxi medallion that was too shiny to be real led to the arrest of a Queens man yesterday on charges of stealing a taxi meter, forging documents and manufacturing his own medallion with a toy soldier casting set.
Five persons suspected of having ties with Brooklyn's warring hoodlum gangs were arrested yesterday on charges of violating the Motor Vehicle Code.

Net income of the Union Pacific Railroad Company rose to $67,670,489 in 1961 from $65,312,512 in 1960, according to a report released yesterday. Operating revenues climbed to $499,324,448 from $494,184,464. Operating expenses were $360,798,813, compared with $359,741,036.
DEATH IN THE CITY ROOM," an excellent, serious inquiry into the state of health of the newspaper business, was televised last night on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2.
The nation's museums and libraries are pressing to have themselves included in the group of institutions to which a donor may contribute 30 per cent of his taxable income.

THE special pleasures and pressures of raising chil dren in the city are well known to thousands of Manhattan mothers. A mother's busy, sometimes hectic day, requires the swiftness of a gazelle to rescue a toddler from the brink of a minor disaster, the strength of Atlas to match his energy and the adaptability to play myriad roles, of which motherhood is only one.

Roger Lewis, 49, yesterday was elected president and chief executive of the financially ailing General Dynamics Corporation, maker of a wide range of defense products. His appointments become effective in April.
Donald S. McNulty, a former account executive with Marsh McLennan, Inc., insurance brokers, at 70 Pine Street, died Wednesday in his home at 186 Sullivan Street. He was 70 years old.

Carnegie Recital Hall was filled beyond its seating capacity last night for the second concert this season in the series called "The Festive Pipes." For last night's concert Bernard Krainis, recorder player and Morris Newman, bassoonist, were joined by a string ensemble and harpsichord in five baroque concertos.
James Mount Nicely of New York, vice president and treasurer of the Ford Foundation, was elected vice chairman of the new State Job and Development Authority yesterday.
Assemblyman Mark Lane, who has brought conflict-of-interest charges against Joseph F. Carlino, Speaker of the Assembly, appeared yesterday in Chief Magistrates Term to answer a 1960 traffic summons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The director of the Alliance for Progress said today that the "leader class" in Latin America still had not accepted the necessity of social and economic reforms as the only alternative to the spread of Castroism.

Directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company declared a 3 per cent stock dividend yesterday for payment on March 16 to holders of record of Feb. 9. It was the first payment since 50 cents in cash was disbursed in May, 1959, and represented the company's first distribution of shares other than through stock splits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Representative Francis E. Walter intorduced a bill today calling for changes in the State Department's handling of its own security problems and the issue of passports and visas.
HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) Carleton Frederick Bowes, former fish and game columnist and book reviewer for the old Halifax Chronicle, died yesterday. He was 64 years old.

The directors of Delta Air Lines, Inc. voted yesterday a 33 1/3 per cent stock dividend, payable on March 15 to holders of record of Feb. 9. The regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents was also announced, payable on March 1 to holders of record of Feb. 9.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Legislation that would impose a 20 per cent withholding tax on dividends from stocks and interest earned on savings accounts won tentative approval today from the House Ways and Means Committee.
Associates who had worked with James J. Lyons during his twenty-eight-year career as Borough President of the Bronx honored him at a testimonial dinner last night in the Concourse Plaza Hotel.

Senator Kenneth B. Keating said last night at a dinner of the Westchester Republican County Committee that Governor Rockefeller had provided "a living blueprint of social advances, of equity, of economic betterment."

New Jersey residents who work in New York will be allowed to make more deductions on their New York income tax returns this year as a result of an agreement signed yesterday by tax officials of New York and New Jersey.

James Schwabacher, a tenor who has been active in music in San Francisco for many years, largely as a performer but also as an administrator, made his first appearance in New York last night at Town Hall.

PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., Jan. 25 Rear Admiral Joseph F. Quilter, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Quilter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Quilter, to Alan Montgomery Kennedy. He is the son of Mrs. James C. Kennedy Jr. of Quogue, L. I., and New York, and the late Mr. Kennedy.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kaplan of Far Rockaway, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Myrna-Sue Kaplan, to David A. Rubenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rubenstein of Long Beach. L. I.

Stocks kept the upward momentum of their Wednesday closing hours for barely sixty minutes on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but thereafter went into a slow and lackadaisical decline and ended at or near their lows of the day.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 25 A British major and a Roman Catholic priest whom the officer saved at the risk of his own life confirmed today the horror of the massacre at a Roman Catholic mission in Kongolo, northern Katanga.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) President Kennedy today designated March as Red Cross Month. He urged all Americans to support the organization "as a channel of humanitarian assistance for their neighbors in need."

The annual report of Allied Chemical Corporation, one of the nation's major chemical producers, showed increased sales and earnings for the final quarter last year, but results for all of 1961 failed to equal those of 1960.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (AP) -The New York Tapers took a commanding lead in the third quarter tonight and went on to a 110-101 American Basketball League victory over the Pittsburge Rens.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was "appearing personally" before a coming public hearing of the Assembly committee investigating a conflict-of-interest charge against Speaker Joseph F. Carlino.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 East German border guards seized today the entry to a secret tunnel that twenty-eight East Germans used as an escape route to West Berlin yesterday, a spokesman for the Berlin city government disclosed.

In previous editorials, we have discussed the gerrymandering of Congressional districts in this city and state by the Republican-controlled Legislature. Now, Governor and Legislature must decide what they will do about the State Senate and Assembly. It is a question that arises after each decennial census as the extent of shifts in population during the prior ten years becomes known.
MINEOLA, L.I. Jan. 25 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today he was opposed to the Federal plan for a 540-acre airport at the abandoned Mitchel Air Force Base.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 A new administration was elected today on a pledge to clean up the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 25 President Kennedy did not volunteer the statement at his news conference yesterday that, if Congress will create the new Department of Urban Affairs and Housing, he will appoint as its first chief administrator Dr. Robert C. Weaver, who would thus become the first Negro Cabinet member in United States history.

Dr. Isidor I. Rabi, Nobel Prize winner in physics, said here last night that nuclear explosions in the atmosphere and underground could serve peaceful uses by providing scientific information on currents, turbulences and surface waves.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 25 (UPI) Franz Schelle of West Germany posted the best time in today's final training run and was immediately listed among the favorites for the world fourman bobsled championships Saturday and Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 The Transport Workers Union asked the Federal Court here today to halt merger negotiations between the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads until the job status of employes was clarified.
ACADEMIC has long been a bad word to call any body. It stands for a paralysis of thought that turns a discovered visual language into a dead language.
TOKYO, Jan. 25 Japan and the United States opened here today a week-long conference to find ways of promoting cultural and educational exchanges.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 An "adjustment assistance" plan to replace the traditional safeguards against competition from imports was proposed today by President Kennedy.
A theatre party at the first performance here of the Old Vic Company's production of "Romeo and Juliet" at the New York City Center on Feb. 13 will benefit the Musicians Emergency Fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Kennedy was accused today of exploiting racism in his fight to establish a new Cabinet level Department for Urban Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Two retired four-star officers, Admiral Arleigh A. Burke and Gen. Thomas D. White, agreed at a Senate hearing today with the principle of Pentagon censorship of speeches made by military officers.
A four-alarm fire raged out of control for an hour last night in a five-story midtown apartment house, heavily damaging the top two floors. Two firemen suffered minor injuries.

The line taken by Secretary Rusk at the hemispheric conference in Punta del Este, Uruguay, yesterday was presumably a recalculation of the maximum action that the United States could hope for, but our delegation may still be demanding more than it will get.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 25 One of West Germany's leading experts on the Soviet Union suggested today that "six years after Adenauer's trip to Moscow, it is time to invite Khrushchev to Bonn."

American Electric Power Company reported yesterday that it had sold more electricity in 1961 than any other investorowned utility had ever sold in a single year. The total was 28,600,000,000 kilowatt hours. This was 4.9 per cent more than the company sold in 1960.
The Metropolitan chapter of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame made its first scholar-athlete awards yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 25 Milton Bunnell, a civic leader and a former Republican candidate for Hudson County Freeholder, died of a heart attack last night at the Jersey City Medical Center. He lived at 41 Highland Avenue.

WADDINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 25 Announcement has been made by Mrs. Pasco Whitford of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Jane Mayette, to Richard Allen Goodrich. He is the son of Professor and Mrs. Leland M. Goodrich of New York.

President Kennedy's message to Congress yesterday eloquently stated the case for the proposed Trade Expansion Act of 1962. "The two great Atlantic markets"--in the President's words--"will either grow together or they will grow apart. The meaning and range of free economic choice will either be widened for the benefit of free men everywhere--or confused and constricted by new barriers and delays."
Radio and television networks and many independent stations are preparing for coverage of the manned orbital flight scheduled for tomorrow morning.
James Prigoff of the City Athletic Club and Dave Smith of Delta Kappa Epsilon advanced to the final round of the Yale Club's Bulldog Handicap squash tennis tournament yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) The Fourth Estate Stable's heavily favored Editorialist scored a two-length victory today in the feature race at Hialeah Park before a crowd of 14,764.
Lee Higginson Corporation and associates are offering today 200,000 class A shares of Kay Windsor, Inc., at $12.25 a share.
LONDON, Jan. 25 The threat of a subway strike and other labor disputes increased the hesitancy of buyers today and stock market prices declined on a wide front.
ROME, Jan. 25 The Italian Cabinet approved today a tentative budget for 4,761,000,000,000 lire ($7,610,000,000) for 1962-63. The deficit was put at 278,800,000,000 lire ($446,000,000).
PALM BEACH, Jan. 25 President Kennedy flew here late today for a long week-end in the sun and a visit with his father, Joseph P. Kennedy.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 The Mathematical Association of America presented today its first Award for Distinguished Service to Mathematics to Dr. Mina Rees, dean of graduate studies of The City University of New York.
HELENA, Mont., Jan. 25 Gov. Donald G. Nutter and five persons were missing and presumed dead tonight in a plane crash.
MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (AP) The Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League revealed tonight the signing of Sandy Stephens, Minnesota's all-America quarterback.
If snow fell on the jungles of Africa, the scene might look the way the Rotunda of the Sheraton-East did last night for the Animal Kingdom Ball.
The needs of a nation rapidly becoming urbanized will be served if President Kennedy succeeds in his effort to create by Executive order a new Cabinet department for cities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. The first defense contractor covered by a White House agreement designed to end racial discrimination in hiring has increased its Negro employment by 26 per cent in six months.
CLIFFSIDE PARK, N. J., Jan. 25 Arthur T. Cahill, an inventor, died yesterday in his home at 154 Summit Avenue after a long illness.

Except in the Government section, the bond market continued firm yesterday in the wake of a major series of large borrowings by public agencies in which the United States Government has a stock interest.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 24 The United States has shied away from plans to starve out Communist guerrillas by spraying chemicals on rebel-controlled manioc and rice fields.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25 President Arturo Frondizi has introduced additional "streamlining decrees" to reduce imports in an effort to ease the Strain on foreign reserves.

IF the rubber has disappeared from Johnny Antonelli's once elastic left arm, there is plenty left in the tire business. So the one-time ace of the New York Giants pitching staff is abandoning baseball to devote full efforts to two booming ventures he has in Rochester. One is an expanding tire company where the rubber is resilient and the other is a newly acquired luxurytype restaurant where not even the chicken is rubber.

Bad weather across the nation was chiefly responsible for extreme ease in the money market in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. A snowstorm on the West Coast and general high absenteeism kept the float credit extended automatically to member banks on checks in collection from declining as had been expected.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) estimated yesterday that its consolidated net earnings for 1961 were $758,000,000, or $3.50 each on the 216,533,000 shares out standing at the year-end. This represents an increase of 10 per cent over the 1960 figure of $688,573,000, or $3.18 a share on the stock then outstanding.

Raccoons are not listed among the painful afflic tions of Job, but perhaps his chronicler was one of those animal lovers who believed cute, furry things could do no wrong. In any case, the blackmasked little bandits belong in a class with Job's boils.
Cotton futures were 5 to 20 points off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

MACASSAR, Indonesia, Jan. 25--Indonesia's war machine for possible invasion of Netherlands New Guinea began to take shape this week at this staging base on the southern-most tentacle of the starfish-shaped Celebes Island.

PARIS, Jan. 25 Premier Michael Debre sought today to assure a troubled nation that the full weight of the Government would be thrown into the battle against mounting extremist violence in France and Algeria.

Ohrbach's, Inc., announced yesterday that the DutchAmerican Investing Company, Inc., had acquired a portion of its stock. Dutch-American is an affiliate of the Brenninkmeyer organization, which has extensive retail interests in Europe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (UPI) Defiant collegians deployed fresh "sit-in" forces outside the office of the president of the University of Chicago today and rejected his proposal for a faculty-student review of the university's "controlled integration" housing program.
A ten-year program calling for tripled manpower and expenditures in the study of weather, climate and the atmosphere has been submitted to the Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Gen. Thomas D. White disclosed a personal secret today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Administration has decided to press for civil rights legislation at this session of Congress. The unexpected decision was signaled today by the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana.

DENVER, Jan. 25 (UPI) The Denver Broncos, who set an American Football League record last season for losing named Jack Faulkner, the Sar Diego Chargers' defensive backfield coach, as head coach today.
The State of Oregon announced yesterday plans for the sale of $25,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds due serially from 1974 to 1976. Bids will be received for the bonds on Feb. 14.
THE telephone, a conventional fixture in most homes, is becoming even more a conversation piece with the growing popularity of antique instruments from abroad.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25 Syria and Iraq began today to negotiate "defensive military cooperation."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Pakistan's request for $945,000,000 in credits for the first two years of her five-year development program has been granted.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) The world amateur ice hockey championship, threatened with calcellation over the issue of United States visas for the East German team, will go on as planned, John F. Ahearne, president of the International Ice Hockey Federation, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Senator Ralph., Yarborough took himself out of the Texas gubernatorial race today.

WARNER, N.H., Jan. 25 (AP) Officials of New Hampshire and Vermont reported tonight that the wreckage of a plane had been sighted atop Mount Kearsage in this town, twenty-two miles northwest of Concord, N.H.

ONE of New York's most elegant and celebrated restau rants, La Cote Basque, at 5 East Fifty-fifth Street, closed its doors to the public on Wednesday night. Yesterday, telephone calls for reservations were greeted with the comment, "La Cote Basque is closed today on account of labor troubles. May I suggest you call Le Pavillon or may I mike the reservation for you at Pavillon?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals set aside today a $225,000 damage award won by Riss Co., Inc., an interstate trucker, against the Pennsylvania Railroad, three rail associations and the New York public relations firm of Carl Byoir Associates.
The new President of the Philippines has made a bold move in abolishing exchange control and lifting many other governmental restrictions on economic activity.

Today's new opening is a double-bill program on the circuits "The Three Stooges Meet Hercules" and "Twist Around the Clock." The first feature, a comedy, was directed by Edward Bernds and produced by Norman Maurer. The musical entry stars Chubby Checker, Dion, Vicki Spencer, the Marcels and Clay Cole. Both pictures are Columbia releases.
The General Dynamics Corporation is a child of the "coldwar" era.
Boat shows are taking on an international flavor. Once they were thought to be exclusively American, like hot dogs, popcorn, Boston baked beans and codfish.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, today defended Regents examinations against criticism that they inhibited educational change.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 Richard M. Nixon walked through the Mission district today bidding for votes in his campaign for Governor.

Mayor Wagner was told again yesterday that an announcement of the election of a Democratic leader of New York County to succeed Carmine G. De Sapio would provide a capstone for the party's $100-a-plate victory dinner next Monday night.

Hockey may be the college sport with the brightest future, as its adherents claim. But to make it truly national, a lot of missionary work remains to be done in the areas where ice is viewed as something used only to cool a drink.
Quiet trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday ended with more gains than losses.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 25 The Rev. William C. Baxter, rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church here, died today. He was 58 years old.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO. Italy, Jan. 25 (AP) An Austrian skier, Heinrich Messner, plowed into a soft snow drift at high speed in training today and fractured a leg. The injury will keep him out of the world championships next month at Chamonix, France.
Senator Estes Kefauver urged yesterday that the United States coordinate its antitrust program with that of the European Common Market to stimulate international competition.

The General Motors Corporation, world's biggest automobile manufacturer, registered declines in sales and profits for 1961, but results were the third best in the company's history. This was indicated by preliminary figures issued yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 George Taylor Langhorne of this city, a retired Army colonel, died today in Passavant Hospital. He was 94 years old.
Thousands of skiers were still marking time last night before deciding whether to head for the northlands this week-end or to spend two days at home planning future excursions.

Miss Ann Helen Eisenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Eisenberg of Manhattan, and Michael Anthony Cooper, son of Mrs. Otto Cooper of Fort Lee, N. J., and the late Mr. Cooper, plan to be married here in April.

FURNISHING a new home is a very serious venture, ac cording to the 500 young brides-to-be and their fiances who this week trailed after Macy's twelve decorators on a guided tour of the store's newly decorated model rooms.

JACKSON, Tenn., Jan. 25 (UPI) Three Negroes were admitted to eighth-grade classes at a previously white school without incident today. A secret plan was carried out to end school segregation in this town.
A pair of thugs forced their way into a hearse that had stopped for a traffic light yesterday and robbed the chauffeur of a $3,500 payroll.
PARIS, Jan, 25 Trying to play it safe today, Marc Bohan of Dlor repeated ideas from his first smash collection just a year ago, but threw in a few changes.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 25 Wives waiting for commuters at the New Haven Railroad station here tonight watched open-mouthed as their husbands' train sped by.
Even the automated Times Square-Grand Central shuttle needs the occasional attention of humans, the Transit Authority reported yesterday as it sent the train into the shop for a check-up.
The prestige of vocational education in the Soviet Union has soared with the flight of Maj. Yuri Gagarin, the world's first astronaut, a Brooklyn Museum audience was told yesterday.
The Holland-America Line's Nieuw Amsterdam will reappear on the local shipping scene this afternoon as a two-class liner after an absence of more than four months.

The election of two new directors by the Equitable Life Assurance Society was announced yesterday by James F. Oates Jr., president of the company. The new board member's are J. Irwin Miller and Dr. James B. Fisk.
Stockholders of the Firth Carpet Company voted approval yesterday of a proposed merger of Firth into Mohasco Industries, Inc., the nation's leading rug and carpet company.
Former President Harry S. Truman will visit the site of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair on Monday to attend the dedication of Truman Walk, a permanent promenade there.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 One of television's more intriguing problems came to the surface late this afternoon in the network hearings before the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Officials of the National Grange met with President Kennedy today and pledged their vigorous support to his proposal for broader authority to reduce tariffs.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York said yesterday that it expected to raise $20,000,000 by the end of this month toward its goal of $22,500,000 to maintain 116 health and welfare agencies here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Restaurant operators wined and dined their Congressmen today in an effort to head off tax curbs on business entertainment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 Moviegoers who complain these days that many films are too long mould be even more miserable were it not for film editors, who slash a good deal of unnecessary footage.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP) The Soviet Foreign Ministry said today that United States leaders were welcome to visit the Soviet Union, but it denied that the Soviet Union had taxen any intiative in inviting Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York reported yesterday that it had raised more than $28,000,000 last year.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $25,000,000 to $44,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $65,000,000 to $671,000,000. As a result, daily average net free reserves--excess reserves less borrowings--rose $90,000,000 to $627,000,000.
Governor Rockefeller reported yesterday that his new budget recommendations would include an "appreciative" increase for support of the arts.

Prof. Francis W. Sears, chairman of the Physics Department at Dartmouth College, received the Oersted Medal of the American Association of Physics Teachers yesterday for his contributions to the teaching of physics.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 25 Supporters of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, back from a cross-country march toward Punta del Este, staged a noisy but brief demonstration in downtown Montevideo tonight.

Two labor leaders in the maritime field called yesterday for a Government investigation into what they described as the "manipulative practices and blatant defects" in the shipment of foreign-aid cargoes.

The property at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street has been purchased by a group of investors for improvement with a twenty-story and penthouse apartment building. The vacant site, known as 650 Park Avenue, formerly was occupied by the Sulgrave Hotel. It was bought for a reported price of about $4,000,000.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP)--Gardnar Mulloy, an Ecuadorean Davis cup player, Eduardo Zuleta, and a University of Miami star, John Karabasz, entered the Miami invitation tennis tournament semi-finals today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Justice Department said today it was looking into some of the legal aspects of the episode in which President Kennedy rebuked a woman reporter yesterday for the nature of her question about two State Department employes.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., New York realty investors, were the buyers of two apartment buildings at 35-54 Eighty-third and 35-53 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. The parcels were sold recently by J. Raskin through this William K. Langfan Company, broker.
Events today: "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Thomas Schippers, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Zara Boloukhanova,
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 25 (UPI) A hearing on a charge of disorderly conduct against Sherwood Egbert, head of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation, was postponed today over protests of the prosecution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 An executive of the Columbia Broadcasting System indicated today that he thought television audiences were not being annoyed by commercials.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Agency announced today a $189,000,000 program to make air travel safer through improved airports and modernized navigation aids.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 25--Senator Wayne Morse said today that Brazil "did a disservice to the free world by evading a firm stand" on the Communist threat to the inter-American system at the American foreign ministers' conference here.
A Federal grand jury charged a former major blood distributor yesterday with selling unsafe blood to hospitals after changing the expiration date on labels.
When the world is struck a hammer blow by a major earthquake, everything on earth bounces up and down for roughly a month.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 25 A twenty-nation conference of African heads of state and government leaders opened here today with formal acknowledgement of a basic split among independent African countries.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) Sprite Rodney, the 1961 2year-old trotting sensation, became one of the highest-priced fillies in harness racing history today when she was sold for $100,000 at the Ben White Raceway Training Center.
AS the bidding diagram shows today, North-South reached a slam contract at six diamonds and, as examination of the four hands will show, the slam was a laydown.
NAM THA, Laos, Jan. 25 (AP) The village militia, including small boys, was hastily armed today to help defend this provincial center against a sudden attack by pro-Communist Pathet Lao troops.

An informal census taken aboard the Grace Line's S. S. Santa Paula yesterday revealed that at least thirteen young Peruvians counted themselves as friends of the United States. All are members of Peru's national basketball team, which is touring this country under the aegis of the People-to-People Sports Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) Phyllis Preuss of Pompano Beach and Barbara Williams of Richmond, Calif., gained a 5-and-4 victory today in the opening round of the women's amateur international four-ball golf tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25 Adlai E. Stevenson served notice today that wherever states resorted to force, instead of using United Nations machinery for peaceful change, they could expect "vigorous opposition from the United States, whoever they may be."
RAMSEY, N.J., Jan. 25 The second of two escaped convicts was captured here at 7:30 o'clock this morning, about twelve hours after his companion had been seized in nearby Allendale.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) The first stages of a $65,000,000 industrial development at Boundary Bay, at the United States border about twenty miles south of here, will be started next year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 For over 100 years, Democratic Presidents have been talking about the virtues of free trade, but none has taken a bolder step toward that goal than President Kenned.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 25 (AP) The physics building at the University of Alabama was closed when leakage of radioactive material used in research was discovered yesterday, a university official said today.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, former Prime Minister of Indian-held Kashmir, and fourteen others were turned over to a higher court today after the longest trial in Indian history.
LONDON, Jan. 25 A National Productivity Year described as the biggest cooperative effort ever made by British industry in peacetime was announced here today.
Plans for the construction of a new motion-picture theatre here and an expanded program in film distribution and in television were announced yesterday by Trans-Lux Corporation.

The Monsanto Chemical Company's fourth-quarter results lifted its 1961 sales to a record of $932,915,000. This was 4.8 per cent above the $890,114,000 volume of the year before. Consolidated net income also was above the 1960 level. Monsanto was the only one of four chemical companies that reported annual results yesterday to show higher earnings.

One of the high points of the current season of the New York City Ballet at the City Center was the revival last night of Frederick Ashton's superb ballet, "Illuminations", set to Benjamin Britten's cycle of songs on poems of Rimbaud.

FOR the greater part of "Creditors," Strindberg treats his favorite theme, the ruthless battle between the sexes, with the laughing dex terity of a swordsman who relishes the sport as he waits artfully for the kill.
Western European nations cannot unite and keep their sovereignty, too, Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium said yesterday.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 25 A commission of seven ministers of Morocco and the Algerian rebel regime was designated today to draft a "Charter of a Union of North African States."
For the first time, peds were allowed to walk swanchwise here yesterday. They liked it very much.

NEXT Monday will be the 225th, anniversary of the birth of Thomas Paine in Thetford, England. This chronological fact has no current significance except that it does give this column a technical license for discussing the least celebrated period of his life.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 The Court of Appeals, in a 6-1 decision, today upheld the right of New York City's Board of Education to bar two construction concerns from further school building.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 25 Secretary of State Dean Rusk's eloquent speech today was generally received with approval by the other foreign ministers meeting here.

Directors of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation have elected Austin R. Zender as president of the company, it was announced yesterday by John E. Bierwirth, chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Zender succeeds Roy F. Coppedge Jr., who has resigned as president and a director to become general counsel of the corporation.

For labor leaders who worry about how proposed railroad mergers will affect their members, John Budd, president of the Great Northern Railway, has a suggestion. His carrier, the Northern Pacific, the Chicago Burlington and Quincy and the Spokane, Portland and Seattle roads want to merge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Trustees of the New Haven Railroad told members of the New York and New England Congressional delegations today that about $7,000,000 of Federal and state aid must be provided annually if the line was to maintain its passenger services.
Governor Rockefeller pledged his support yesterday to legislation that would add thirtyeight new judges to the state court system.
Bethlehem Steel Corporation's earnings for the final quarter of 1961 reached the highest level since the March quarter of 1959 and capped the best yearly profit showing since 1958.

Casey Stengel, speaking without a trace of double-talk, yesterday warned that the Yankees would "go on winning the pennant for at least five years" unless the nine other American League clubs did something about it.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Jan. 25 Jean Tschumi, internationally known Swiss architect, was found dead today in his compartment on a Paris-Lausanne train. He was 57 years old.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 Despite frequent incursions by the censor, East Germany's leading political cabaret, die Distel (the Thistle), appears to be as lively at it was before the Communists walled in the country last August.
Joseph P. Blitz, Inc., builder and realty investor, has announced that three construction men of long experience have joined the organization.
A plan to use demountable or portable classrooms to relieve overcrowing in about seventy schools by next September was announced last night by the City's Board of Education.
Dr. David Tropauer, a physician of 2720 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, died yesterday in the Bronx Veterans Hospital. His age was 68.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 Two of the most significant rocket launchings in the space program to date are on the schedule for tomorrow and Saturday.
The Fire Department brought operators of 120 hotels and rooming houses into Municipal Court yesterday in a continuing safety campaign that was spurrred by a fire in the Mayflower Hotel last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Kennedy asked Congress today for new tariff bargaining powers that be said would clear the way for a vast expansion in the foreign trade of the United Siates aand of the West.
ALGIERS, Jan. 25 Crowds of European Rightists demonstrated against President de Gaulle today in Algiers and Oran, Algeria's two largest cities, and mass violence erupted in Oran.

ROME, Jan. 25 Pope John XXIII braved a cold drizzle today to leave Vatican City and drive to the Basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls. It was there three years ago today that he announced intention to convoke the ecumenical or universal council of the Catholic Church.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25--The Soviet Union called today for an immediate meeting of the Security Council to consider the failure of the United Nations to obtain the removal of mercenaries from Katanga.
The Bethlehem Steel Company plans to close its two ship repair yards in Brooklyn and consolidate these operations with its Hoboken, yard.

PARIS, Jan. 25 Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, came today to the defense of Gen. Adolph Heusinger, who is under attack by the Soviet Union for his war record as a German officer.
"The Jack Benny Program" is expected to continue next season on the Columbia Broadcasting System. Now televised on Sundays at 9:30 P.M., the show may be rescheduled in the fall on Tuesdays at 9:30.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Jan. 25 A sixty-acre estate in the Shinnecock Hills section was purchased today for a liberal arts college of Long Island University. The cost was $325,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Howard Charles Petersen has just walked into a lion's den. Mr. Petersen is a Philadelphia banker and a Republican--a combination that might suggest he would not be the man to manage President Kennedy's campaign for a new look in foreign ...
Dr. Edward Dangler, principal of Public School 154 in Jamaica, Queens, for the last ten years, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 64 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn.

By his icy rebuke to the news correspondent who, emulating the late Joseph R. McCarthy, called two State Department employee "wellknown security risks," President Kennedy has let it be known that he will use all his prestige to defend officials against unsubstantiated attacks. Adequate channels exist for evaluating complaints about the trustworthiness of people in sensitive Government jobs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) The New York Knickerbockers, paced by Richie Guerin and Willie Naulls, scored a 117-102 victory tonight over the Chicago Packers.

The new president of the General Dynamic Corporation, Roger Lewis, was no stranger to aviation when he joined Pan American World Airways in 1955. He had been assistant secretary of the Air Force for two years before that.
Two Wall Street investment houses announced yesterday the appointments of new executives.

Last season the New York Giants picked up the not-soyoung Y.A. Tittle as quarterback insurance for Charlie Conerly. The insurance man passed the Giants to the Eastern Conference title in the National Football League.

A thousand demonstrators 300 hot-rodders and 700 of their supporters showed up on Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens, last night to renew their plea for a legal, quarter-mile drag-racing stirp.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) A 5,800-acre site has been purchased for a $25,000,000 national religious center in which Biblical scenes Will be reproduced and research in Bible history conducted.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged Wednesday from 85.1 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.1 on Jan. 19, 1961.

WARSAW, Jan. 25 Two thousand Poles who were forced laborers for the I.G. Farbenindustrie have abandoned a four-year attempt to obtain group compensation from the West German concern, it was announced today.

Delbert Mann, who won an Oscar for directing "Marty," has agreed to stage a musical version of the film "Tovarich." This will be his first Broadway musical assignment; he has staged such straight works as "Speaking of Murder" and "A Quiet Place."

WARSAW, Jan. 25 Two thousand Poles who were forced laborers for the I.G. Farbenindustrie have abandoned a four-year attempt to obtain group compensation from the West German concern, it was announced today.

Delbert Mann, who won an Oscar for directing "Marty," has agreed to stage a musical version of the film "Tovarich." This will be his first Broadway musical assignment; he has staged such straight works as "Speaking of Murder" and "A Quiet Place."
CARACAS, Jan. 25 One person was reported to have been killed here today in a skirmish between "extremists" and policemen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) A group of Washington business men culminated a two-year, $500,000 study today with a broad proposal for a general improvement of the main business district of the capital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 About 3,100,000 workers in the United States owed their jobs to the nation's export trade in 1960, the Labor Department reported today.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 25 Secretary of State Dean Rusk urged the conference of American foreign ministers today to adopt a plan "to guard our own continent" against the dangers of aggression from the Soviet bloc through a Cuban bridgehead.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 25 A $30,000,000 electronic system for providing airline information and reservations instantly was operated experimentally here today by American Airlines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 17 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 25 Premier David Ben-Gurion asserted tonight that "Israel is the basis of the whole existence of the Jewish communities everywhere, especially in the United States."
ATHENS, Jan. 25--Archbishop Iakovos, who was elected twelve days ago as Primate of the Orthodox Church of Greece, yielded to a nation-wide outcry and abdicated today.
The United States should export more ideas and fewer tractors to the newly emerging nations, Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court said here last night.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (UPI) The executive board and wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers of America will meet here next month to formulate the demands that will be presented in forthcoming contract negotiations covering basic steel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) In one of their broadest general advances in a month, wheat futures gained almost two cents a bushel in spots today on the Board of Trade. All other commodities were firm to strong but gains were limited to about a cent.
Professional basketball's top attraction, the Boston Celtics, will meet the New York Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Some Republicans on the Joint Economic Committee complained today of what they called omissions in the Administration's annual economic reports. They suggested reforms.
The Citizens Union voiced strong opposition yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's proposal to transfer city rent control to the city government.
The sixth birthday luncheon of the Gotham Chapter of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee will be given next Tuesday at Le Chateau in the Savoy Hilton.

An improved detection system for heavy ions used in the accelerator experiments of nuclear physics was reported by Yale University physicists here yesterday at the meeting of the American Physical Society.

THE circumstances surrounding Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera" are well known among opera buffs: how Verdi and his librettist, Antonio Somma, originally set the opera in Sweden; how the Italian censors of the Eighteen Fifties put their foot down; how the locale was transformed to Boston.

Mrs, Lucy Robins Lang of Beverly Hills, Calif., writer and an early leader in the American labor movement, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. She was in her late seventies and the wife of Harry Lang, retired staff writer of The Jewish Daily Forward.
SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 25 Provisional President Eusebio Rodolfo Cordon said today that El Salvador and the entire Caribbean area were threatened by a conspiracy of international communism based in Cuba.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (AP) Mrs. Grace A. Stoops Kaufmann, widow of Edgar Kaufmann, the department store executive, was found burned to death in her home today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Substantial increases in freight movements last week from the levels of the preceding week and the 1961 period were reported today by the railroad and trucking industries.

Contracts for new construction throughout the country amounted to $2,712,090,000 last month, an upsurge that swelled the building total for 1961 to a record high. The total last year was $37,135,367,000, a gain of 2 per cent over the volume of $36,317,629,000 in 1960.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Friday, Jan. 26 (AP)--Dr. E. Stanley Jones, United States born missionary, has been nominated for the 1962 Nobel Peace Prize, the Newspaper Stockholms-Tidningen said today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Jan. 25 Mrs. Eliza (Granny) Harper, who remembers seeing Gen. Ulysses S. Grant parade in Brooklyn after the Civil War, received a card here today from President Kennedy on her 106th birthday anniversary.

TRENTON, Jan. 25 The Port of New York Authority disclosed plans today for a sweeping extension of the Hudson Tubes system to provide North Jersey commuter railroads with a rapid-transit link to Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Senator Kenneth B. Keating urged the Senate today to heed the demands of the nation's colleges and adopt a bill to make the fixing of sports events a Federal crime.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) The "Tuesday-toThursday Club," a group of Representatives devoted to a three-day work week, has come under attack by a fellow lawmaker.

Now that Thelonious Monk works fairly regularly, much of the aura of mystery that once shrouded him has passed to another jazz musician, Sonny Rollins. Mr. Rollins, a tenor saxophonist, has spells of going into retirement to think and to practice. His most recent spell lasted for two years and ended in November.

Frank Boucher will be the first hockey player and also the first Canadian to receive the annual award of The Sportsmanship Brotherhood at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor on Feb. 8. The ward was iniated in 1927, when it was awarded to Walter Johnson.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 25 (UPI) Eric Carlsson and Gunnar Haggbom won the Monte Carlo rally today and gave Sweden its first triumph in the thirty-one runnings of the event.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 25 (AP) President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes put Guatemala under a state of siege today following the assassination last night of the country's secret police chief, Ranulfo Gonzalez Onelle.
WASHINGTON, Jan.25 (AP) President Kennedy and the president of the Southern Baptist Convention, the Rev. Dr. Herschel H. Hobbs, exchanged greetings and books today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 25 Dr. Alice Farwell Warren, chairman of the Department of History at Skidmore College, died yesterday in a nursing home in Bedford Hills. Her age was 57.

Twenty-three chess masters, representing twelve countries, will participate in the interzonal tournament at the Kungshallen in Stockholm, according to a report from Sweden yesterday. The tournament will start tonight and last to March 8. It is the second step leading to the world championship.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP)--Stockholders of Air Products and Chemicals, Inc., and the Houdry Process Corporation have approved a plan to merge the two concerns. The merger will take place in about two weeks, it was announced.
The status of the world amateur hockey championship became clouded by a State Department announcement in Washington yesterday that Allied policy would bar the East German team from the competition.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)--The presence of Fourand-Twenty in tomorrow's $153,910 Santa Anita Maturity failed to frighten many horses from the one-and-a-quarter-mile race today. Nine were entered for the $100,000 added stakes.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 26--The European Common Market today welcomed President Kennedy's request for new tariffnegotiating powers to facilitate a broad agreement with the six-nation economic bloc.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26--An international convention to protect performers, broadcasters and record companies from "piracy" was deposited today at United Nations headquarters to be signed by Governments that have not already done so.
BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- Eighty Internal Revenue Service agents armed with tax liens seized the industrial empire of Bernard Goldfine today to protect Government tax claims.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 25--The Yugoslavia Express puffed into Sofia's main railroad station after a ten-hour trip along the 337 miles from Belgrade. An impassive taxi driver deposited baggage in the trunk of his shiny Russian Volga, gestured suddenly at the fog blanking out all but near-by buildings.

Michael Ellis has acquired for Broadway next season "Before I Die," a new play by Robert Noah based on the tenacious fight by a prominent Boston lawyer to free Sacco and Vanzetti in the murder of a paymaster and a guard at South Braintree, Mass.
Milton Mollen is slated to be named chairman of the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 25-- United States pilots are risking their lives dropping live pigs and chickens to starving South Vietnamese troops at army outposts along the Laos frontier.
A variety of dreams went on display at the coliseum yesterday for the man who would like to run his own business and be his own boss.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 26 (AP)--Richard W. Rogers, chief of the Public Safety division for United States aid in Libya, died of a heart attack Wednesday night. He was 54 years old.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 26--A fleet of twenty-six ocean racers is scheduled to leave here at noon tomorrow in the 403mile race to Fort Lauderdale.
