STRETCHING the limited storage space of a small kitchen takes some ingenuity, much planning and a bit of shopping around. With little shelf area, cooking utensils that stack one on top of the other are often advisable.
TWO New York department stores are offering sewing classes beginning Monday that are open to the public free of charge.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 --The Pennsylvania State Senate early today passed a compromise reapportionment bill reducing the number of Congressional districts in the state from thirty to twenty-seven. The vote was 44 to 6.

The Cuban revolution, from its inception three years ago, resembled the process of dropping a stone in a lake. There is the splash--and then the ripples that go on and on until stopped by the solid shores.
Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller intend to go through with their previously announced plans for a divorce, a family spokesman said yesterday.

CULTURED pearls, muchcoveted luxuries in any woman's jewelry wardrobe, are becoming more and more popular in America. The number imported from Japan has jumped from 9,000,000 in 1957 to an estimated 16,000,000 in 1961, according to the Japan Pearl Trade Association.

The European Economic Community, having passed the point of no return in economic integration, now moves to a higher plateau. It is embarking on the road toward political unification, for which economic integration was a necessary preparation. At the end of this road beckons a vision that has inspired European minds for centuries--a kind of United States of Europe embracing 300,000,000 people and equal in world power to the United States and the Soviet bloc.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP)--The administrators of the estate of Bishop Sherred C. Johnson sued fifty-two radio stations today. They charged that recordings of the Bishop's voice were being used without authorization.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 26-- Fighting in the hills near the provincial capital of Nam Tha threatened today to deprive Prince Boun Oum's Right-wing Government of administrative control of an important sector of the province.

WASHINGTON Jan. 26 (AP)--The United States Court of Appeals upheld 2 to 1 today findings of unfair labor practices against the Kohler Company in the Wisconsin plumbing fixture company's eight-year dispute with the United Automobile Workers Union.
A 58-year-old Bronx physician was shot and killed in his office at noon yesterday by a former mental patient. The slayer surrendered a few minutes later to a patrolman a short distance away.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) --The Los Angeles Lakers increased their lead to eight and a half games in the Western Division race of the National Basketball Association tonight by beating the Cincinnati Royals, 116--112, before 12,962 fans.
Higher retail prices for food, housing and personal care more than offset December declines for apparel, transportation, reading and recreation and other goods and services in New York City.

WOLF CREEK, Mont., Jan. 26 (UPI)--The bodies of Gov. Donald G. Nutter of Montana and five other men were removed from a snowy hillside near here today. At the same time, investigators from two agencies began arriving to search for the cause of the airplane crash that killed them.

Puerto Rico is giving technical assistance in planning and economic development to the new Government of the Dominican Republican, Rafael Pico, president of the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico, said here yesterday.
Henry Cabot Lodge endorsed yesterday the Government's policy in the Congo.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP)--An unseeded player, 16-year-old Thomas Koch of Porto Alegre, Brazil, upset the Brazilian Davis Cup player, Carlos Fernandes, today, 6-3, 3-6, 6-0, to advance to the semi-final round of the Miami invitation tennis tournament. Fernandes of Sao Paulo was seeded second.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26--Guinea warned today that the independent nations of Africa might resort to force to free Angola from Portuguese rule if the United Nations did not find a way to do so.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 26 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today a tentative decision to allow three cargo airlines to remain in service, but without Federal subsidy. Subsidies had been considered in a C.A.B. review of cargo line problems. The three lines are Flying Tiger, Slick and Riddle.

The Ohio Oil Company last year had estimated net earnings of $38,934,000, or $2.73 each on the 14,257,169 shares outstanding, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $39,215,000 in 1960, or $2.84 each on the 13,807,450 shares then outstanding.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26-- Gen. Taymour Bakhtiar, who was regarded as the strongest rival to Premier Al Amini, left Teheran by air today on the orders of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi for a trip to several countries of Western Europe. The general is expected to be gone indefinitely.

ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Outbreaks of influenza-like disease have developed in five more states, bringing the number of states affected this season to twenty-one, the United States Public Health Service reported today.
Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday that its sales in 1961 had topped $100,000,000 for the first time in history. The figure was $101,868,050, against $96,059,361 a year earlier.

HERSHEY, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP) --Paul Arizin went on a 4point scoring spree in the third period and Wilt Chamberlain tallied 20 of his 47 points in the final quarter to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to a 136-110 victory over the St. Louis Hawks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

PHILIPSBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 (UPI)--A thirteen-day search in an abandoned clay mine for two missing boys was halted today when mine inspectors agreed that no further steps could be taken in the underground rescue attempt.
LONDON, Jan. 26--Most sections of the stock market finished the week on a gloomy note today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-- Elvis J. Stahr Jr., Secretary of the Army, told Congress today that Regular Army men whose duty tours had been involuntarily extended as part of the build-up in the Berlin crisis would be released by July 31.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Saturday, Jan. 27--The Dominican Republic called on the meeting of American foreign ministers yesterday to apply against Cuba the kind of sanctions that helped destroy the Trujillo dictatorship.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 26--Fairleigh Dickinson routed the University of Baltimore, 79--41, tonight for its sixth victory of the season against nine losses. Baltimore has a 3-10 mark.
The Barnes Dance, a success on the road for years, appears to have scored a hit in New York.
A liner of unusual design-- built to carry passengers and a mixture of containers and general cargo--will be launched for the Grace Line on Feb. 13.

ALBANY, Jan. 26--Governor Rockefeller today announced the filing of three motor vehicle bills. They would implement highway safety proposals he made to the Legislature in his annual message earlier this month.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 26--Three suspended Southern University students were rebuffed today in their attempt to gain reinstatement at the all-Negro state institution here.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (AP) --Steve O'Neill, who spent thirty-one years in professional baseball as a catcher and manager for four different teams, died today in Huron Road Hospital here. He was 69 years old.
GENEVA, Jan. 26--The Soviet Union again reversed itself on an issue involving nuclear testing by refusing today to refer it to the eighteen-nation Disarmament Committee.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru indicated tonight that there was little hope for an early settlement of the Kashmir dispute with Pakistan.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26-- Dr. Erich Mende said today that West Germany's Ambassador in Moscow should begin talking with the Soviet Union as part of the Western exploration of Soviet intentions now being conducted by the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Consumer Price Index last year showed its smallest annual increase since 1955, the Labor Department reported today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 --Representative James E. Van Zandt of Altoona became the fifth candidate today for the Republican gubernatorial nomination.
Peter L. Waters Sr., under whose coaching Manhattan College became a track and field leader, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.

FALMOUTH FORESIDE, Me., Jan. 26--Willis Paine Beal, comanager of the Portland office of Townsend. Dabney Tyson, members of the New York and Boston Stock Exchanges, died today in his temporary home at 173 Foreside Road. He was 59 years old.

DURING the week Manhattan was weighed down with painting and sculpture, but the island showed no sign of sinking. From the point of quality, a great deal of the weight was still concentrated at the Museum of Modern Art, where the "Redon, Moreau, Bresdin" show has but one more week to run. The late Jan Muller's memorial exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum is also one not to miss.
ALTHOUGH in no way exceptional, the small show of drawings by Matisse, Picasso and Braque at the Iolas Gallery, 123 East Fiftyfifth Street, contains a few good things.
PALM BEACH, Jan. 26--President Kennedy took his father yachting today, a happy result of the progress the elder Kennedy has been making toward recovery from a cerebral stroke.

BUFFALO, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Oscar C. Anderson, the Colgate University player who as a senior was selected quarterback on Walter Camp's 1916 AllAmerica football team, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 67.

The Southern Railway announced yesterday that E.M. Tolleson had been elected executive vice president. Mr. Tolleson, formerly vice president for operation, succeeds Dennis W. Brosnan, whose election as president was announced earlier this week.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 26--Rider College defeated Juniata College, 79--58, tonight. Doug Endres paced Rider with 24 points. Pat Frazier tallied 17 for Juniata.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 26. The United States will invoke a section of its foreign aid legislation to cancel most of is remaining trade with Cuba, United States sources said here today. A dispatch printed in The New York Times today said the trade would be curbed under the Trading with the Enemy Act.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 26--Dr. Sture C. Linner, retiring chief of United Nations operations in the Congo, said today he was convinced that President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province was expelling white mercenaries from his forces.
State Commerce Commissioner Keith S. McHugh reported yesterday a total of 789 new plants or plant expansions in the state in 1961.
Mayor Wagner urged yesterday that proposed legislation on court reorganization be made public immediately and that prompt hearings be held.
FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 26-- California's big organization of volunteer Democrats prepared tonight to endorse a state-wide ticket of candidates headed by Gov. Edmund G. Brown.
NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 26--A proposal that the Christian Democratic party form a Center-Left coalition will be discussed at the party's eighth congress, which opens here tomorrow.
A summit meeting of governing heads of twenty-one African states with a combined population of 135,000,000 is meeting in Lagos, Nigeria, to launch a drive for pan-African unification.

The Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company reported yesterday that its net income in 1961 declined to $8,639,000, or $3.37 at common share, from $10,090,000, or $3.79 a share, in 1960. Sales and operating revenues fell to $71,684,000 from $87,001,000 a year earlier, according to the preliminary report.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 26 (AP) --The start of the four-man world bobsled championships was postponed today from tomorrow until Sunday because unseasonably high temperatures and rain left the mile-long Olympic course in poor condition.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP)--The strange case of Kimble Berry, who allegedly was released from a Mississippi prison to pick up $300,000 in cash that purportedly had been secreted by a convicted burglar, will be reviewed early next month by Gov. John A. Volpe of Massachusetts.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Two Roman Catholic priests, tried at Vilna in Soviet Lithuania on charges of black market speculation and illegal currency dealings, have been sentenced to prison terms ranging from four to eight years, the official press agency Tass announced today.

Twenty representatives of the New York Committee for the General Strike for Peace picketed The New York Times for an hour yesterday afternoon. They were protesting The Times' refusal to publish a full-page advertisement calling for a "world-wide general strike for peace."

GUATEMALA, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--Guatemala remained calm under martial law todayafter the Government's disclosure of an alleged "vast plot" to assassinate President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes and his Cabinet and overthrow the regime.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 26-- Nassau County Republicans were accused today of "attempting to preserve" the seat of Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach in their plan for reapportionment of the county.

Junior Achievement Week, proclaimed for next week by Governor Rockefeller, will be observed in New York City by almost 1,500 teen-agers, who operate a total of eighty-three Junior Achievement companies.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 26 --Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Farnsworth Vander Poel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Billings Vander Poel, to Richard William Day. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Verne William Day of Saginaw, Mich.

GREENVILLE, Del., Jan. 26 --Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Sharp have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah MacLellan Sharp, to William S. Farish 3d, son of Mrs. Hugo V. Neuhaus of Houston, Tex., and the late Mr. Farish Jr.

The State Power Authority filed eleven damage suits in Federal Court here yesterday against seventeen manufacturers of electrical equipment for alleged overcharges based upon collusive bids submitted to the authority.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (UPI)-- A Lloyds of London insurance underwriter is ready to bet that Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. will return alive from his orbits around the earth, a Lloyds official said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--A 9-year-old girl's complaint to President Kennedy about the state of television became part of the record at a Government hearing today.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 26-- Moroccan troop reinforcements moved to the Algerian border today with orders to use "every means" to prevent violations of Moroccan territory by the French Army in Algeria.
Cotton futures rose yesterday 1 to 20 points on the New York Cotton Exchange as the market staged a late recovery on local buying.

The President's Council of Economic Advisers has banished much of the fog about what the Administration means by recommending wage increases geared to productivity and price stability. Its guiding principle is that the over-all increase in output per man-hour of 2 to 3 per cent a year be taken as the measuring rod for higher wages and fringe benefits in any industry.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 26-- Mayor Steven J. Bercik charged today that jet aircraft operations at near-by Newark Airport had been "highly misrepresented."
Twenty-four naval vessels and numerous search planes and helicopters are deployed across the Atlantic to pick up Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. from any one of nine recovery areas.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 26--The entire University Council of Caracas University, including the rector and all deans, resigned "irrevocably today.
The Metropolitan Opera will give the American premiere of Manuel de Falla's posthumous opera, "L'Atlantida," next fall at Philharmonic Hall in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
The sale of an option to purchase controlling interest in a Wall Street bank has netted a New York real estate operator a six months' profit of almost a million dollars, it was learned yesterday.

Dealers cut by one-eighth percentage point yesterday the intrest rate paid on commercial paper sold in the open market. These are the unsecured short-term borrowings of industrial concerns and smaller sales finance companies.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 26 (AP)--The order that Alfred Krupp dispose of his coal and steel holdings has been suspended for six months more, to July 31 of this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 26-- Robert Dewey, New York's fifthranking player, rallied tonight to defeat Tom Leonards of Haverford, Pa., 15--17, 17--18. 15--12, 15--4, 15--12, in the second round of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Racquet Club.
An increase of 2,410 policemen above the present quota of 24,590 was requested yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.
The Fair Play for Cuba Committee said yesterday that Robert Taber, its executive secretary, would return to the United States "by the first of February."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) --The Kennedy Administration's first civil rights bill ran into a slashing attack from Southern Senators today. They denounced it as politically inspired and unconstitutional.

Many whose names have long been interwoven in the city's' history, gathered last night for the twelfth annual Ball of the St. Nicholas Society in the grand ballroom of the Plaza. Livingstons and Delafields, Van Burens, Van Nordens and Gardiners were among the table holders.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Mounting evidence that tuberculosis can be spread by air currents long after an infected person has left the area was reported today by The Journal of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Administration has no intention of switching shraply to a tight-money policy when recovery from last year's recession appears complete, Budget Director David E. Bell said today.

No money. No rink. This is the plight of the Brooklyn College Newman Club team. Yet the seventeen players and their volunteer coach, Dan Levy, have no intention of discarding their ten-game college schedule or ceasing their quest for a home playing surface.

What a privilege it is to hear Zara Doloukhanova again! The mezzo-soprano who came from the Soviet Union three years ago to sing in a recital here, returned last night to give a program in Carnegie Hall. Happily, her voice and artistry were as impressive as they proved to be in her first visit.
The New York Academy of Sciences has acted to relieve itself of the embarrassment of having elected a Swiss bogus physician as a Fellow of the Academy.
Airline sources close to the current mail balloting on a traps-Atlantic group discount fare were guardedly optimistic yesterday that the proposal would be adopted.
Physicians and dentists in the city's prison system yesterday demanded that correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross apologize for having said they were "generally of low quality."

THE Paris haute couture is about to be invaded for the first time in its history by an American sportswear designer. John Weitz, a much-honored designer who was born in Berlin and bred in the tradition of 11-American sportswear, said ...
THE deal shown today was played earlier in the week at the Harmonie Club in New York, and the result was determined by the timely use of a choice-compelling lead.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP)--Phyllis Preuss and Barbara Williams, last year's winners, today gained the semifinals in the women's four-ball golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-- Representative Neal E. Smith, Democrat of Iowa, proposes to make it unlawful for a Federal official to employ a relative.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 26 --William C. Martens, retired finance director of the Mennen Company, manufacturers of lotions and creams in Newark, N.J. died today of a heart attack in his home at 16 Sunny Brae Place. His age was 69.
Two major church conferences will convene at opposite ends of the Atlantic City Boardwalk beginning Tuesday.
A court ruled here yesterday against a husband's right to enter, uninvited, his legally separated wife's abode for the purpose of obtaining evidence of alleged adultery.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 26--An attempt to send a complex 727-pound spacecraft to take close-up television pictures of the moon failed today. The craft had also been intended to land the first instruments on the moon's surface.

The New York Athletic Club, led by Johnny O'Connor with 25 points defeated the University of Bridgeport, 92--75, last night at the Winged Footers' gymnasium. It was the N.Y.A.C.'s tenth basketball victory against two losses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) --Senator Paul H. Douglas said today that he and many astronomers question the wisdom of spending billions to land a man on the moon.
The International Longshoremen's Association suffered another setback yesterday in its protracted legal effort to seize the treasury of a secessionist tugboat union.
PARIS, Jan. 26--President Bourguiba of Tunisia accepted today a French proposal to resume negotiations over the naval base of Bizerte July 1.

A threatened strike by 3,200 garage workers in Manhattan and the Bronx was averted last night when the garage owners agreed to arbitrate contract renewal issues. The contract expires at midnight tonight.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 26 (UPI)--Gov. Gaylord Nelson signed today a controversial bill providing for state aid for parochial school buses. At the same time he asked for a Wisconsin Supreme Court decision on its constitutionality.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 26-- The parish of St. Paul's Episcopal Church on the Green will celebrate on Sunday the 225th anniversary of its founding with a special service of Solemn Eucharist at 10 A.M.

Almost all commodity futures registered price declines yesterday on the New York exchanges as traders evened up positions for the week-end. A few commodities were irregular, but none showed a definite upturn.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--Communist demonstrators shouting pro-Cuban slogans burned an American flag here today.
Stocks closed lower after The New York Times combined average reached the lowest point in six months. Discount stores and West Coast savings and loan issues were weakest; volume, 3,332,330 shares.

R. G. Associates, Inc., has announced plans for underwriting a syndication issue of $525,000 on Silver Lake Arms, an apartment house development on Victory Boulevard in the Silver Lake area of Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, who was once a Boy Scout in Britain, was reinducted today as an honorary Scout.

What's wrong with the Rangers? It wasn't a question to make a team that had lost eight straight National Hockey League games happy, but Coach Doug Harvey and some of the other players accepted it in the right spirit--analytically.

Mrs. Lansing P. Shield and Mrs. Eric Moederle, co-chairmen of the Blue Ridge Ball at the Pierre last evening, were honored before the dinner dance at a cocktail party given in the hotel by Howard Schermerhorn.
The wintry days are gray and dreary as men go out the door in the morning, leaving their wives to ...
James Prigoff of the City Athletic Club won the Bulldog squash tennis tournament yesterday at the Yale Club.

With military fanfare and a colorful combination of uniforms past and present, the Old Guard of the City of New York last night celebrated its 136th anniversary at the Commodore. The annual Military Ball was held in the Grand Ballroom.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26--The Eastman Philharmonia Orchestra of Rochester, N.Y., was given an overwhelming reception tonight in its first performance in the Soviet Union.
ST. LOUIS, Jan, 26--The Communist party in this country is stepping up a nation-wide campaign to influence students, an official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 26 (AP)--Sale of the Hotel Muehlebach and other near-by downtown properties to New York investors was announced today by Barney L. Allis, president of the company operating the hotel.
Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the retiring Philippine Ambassador, paid tribute yesterday to the United States in a farewell address. He called the United States a "beacon light" in a troubled world.
A heavy fog blanketed some areas of southern Fairfield County and northern Westchester County last night and early today.
PARIS, Jan. 26--France has urged the Algerian rebel Provisional Government to sign a peace accord soon to fore stall action by extremist enemies of peace in both camps.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 26--Nick Werkman, the nation's second highest major-college basketball scorer, added 33 points tonight as Seton Hall defeated Scranton University, 120 --100, before 1,995 fans.

AGANA, Guam, Jan. 26 (UPI)--Harry Guthertz, business man, said yesterday that his department store had been boycotted by Federal employes since he charged that privileges at the United States Post Exchange and commissary here had been misused.
LONDON, Jan. 26--London residents wondered tonight what was going to happen to their transportation system Monday.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan, 26-- A coincidence prevented a Negro family from obtaining an apartment last Sept. 1 in the all-white Rye Wood Gardens at Rye, the State Commission Against Discrimination was told today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-- Beulah Louise Henry, a New York inventor, set some sort of record this week though she has lost count of her patents, Government files indicate that the one she has just received is at least her forty-fifth.

The new-issues market for next week will be both narrow and sizable because the $180,000,000 issue of revenue bonds of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority will account for part of the volume. Other than that, $57,555,000 in major fixed-interest securities are slated for marketing.

SAINT--NAZAIRE, France, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--The French Line's 66,000-ton liner France, returning from her inaugural cruise to the Canary Islands, paid a last tribute today to the former flagship Liberte.
The wholesale commodity price index stood at 85.1 on Thursday for the third straight day. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, was 82.7 on Jan. 20, 1961.
Fast-moving but light-hitting Luis Rodriguez of Cuba will pit his youth and speed against the power-punching of Federico Thompson in Madison Square Garden tonight.

PARIS, Jan, 26--Roberto Capucci made it this morning with his first collection on French soil. He stirred up the most genuine excitement of the week. Loud shouts of "Bravo" pierced the air, along with the softer musical cries of "Bellisimo, multo bello" from the lips of the misty-eyed Italians in the audience. Capucci and his sister, Marcella, his business manager, were crushed in the corner by the eager audience.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Generally quiet grain futures trade consisted today almost entirely of a smattering of profit taking and hedge selling at mostly steady prices.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan 26 --In April, 1951, Dr. Fel ton Grandison Clark, then in his thirteenth year as president of Southern University, the nation's largest all-Negro college, was offered the position of senior specialist in the United States Office of Education.

With the pricing of big issues of long-term bonds of Government corporations out of the way, the bond market began to turn its attention yesterday to the next distraction coming from the new-issue calendar-- the $11,000,000,000 refunding that the Treasury will face in February. Announcement of the refunding securities is expected to be made known by the Treasury next week.
EAST SETAUKET, L.I., Jan. 26--Dr. David E. Overton, Suffolk County Health Commissioner, died of cancer today at Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson. He was 58 years old.

FOREIGN SOIL," by Robin White, is a splendid collection of stories about life in Southern India. Although I'm afraid it will do little to resolve boiling debates on imperialism and all that, or even teach us how to work the rope trick, the book is an enjoyable and subtle contribution toward international enlightenment.

ROME, Jan. 26 (UPI)--An Italian Government source said today that a Bulgarian pilot who crashed in his MIG jet fighter while apparently photographing Western missile bases in southern Italy would be tried on espionage charges in a civil court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)--Here's a suggestion for anyone irritated by junk mail: answer it.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These notes do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Four thousand scholastic runners from 175 schools will compete today in the sixth annual St. Francis Prep track and field games at the 102d Engineers Armory.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26 --Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, will fly to Paris tomorrow for meetings with the top American information officers in Europe and the director of the United States Information Agency.

Crafts Display AN open house, to acquaint visitors with the varied program offered by the Craft Students League, will be held in Tuesday from 6 to 9:30 P.M. the Young Women's Christian Association, Eighth Avenue at Fifty-first Street. The techniques used in crafts will be demonstrated and examples will be on display.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan., 26 (AP)--Gene Littler, the United States open champion, shot his second straight sub-par round today and took a five-stroke lead in the $50,000 San Francisco international golf tournament. He had a three-under-par 68 for 133 at the midway point in the tourney.
For many years a soft-spoken, hospitable Southerner--turnedNew Yorker has borne the title of "Lady Edison."

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Die Goetterdaemmerung," at 1 P.M. and "Tosca" at 8; Boston Symphony, Richard Burgin, conductor, Florence Kopleff, contralto. Chorus Pro Musica of Boston, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; New York Philharmonic, Thomas Schippers, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Golden Hill Chorus Charles Enniss, conductor, Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) --The American Medical Association urged Federal aid for the construction of medical schools today, but took no position on Federal scholarships for medical students.
A young Italian was in Federal custody here yesterday in what was said to be the first case of smuggling vitamins into this country.

Roger Maris, to the surprise of no one, added the Van Heusen Outstanding Achievement Award to his collection yesterday. The presentation, made before several hundred persons, including some present and future baseball Hall of Fame members, was made at a luncheon at Toots Shor's.

The State of Massachusetts is planning the sale of $40,000,000 to $45,000,000 in bonds in February to finance highway and sewer improvements and construction of a state office building. The date of sale has not been decided.

Minus the imposing presence of 6-foot-10-inch Bill Russell, the Boston Celtics were nothing more than suitable opponents for the New York Knickerbockers last night at Madison Square Garden. And the Knicks, sparked by Al Butler's 35-point performance, downed the National Basketball Association champions, 129--121.
The Collegiate Chorale's Town Hall concert last night was its first under its new conductor, Abraham Kaplan.
Stocks slipped yesterday to the lowest levels since July 25, according to The New York Times combined and industrial averages.
LONDON, Jan. 26--Britain will join the European Economic Community before the end of the year, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West Germany's Minister of Economics, predicted tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- First moves were made today for intervention by Parliament in the proposed 200,000,000 merger of Imperial Chemical Industries (I.C.I.) and Courtaulds. Imperial Chemical is seeking to win a large shaer of Britain's textile industry by taking over Courtaulds.
State Senator Seymour R. Thaler announced yesterday that he would run for the House of Representatives as an independent in the special election Feb. 20 in the Queens Sixth District.

The directors of the Hercules Powder Company declared yesterday a dividend of 30 cents on the common shares payable on March 23 to holders of record of Feb. 16. The company has paid dividends of 25 cents each in the March, June and September quarters and the year end dividend of 5 cents in the December quarter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UPI)-- Turkey futures advanced for the fifth straight session today, but egg contracts weakened on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Shell eggs fell 25 to 45 points, frozen eggs 25 to 30 points, turkeys rose 55 to 60 points and frozen pork bellies were nominally unchanged.
"Citizen Kane" has been named the best film in motionpicture history in a poll of seventy international critics conducted by the British Film Institute.

A two-for-one split of the common stock of the Public Service Company of Indiana and an increase in the dividend were recommended by directors at their meeting in Chicago yesterday.

Members of the volunteer committee are working on plans for the seventh annual participation of the Thrift Shop of Irvington House in the National Antiques Show. The show will open at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 28 and will run through March 8.

Carl Rossini Diton, composer, vocalist and an instructor of concert piano at the Juilliard School of Music, died Thursday at Sydenham Hospital after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 1925 Seventh Avenue.

Net income of the St. Joseph Lead Company for 1961 rose to $6,332,196 from $2,972,068 for 1960, the concern reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) --About 600 aides to Senators and Representatives, including some Republicans, were briefed for four hours today by President Kennedy's Cabinet on the Administration's legislative program.

Consolidated net income of Texaco, Inc., amounted to $430,116,577 last year, or $3.48 each on the 123,577,029 capital shares outstanding at the year-end.

In St. James Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Sandra de Clairville, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond de Clairville of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., was married to Thomas Powell Fowler Palmer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Morgan Palmer of New York.

Miss Margaret Anne Mullins of Kensington, London, a fashion commentator on British television known professionally as Veronica Gray, was married here yesterday afternoon to Gordon A. Members of golf clubs were told yesterday to expect higher dues and fees together with a curtailment of services if operating costs continued to increase. Carl Jehlen, general manager of the Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J., issued the warning as he addressed the United States Golf Association's Green Section meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

Mack G. Klosty, president of the Association of Ship Brokers and Agents, said yesterday that his group would reply next week to charges of malpractice in the chartering of ships for United States foreign-aid cargoes.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., producer of drugs and pharmaceuticals, may expand into the business of selling cosmetics and household food and drug products on a door-to-door basis through a possible acquisition.
A trustee of the New Haven Railroad said yesterday that a 10 per cent increase in the fares of 14,000 commuters in New York State was imperative.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 26--The countdown proceeded smoothly today for tomorrow's attempt to send Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. on a three-orbit journey around the earth.

Stockholders of Basic, Inc., manufacturer of refractories for open hearth and electric furnaces and of other products, voted at a special meeting in Cleveland yesterday to create a new issue of 140,000 shares of series preference stock of $50 par value.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur celebrated his eighty-second birthday yesterday, saying that he had "reached an age when every new birthday is something of a triumph."

This artful and unaffected first novel by 26- year-old Joyce Glassman reminds us that youth is no fixed quantity or state with an allexplaining adjective. It is a period of becoming whose essence is flux: the lostness or wildness are merely way-stations along this road of change.

Cesare Valletti gave his only New York recital of the season Saturday night at Hunter College. It is a pity that his appearances here are so rare these days, as Mr. Valletti is a special and cherishable musician.

THE standard bridge advice "cover an honor with an honor," like all other maxims of the game, is generally sound but is subject to many exceptions. However, the greatest weakness of this maxim may be that it does not go far enough.

UNLIKE most Broadway productions, the Baseball Writers' Show is designed to run only one performance. It's just as well. It never could survive beyond the opening anyway. Hence it ended its run on the stage of the Waldorf-Astoria last night-- unwept, unhonored, unsung--and still unrehearsed. As Walter Kerr once remarked in a crisp critique: "It was the sort of play that gives failures a bad name."
WANGANUI, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (UPI)--Peter Snell and his coach put a damper today on hopes that he would run at least two one-mile races at Madison Square Garden next month.

EDDIE ROUSH sat in the Braves' clubhouse at Bradenton in Florida last spring. He was wearing a Milwaukee. uniform and he kept pounding his old glove as he talked. Unlike the oversize leather baskets that the moderns use, his stubbyfingered mitt was no bigger than a motorman's glove. It made a bystander marvel at the fact that the once fleet center fielder had been one of the surest-handed flycatchers of his era.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Dr. Ambrose Caliver, chief of the Adult Education Section of the Office of Education, died today at his home. He was 67 years old.
Steel production advanced for the fourth consecutive week in the period ended last Saturday.
Mayor Wagner told more than 2,000 enthusiastic adherents last night that the Democratic party had "only just begun to move forward" toward achieving the full goals of reform.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 (AP)--Cuba made another plea today for understanding from her Latin-American neighbors.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Jan. 29 --Twenty-five South Jersey farm workers are learning how to develop new skills here. Ranging in age from 25 to 45, they are enrolled in the nation's first training course for farm workers under the Area Redevelopment Administration's program for the under-employed and unemployed.
More than 300 pacifists and opponents of nuclear testing marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday calling for a worldwide general strike for peace.
Physicians throughout the country are being taught the new method of external heart massage that was devised by a Johns Hopkins University team two years ago.

"IT'S the things you do that don't seem to have any significance at the time that have the greatest impact on your life," Samuel Brookner Gould says. Mr. Gould also believes in serendipity--the gift of finding agreeable...

The Southern Pacific Company, the biggest money-maker among the railroads of the nation, reported yesterday it had cleared $70,114,017 last year, compared with $65,424,791 in 1960. This was equal to $2.58 a share, compared with $2.41 a year earlier.
Can a yogi really stop the beating of his own heart? Medical research now discloses that perhaps, in rare cases, he almost can.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29-- The independent thinker was a hero at a four-day international symposium ending here today at the University of California Medical Center.
A rabbi and two undertakers received one-year suspended sentences and were placed on probation yesterday for having made false claims to the Social Security Administration for funeral expenses.
LONDON, Jan. 29--Britain intends to buy up to $12,000,000 worth of United Nations bonds by the end of 1963, Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, announced today in the House of Commons.

Profoundly Respected Nikita Sergeyevich: Eight months ago, having finished my scientific scholarship in this country, I decided to leave the ranks of the Soviet Communist party and not to return home. My reason was that I disagreed with certain aspects of the party's policy.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 29--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Yerrington Dear Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Alice Dear, to David Dearborn. He is the son of Mrs. William Gifford Nickerson of New Boston, N.H., and Wenham, Mass., and of the late Frederick Myers Dearborn.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 29 --Classes resumed today at Southern University, the nation's largest all-Negro college, despite efforts by some students to promote a general boycott.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) --The Senate confirmed today President Kennedy's key nominations in his shake-up of State Department personnel last fall.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 29 (AP)--St. John's of Brooklyn poured it on in the second overtime period for a 78--72 basketball victory over Notre Dame tonight.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 29 (UPI)--Jump-shooting Mel Nowell scored 29 points and led unbeaten Ohio State to its fifteenth basketball victory of the season tonight, a 94-73 conquest of Purdue. The triumph was the Buckeyes' fifth in Big Ten competition.

The governing heads of a score of African states gathered at the "summit" in Lagos, Nigeria, have joined Premier Adoula in a protest against the Soviet demand for a United Nations Security Council meeting, scheduled for today, to hear Moscow's latest complaints about events in the Congo.

Directors of Continental Air Lines and of National Airlines decided yesterday not to go through with their merger plans. After a seven-week "engagement," the lines an nounced they had been unable to "finalize a definitive merger agreement."
MOSCOW, Jan. 29--Dorothy Kirsten, the American soprano, made a hit tonight in "La Traviata" in Moscow's Bolshoi Theatre despite the technical problems of singing with a strange company.
ALBANY, Jan. 29--Governor Rockefeller was reported tonight to have chosen John J. Gilhooley of Brooklyn to fill a $30,000-ayear vacancy on the New York City Transit Authority.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 29--The United Nations announced tonight that it was informing President Moise Tshombe of Katanga that his request for a month's delay to oust mercenaries was "unacceptable."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29-- The State Department said today that the United States was now firmly convinced that the Soviet Union, despite all its "pious words to the contrary," did not want "an effective testban treaty now or at any time in the foreseeable future."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29-- Eligible to compete again with the lifting of his suspension by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., will be back in action within the next two weeks.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Jan. 30 (AP)--Huseyn S. Suhrawardy, a former Prime Minister of Pakistan, was reported to have been arrested at his residence early today.

Dr. William Duncan Strong of 452 Riverside Drive, Loubat Profesor of Archaeology at Columbia University, died yesterday at his country home at Kent Cliffs, N.Y., apparently of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.
Rather than face a court battle, the Dell Publishing Company has changed the title of its forthcoming book about President Kennedy's wartime exploits.

PLEIKU, Vietnam, Jan. 29-- Here in the western highlands of South Vietnam, the regime of President Ngo Dinh Diem and its Communist opponents are in a desperate race to win the loyalty of about a half million tribesmen.
ALGIERS, Jan. 29--An explosion today wrecked what was believed to be the headquarters of a French Government secret service unit combating outlawed European Rightists.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 29-- The congress of the Christian Democratic party continued debate today on the advisability of effecting an "opening to the Left." This would create a Center-Left government with the support of neutralists and the pro-Communist Left-wing Socialist party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--President Kennedy's statement at last week's news conference that even the highest civilian officials and military officers should circulate their proposed speeches through the Government for "guidance," as he did his State of the Union message.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29--Movie royalty, which owns so much valuable art, will be urged in the near future to invest in tax deductible classical music.

GENEVA, Jan. 29--The discussion by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union on a treaty to end nuclear weapons tests ended in failure today, The talks had been going on here for more than three years.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 (AP)--Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, listed four possible ways today for the United States to meet increasing economic competition from overseas.
LONDON, Jan. 29--Wildcat strikes by motormen on the London subway and on one of the city's suburban railroad lines caused traffic chaos here today.

LONDON, Jan. 29--Against a background of strikes, slowdowns and general industrial discontent, British politics has abandoned the decorous gymnasium fencing of the last decade for the cut and thrust of genuine political crisis.

Directors of the National Biscuit Company, at a meeting held here yesterday, proposed a two-for-one split in common shares of the company and increased the quarterly dividend payment to 75 cents a share from 70 cents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)--The Senate Armed Services Committee was told today that the Army plans a 67 per cent increase in spending to expand its chemical and biological warfare program to counter Communist advances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Kennedy told Congress today that the purchase of half the projected $200,000,000 United Nations bond issue by the United States was "vital to the interests of our country and the maintenance of peace."

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 30 (UPI)--A Federal grand jury indicted three former officials of the Sister Kenny Foundation and four advertising executives today on charges of mail fraud and conspiracy in polio fund drives.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 30--Sanford Jarrell, newspaperman and author, was found dead yesterday in his apartment here, apparently from the fumes of an unvented heater. He was 65 years old. Mr. Jarrell's son Pat was unconscious when a friend of the Jarrell's, Joe Wilde, entered the apartment. The son was taken to St. Mary's Hospital.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30 (AP)--A cotton merchant said today the United States must make trade agreements with foreign trade blocs.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30-- The state that has developed more men and women champions than any other of the union for the past half-century will have the honor of acting as host to the annual meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for the second time in the organization's eighty-one-year history.
A master plan for dealing with mental illness in New York State was announced to the Legislature yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to impose about $550,000,000 a year in new taxes on mutual savings institutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- What the Salvation Army is to the man on Skid Row, what the Travelers Aid Society is to the girl from the country, the Housing and Home Finance Agency is to the nation's mayors and house builders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--In their fight against President Kennedy's efforts to create a Federal Department of Urban Affairs, the Republicans have based their argument on very insecure political and historical grounds.
The appointment of Joseph G. Herzberg as cultural news director of The New York Times has been announced by Turner Catledge, managing editor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that underground testing of atomic weapons had proved to be slower, more difficult and more expensive than had been expected.
The American Stock Exchange was told yesterday that it should further tighten its minimum requirements for listing new stock issues.
JUDITH MISCHEL is a woman who enjoys getting ready for a party. She has made a business of it.
WASHINGTON, Jan 30--A $1,500,000,000 college-aid program won the approval of the House of Representatives today by a bipartisan vote of 319 to 79.

The Funk Wagnalls Company, publisher of dictionaries, encyclopedias and other hardcovered books, has moved its executive, sales and editorial offices to 360 Lexington Avenue, at Fortieth Street. The company had been at 153 East Twentyfourth Street.
LONDON, Jan. 30--The recent dribble of selling dried up today and a modest renewal of demand gave a cheerful tone to the stock market here.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 30--The doctrine of incompatibility, by which the conference of American foreign ministers here is judging Premier Fidel Castro's Cuba, is a new concept in inter-American political relations. It purports to reconcile policy of nonintervention with the presence...
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30-- The Pennsylvania Railroad obtained a Federal court injunction today barring a strike scheduled by the Transport Workers Union for 12:01 A.M. Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Pierre Salinger, the White House press secretary, accepted today an invitation to visit the Soviet Union early in the spring for informal talks about improving exchanges of news and information.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 30-- The leaders of twenty African states adjourned their meeting tonight after reaching agreement on the principle of creating a new Organization of African States.

Tentative approval by the House Ways and Means Committee of a plan for taxing savings and loan associations upset such shares on the stock market yesterday. Most other major groups on the New York Stock Exchange, however, pushed vigorously upward and the market closed with good gains.
Johnny Carson will succeed Jack Paar as host of the National Broadcasting Company's late night entertainment show in October, it was reliably reported here yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Proposals for the operation of the new state-wide Family Courts and for the administration of the unified state court system were announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--Following is the text of an Asian-African resolution on Angola adopted today by the General Assembly:

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 30 --About fifty students picketed on the campus of Southern University and Agriculture and Mechanical College today in an effort to muster support for a student boycott of classes.

The New York Rangers, who continue to win fans while losing games, made line-up changes yesterday that they hope will snap a ten-game National Hockey League losing string tonight. The Blues will meet Coach Phil Watson's Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.
A resolution was introduced in the City Council yesterday in a move toward freezing the Council's membership at thirtyfive--the present twenty-five plus the ten provided for under the new Charter.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, after three years of effort to run its credit card plan profitably, is selling the service to a new company, George Champion, the bank's chairman, told the stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.
Robert Mann, Leonid Hambro and Lucy Rowan make up, to put it mildly, an unusual sort of trio.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Senator Joseph S. Clark said today that John A. McCone should dispose of his oil stockholdings to avoid a conflict of interest in his job as director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
"CLOSE-UP!", the documentary series of the American Broadcasting Company, had an excellent installment last night, a study of the world-wide movement to ward unity among the Christian faiths.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Billy Bruton, a center fielder, and two players brought up from the minors signed their contracts today with the Detroit Tigers.

PARIS, Jan. 30--The very small collection of coats and suits shown by Andre Courr ges last season was an instant success. This former student of Balenciaga was one of the bright new hopes of the Paris couture and everyone has been curious to see what he would do in his second collection, always more difficult.

GENEVA, Jan. 30--Sir Michael Wright, British delegate at the defunct conference on a treaty to ban nuclear testing, described as "sinister" today the Soviet view that the test-ban question had no place in disarmament negotiations.

AT a recent gathering of the Midtown Turf, Yacht ing and Polo Association, an amorphous coterie of outdoor cranks, one of the less stable members described in impossible detail how worm and spin fishermen have sometimes made his life miserable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--The Atomic Energy Commission reported today progress in the nuclear-powered ship program.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 30 (UPI)--A Russian delegation appeared unexpectedly today for ceremonies observing the eightieth birthday anniversary of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Because the United States is such a wonderland for the consumer, it may now have become somewhat of a blunderland. That is the implication in a study just released by an industry group.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30--Alan Conneli, the winner of the national championship sports car race last Sunday, will return next week to compete in the Daytona threehour international contest on Feb. 11. He also has entered the Daytona 500-mile late model stock car race set for Feb. 18.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Wednesday, Jan. 31--Following is the text of a resolution approved by fourteen nations early today excluding Cuba from interAmerican affairs:
ALGIERS, Jan. 30--The French Army in Algeria is understood to have been alerted for a possible emergency within the next few days. All units are under orders to stay battleready.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 30-- A last-ditch appeal has been sent to Pierre Salinger, President Kennedy's press secretary, to save the Seventh Army's symphony orchestra, the only one of its kind in the United States armed forces.
A mother has sued the city for $1,000,000, charging that her 2-month-old daughter died of pneumonia the day after two city hospitals refused to admit the baby.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Kennedy chose a longtime Government lawyer today to be a judge of the United States Court of Claims. The White House announced that he would nominate Oscar H. Davis, First Assistant to the Solicitor General. Mr. Davis, who is 47 years old, has been in...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Treasury and the Federal Reserve System were major providers for the long-term money market last spring when corporations and state and local governments were borrowing heavily, the chairman of the Reserve System reported today.

Thousands of persons with impaired hearing will receive further aid from the proceeds of the sixth annual luncheon, which the Parents Association of the New York League for the Hard of Hearing will give at the Plaza on Feb. 6.

ONCE upon a time the guardians of the foot-racing record book viewed with a stubborn suspicion any athlete who came rocketing up from nowhere to splinter one of the sacred marks they protect with a jealous zeal. It wasn't that they objected to strangers. They were merely taking the stand that a record-breaker had to have a certain familiarity with the vicinity of the mark before he could be recognized as valid.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 30--A medical rescue team dropped onto the snow-swept Zagros Mountains today and found four of five United States airmen who had crashed in a small Army plane.
Sutro Bros. Co. and associates are offering today securities of the Realty Equities Corporation of New York consisting of debentures and common stock purchases warrants.
The election of M.R. Chambers as president of the International Shoe Company, the nation's leading producer of footwear, was announced yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 30-- Forces of the pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement pushed beyond the ridges overlooking Nam Tha in northwestern Laos today to a point within four miles of the town.
FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA., Jan. 30--The new queen of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference is Robin, a speedy, forty-five-foot yawl designed and skippered by Ted Hood of Marblehead, Mass.

BRANTFORD, Ont., Jan. 30 (Canadian Press)--Shareholders of Cockshutt Farm Equipment, Ltd., today approved the sale of the company's farm implement division to the White Motor Company of Cleveland for about $15,000,000.
One of several group gifts received by The New York Times Neediest Cases was a $5 check from the Westwood, N.J., Methodist Church Choir in memory of Edmund A. Oest.

EXETER, Pa., Jan. 30--A high official of the United Mine Workers Union and a bank cashier were freed under $25,000 bonds today on charges of embezzling nearly $400,000 from the First National Bank of Exeter.

"I don't think I have any hope," said a woman peace marcher yesterday through lips stiff with cold. "But I just heard that William the Silent said that it wasn't necessary to hope in order to act. You can act without hope. I think that I'm in that category."
"The Truth About Soviet Propaganda," by R.H. Shackford, chief European correspondent for the Scripps-Howard newspapers, is planned for spring publication by Public Affairs Press of Washington.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP) --Franz Schelle, a 32-year-old trucker, piloted the No. 1 German sled to the world four-man bobsled championship today in a two-heat competition.

Gigacycle computers can be a reality in a few years, experts said here yesterday.
Mayor Wagner was honored last night by the Lotos Club at a "state dinner" in recognition of his re-election to a third term.
LONDON, Jan. 30--Lloyd's Register of Shipping began an international search today for twenty-nine shipping registers that were published here between 1760 and 1833.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 30-- The sharpening differences on foreign policy in West Germany's Government were held up for public view today.
The Martin-Marietta Corporation last year cleared $44,500,000, or $2 a share, on sales of $1,230,000,000, George M. Bunker, president, reported yesterday.

La Nuit de France, a dinner and ball aboard the new French Line ship France on March 1 will benefit the Family and Child Service of Washington and L'Entr'Aide Francaise of New York. The liner will be at Pier 88 here.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 30--The Rev. Billy James Hargis exhorted a Right-Wing gathering today to work for conservative control of the House of Representatives this year.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--The Legislature's version of a completely revised Civil Practice Act ran into strong opposition at a public hearing today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)--Ralph Lowe's New Policy scored a victory by a nose today over T.V. Lark in the $27,550 Santa Catalina Handicap for California-foaled horses at Santa Anita. It was one of the closest finishes of the meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Gen. David M. Shoup, commandant of the Marine Corps, told a Senate panel today that combat training was much more valuable than the political indoctrination of troops.

PARIS, Jan. 30--One feature of the relative detente with Russia is a widening of direct contacts. The factual gap separating Washington from Moscow has not diminished. But the manner and scope of discussing it have changed.
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP)--Jackie Foley neared the Holy Cross scoring record tonight, contributing 30 points as the Crusaders routed Dartmouth, 92--61, for their ninth victory in a row.

AN exhibition of foreign picture books for children may be seen at the Children's Room of the Hudson Park Branch of the New York Public Library, 10 Seventh Avenue South. The exhibition focuses on children's classics that have been published in many languages over the years. The Children's Room is open from 3 to 6 P.M. Monday through Friday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) --The Justice Department has asked Robert H.W. Welch Jr., founder of the John Birch Society, to produce any evidence he has to support his charges of Communists in Government.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30-- Church historians of the future may look back on 1962 as a key year in the rapidly accelerating trend toward Christian unity.
From the depths of the National Basketball Association basement, the New York Knickerbockers reached up and tripped the galloping Philadelphia Warriors, 116--110, at Madison Square Garden last night.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)--The attempt to orbit the first United States astronaut was postponed to day until Feb. 13. The often-delayed flight had been scheduled for Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Government's two principal financial officers--the Secretary of the Treasury and the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board--revealed concern today for the renewed heavy flow of money out of the country in the closing months of last year.
THE avant-garde is way behind Jean Tardieu. He makes some members of the fraternity look about as baffling as a McGuffey reader.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 30-- Hofstra College's strong basketball team may become just a mite stronger at about 4 P. M. tomorrow when it begins using Jim Boatwright.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--The state acted on two fronts today to speed plans for rebuilding Albany's deteriorating downtown sector.

"An Evening in the Theatre with Basil Rathbone" will be held at the Parish House of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, 31 East Seventy-first Street, on Feb. 28 for the benefit of Elko Lake Camps in Parksville, N.Y., one of the seven services of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.
MOSCOW. ONE of the basic possessions of every Moscow housewife is a string bag called an "avoska." The name comes from the Russian word "avos," which means "perhaps" or "maybe."

Madison Avenue's biggest advertising agencies in recent months have been locked in a bitter competitive struggle to expand their operations overseas. Some agencies have established new offices abroad; some have acquired a financial interest in foreign agencies. But hardly a week goes by without word of some new invasion by an American agency.
United States Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon has fired a blast against consolidation proposals involving thirteen New York banking institutions, it was learned yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 30--Officials here think that the issue of peace or continued war in Algeria may be largely determined at a meeting of the rebel provisional Government in Tunis Thursday and Friday.
HOLLANDIA, West New Guinea, Jan. 30 (AP)--Objects of primitive art collected by Michael Rockefeller before he was lost off the southern coast of New Guinea are en route to New York for exhibition.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--Belgium today urged independence for Ruanda-Urundi by the middle of this year, and asked that the United Nations establish a "presence" there until that time.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Governor Rockefeller charged today that Mayor Wagner had made an increase in New York City transit fares almost inevitable.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30--The Soviet Union paid tribute today to President Franklin D. Roosevelt on the eightieth anniversary of his birth with a press memorial and a meeting of a Soviet-American friendship group.

Mrs. Griffith Baily Coale of 163 East Eighty-first Street and Stonington, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Griffith Manning Coale, to Richard Fenner Anderson Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson of Burlington, N.C. A spring wedding is planned.

The city's newest museum-- Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle--is still a year away from completion. The museum has been beset by delays; it was confidently expected to be admitting visitors in 1960, then in 1961, and then this year.
The United States Steel Corporation reported 1961 net income at the lowest level since strike-pitted 1952, on sales that were below those in every year back to 1954.

TO make guests feel welcome, most hostesses like to offer something to eat and drink fairly soon after the greetings are completed. When an elaborate dinner is planned, serving an appetizer in the living room also has the advantage of keeping guests occupied while the hostess applies the finishing touches to the meal.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP)--Sixty-five machinists who had been on strike since last August at the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company returned to work today. They were the first to report following settlement of the long dispute.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--New York City moved today to upset two Public Service Commission decisions that permitted the Consolidated Edison Company to add $26,000,000 in rate increases.

New York City has borrowed $60,000,000 in short-term funds from seventeen banks and trust companies, Controller Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday. The issue consisted of 2 per cent tax anticipation notes to be dated Feb. 1 and payable May 7.

RUDOLF SERKIN played a double-header last night with the Philadelphia Orchestra. He devoted himself to Mozart's last piano concerto--the B flat (K. 595)-- and Beethoven's No. 4 in G. The rest of the program was contemporary with Bartok's "Two Portraits" and the first New York performance of David Diamond's Seventh Symphony.

Control of the Fischer Baking Company, a leading independent producer of baked goods, has been transferred from members of the Fischer family to Bakery Enterprises, Inc., Carl F. Nitto, a Passaic, N.J., lawyer, announced yesterday.

DENNISON, Tex., Jan. 30-- An editing error that appeared in the first edition of The New York Times on Jan. 28 in a news article on the Texas Congressional election campaign became a political issue in the race today as the voters went to the polls. The error did not appear in later editions and an explanation and correction were printed the following day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Senator Mike Mansfield assured the Senate today that it would have a chance to act on the Adminstration's bill on voting rights within sixty to ninety days.

Gil Hodges, for all his heft and hidden muscles, is a baseball rarity: In fifteen and a fraction seasons with the Dodgers (Brooklyn and Los Angeles) he never had a fist fight and never was ejected from a game.
A 17-year-old youth was shot to death yesterday by his 16year-old high school companion with a .22-caliber revolver during horseplay in a Bronx apartment, the police reported.
"A Place Without Twilight" is to be introduced next season by Roger L. Stevens and Oliver Smith, the scenic designer who joins forces with Mr. Stevens occasionally in the managerial division.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Jan. 30 --Lorraine Gurka, 17-year-old editor of the yearbook at Newark's West Side High School, received her high school diploma tonight because her classmates didn't want to graduate without her.
There are indications of a "slight" revival in construction of new freighter tonnage throughout the world, chiefly in specialized types of ships, the American Bureau of Shipping reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--The Security Council adjourned a meeting today without deciding whether to place on its agenda a new Soviet complaint against the ... United Nations policy in the Congo.

Inactivity prevailed in the high-grade bond market yester- day except in the municipal section. The tax-exempt-interest bonds of local government were carried to higher values by the keen competition of syndicates to buy new issues. Among Treasury securities, discount rates on the shortdated bills fell slightly on the day, in the face of the implications of statements made in Washington by Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon before the House-Senate Joint Economic Committee.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 30 --Chilling memories of the Nineteen Thirties are evoked in the buff brick buidling at 147 North Avenue here.

The city's uniformed firemen served notice on Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate yesterday that they wanted at least $27,000,000 in pay increases for the fiscal... year starting July 1. Gerald J. Ryan, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, announced that the firemen also would seek improved working conditions.

IN the past, the story of Mary, the Queen of the Scots who intrigued for the throne of Elizabeth of England during the sixteenth century, has fascinated such writers as Schiller, Swinburne and, in recent times, the late Maxwell Anderson. Each has drawn his own special portrait of the redoubtable Scottish monarch and each has drawn his own conclusion of the events that led to the tragedy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Cook County, bearing a heavy relief load, advised unskilled workers from other areas today to stay away from Chicago.
Twelve films by Roberto Rossellini, including four not previously shown in America, will be presented in a two-month series starting Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Kennedy sent to Congress today a plan to reorganize the Housing and Home Finance Agency as a Department of Urban Affairs and Housing, with Cabinet rank.

IT is thirty-three years now since the publication of Richard Hughes' "A High Wind in Jamaica," that extraordinary novel about the innocent cruelty of children. Few novels of its time are so well remembered. People recall it with pleasure and admiration; but they also recognize the force of its psychological revelation.

The first phase of the Senate hearings about the "muzzling" of military officers has emphasized the obvious: (a) a system of coordinating and reviewing the public statements of military officials is essential; (b) the past and present system requires some revision.
The Public Schools Athletic League's temporary championship football play-off system received an endorsement yesterday in the form of a recommendation that it be continued indefinitely.

The Russian Orthodox Theological Fund, Inc., will benefit from a cocktail reception, to be held at the Carnegie Endowment International Center Building, 345 East Forty-sixth Street, Sunday evening. The event is under the honorary patronage of Princess Ileana of Rumania.
New top officers of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company were announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Mayor Wagner's proposal for the legalization of off-track betting received its perennial rejection by the Legislature today.

The Foreign Credit Insurance Association, a partnership between the Federal Government and fifty-seven private insurers, will begin issuing commercial and political risk policies to United States exporters on Monday, it was reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 30--Maj. Gen. Sir Rohan Delacombe, the British commandant in Berlin, called on his Soviet counterpart in East Berlin today with a Western proposal to restore freedom of movement throughout the city for the commands of the four powers here.
AT a tournament played at Baltimore last week-end, Alfred Sheinwold heard about, but did not play, the deal shown today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) --A transportation consultant representing Philadelphia urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve Northeast Airlines' application to serve Florida on a permanent basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (UPI)--Joey Giardello, 164 pounds, Philadelphia, avenged a previous defeat by Henry Hank tonight by winning an unpopular, majority decision over the Detroit middleweight in a ten-round bout at Convention Hall.
A bright blue bus designed for handicapped patients arrived yesterday at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University Medical Center, 400 East 34th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) --Senator Roman L. Hruska, Republican of Nebraska, angry and thumping a table, accused Senate drug investigators today of concocting "deviltry" in suggesting that some advertisements for prescription drugs were designed to delude physicians.

The Port of New York Authority and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York filed treble damage suits yesterday in Federal Court against manufacturers of electrical equipment, Charging antitrust violations involving price fixing.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported yesterday for 1961 a consolidated net income of $153,837,000, or $4.30 each on the average of 35,772,365 shares outstanding during the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A talking horse and a Western program decisively outpointed the Federal Communications Commission in television ratings, the agency learned today.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP)-- There is no chance that East German hockey players and skiers will get visas to compete in world championships in the United States and France, authoritative Allied sources said tonight.
A new foundation dedicated to the fight against Parkinson's disease was announced here yesterday. It will be financed through a $1,000,000 fund campaign to open in April.

A thirty-five-foot house trailer will soon become a ticket office and waiting room for the Long Island Rail Road in the north Queens community of Douglaston.

Stockholders of the Mercantile Stores Company approved a proposed two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday at a meeting in Wilmington, Del. The new shares will be distributed on Feb. 15 to holders of record of Feb. 6.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30--Sir Patrick Dean of Britain, current president of the Security Council, today announced a meeting Thursday to consider Pakistan's complaint against India on Kashmir. The United States chief representative, Adlai E. Stevenson, will preside as president of the Council for February.

LONDON, Jan. 30--The Government rejected today demands that it institute a public inquiry into the proposed merger of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., and Courtaulds, Ltd.
