Just when it seemed that the Williams College Carnival was going to run into a snow shortage, along came a storm last Tuesday that left four inches of powder and eased the pressure.
An increase of 4,227,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- More than 500 Young Republicans swarmed through the meeting halls of a motor hotel here today, seeking how to be good politicians.
NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 31 (AP) --Premier Amintore Fanfani's ruling Christian Democratic party approved tonight a parliamentary alliance with the Leftist Socialist party.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Administration's contacts with high Soviet officials were described by President Kennedy today as useful, but he cautioned that the East-West ...
LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)--It just isn't cricket to picket in cricket, old boy.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 31 (AP)--The Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered cargo-passenger ship, put out to sea today on her maiden voyage.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31--A Yugoslav newspaper reported from Moscow today that the Soviet Communist party was united on the necessity for de-Stalinization. Internal disputes involve only the speed with which the policy agreed on at the party congress last fall will be put into effect" it said.
Steuart L. Pittman, Assistant Secretary of Defense, urged yesterday a shift in emphasis in industrial preparedness toward saving lives in the event of a nuclear attack.

ALTHOUGH Laurance Spelman Rockefeller is prom inent in space-age industries, he takes particular pride in the old-fashioned title of "conservationist." His abiding concern with the preservation of our natural treasures was elequently expressed in the program submitted yesterday ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- President Kennedy said today he did not foresee new controls over television programs by the Government.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., Jan. 31 --The standard pattern of education in the conventional American school is a failure, a Harvard educator declared here today.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 31--William Hard, a roving editor of The Reader's Digest since 1940, a pioneer radio news commentator and a freelance writer, died yesterday of a stroke at his home here at 211 Park Street. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)--Senate drug investigators said today a New York advertising agency had softened warnings about drugs that might cause blood disorders and certain male characteristics in female babies.

EAST PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 31 (AP)--Directors of the Caterpillar Tractor Company today elected Harmon S. Eberhard chairman and William Blackie president. Mr. Eberhard had been president and Mr. Blackie, an executive vice president.

Nearly every New York street has the magic of familiar things for somebody. stranger who finds West Eighteenth Street much like West Nineteenth Street. Each thoroughfare manages a certain individuality that is felt ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- President Kennedy proposed to Congress today the toughest control program yet devised in an effort to cure chronic surplus production and other economic ills of American agriculture.

New York University yesterday denied a charge that it practiced "apparent systematic discrimination" in its off-campus housing. Dr. James M. Hester, president of the university, said that since its founding in 1831 the institution "has been a leader in non-discriminatory practices."
NEW JERSEY held its controversial one-day, either sex deer season Wednesday and preliminary reports indicated that it came out just about as expected by officials.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 1 --Miss Jewelle Ann Wooten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Allen Wooten of New York, was married here this evening to Nathaniel Judson Bickford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Conde Bickford of Ardsley-on-Hudson.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Operators of small driving schools clashed with large-school owners today over proposed state regulations calling for higher license fees and tighter supervision over their activities.

WITH a warning that machines are taking over everywhere, "New Faces of 1962" introduces itself as possibly the last all-people revue. The prospect may be dire, people, but don't grieve. The machines couldn't do much worse.
Most commodity futures declined or made only modest gains in quiet trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. The exception was world sugar, which advanced for the third day in a row.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 --A shake-up of producers has been approved by top officials of Twentieth Century-Fox. How soon the shake-up will go into effect could not be learned.

Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation will start construction in May on a $30,000,000 iron ore mining and pelletizing complex in Eastern Ontario, Charles M. Beeghly, president, announced yesterday in Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall has warned that "this is the moment of decision in resource conservation."
The United States Treasury gold stock declined by $25,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1--Maj. John W. Hession, a world rifle champion, died today in Clearwater, Fla. He was 84 years old and formerly lived in Orange, a community near here.
ATHENS, Feb. 1--A large number of brilliantly painted vases, dug up last summer by archaeologists on the island of Crete, now enrich the famed collection of antiquities of Knossos.

SAINT GERVAIS, France, Feb. 1 (UPI)--Madeleine Bochatay, an 18-year-old girl, snapped Austria's domination of women's skiing today by winning the giant slalom opener in the world championship dress rehearsals.

Paul C. Grening, a retired lieutenant commander in the Navy who was given a ticker tape parade up Broadway for his part in a sea rescue on Oct. 20, 1925, died Wednesday in the Kingsbridge Veterans Administration Hospital, the Bronx. He was 81 years old and lived at 205 Prescott Avenue, Grant City, S.I.

"No Strings" has finally extricated itself from a difficult situation. Faced with the possibility of being prevented from opening at the Mark Hellinger on March 1, for which it had signed contracts, the Richard Rodgers-Samuel Taylor musical will open at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre on March 15.
A clerical workers' union and American Export Lines agreed on a new three-year contract last night, ending a labor dispute that earlier in the day had delayed the sailing of the liner Independence.

THE midwinter illnesses that beset children create a strain in many households. At first the young patient is often too sick to be bored and cranky. The trouble comes during convalescence, when he wants to run before he can walk.
RENO, Nev., Feb. 1--Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller arrived in Reno today with a lawyer who had driven her from San Francisco.
HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 1 (AP) --E.E. Townes, a founder of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, died yesterday at the age of 83.
Electrocardiograms of the hearts of babies, made before they are born, can shed new light upon the development of congenital heart malformations, it was suggested here yesterday.

Julio Bolbochan of Argentina won two adjourned games in the interzonal chess tournament at Stockholm, according to a report from Sweden yesterday, and tied Dr. Miroslav Filip of Czechoslovakia for first place. Both have scores of 3 -- .

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Since this is the season of the new ladies' fashions, let it be noticed that there are new fashions in diplomacy and politics too. As a matter of fact, society and diplomacy have got so mixed up in Washington that it's hard to tell who's ahead in the cold war without reading the women's pages.
Dr. Harold Taylor, former president of Sarah Lawrence College, last night challenged the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. to play "a crucial role" in the racial problems of the South.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Mayor Wagner of New York moved here today to thwart an effort by Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey to have a defense contract shifted from Brooklyn to Hoboken.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1-- Pennsylvania's efforts to require Bible-reading in public schools were set back again today by a Federal court here.
Angolan rebels have established a rudimentary government near the Congo border, two Americans reported yesterday after spending eleven days last month in rebel-held territory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The special Senate Preparedness subcommittee rejected today a move by the Secretary of Defense to shield the identity of individual speech censors at the Pentagon without invoking the Executive privilege.

BOSTON, Feb. 1--The national figure-skating championships opened today with a dual purpose. Primarily the four-day tests will fill the senior ranks left vacant a year ago when eighteen of the nation's top competitors in men's and women's ranks died in a plane crash.

Business leaders were called on yesterday to refuse to accept "the theory that a nuclear war is inevitable and to work with all our will, strength and energies to make sure such a war never comes about."

A flock of paper cranes hovered over several hundred guests who gathered in the grand ballroom of the Pierre last night for the twenty-third annual White Elephant Party of the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1-- Lit Brothers has acquired the four branch stores and four tire stores of another Philadelphia department store, Snellenburgs, Inc.
All across this land this evening thousands of Republicans, in great gatherings, are thinking earnestly about our party--something about its past and present, but more, I suppose, about its future.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- President Kennedy asked Congress today for a broad program of welfare reforms to relieve "poverty that persists in the midst of abundance."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The battle over private vs. public ownership of patents was joined on Capitol Hill today, with the Justice Department favoring initial Government ownership of inventions arising from Federally sponsored research.
MIAMI, Feb. 1--The famed Bacardi Cup series for Star Class sailboats, last held in 1957 at Havana, will be resumed by a twenty-one-boat fleet at 10 A.M. tomorrow in Biscayne Bay.

MIAMI, Feb. 1--A consecutive triple by Bob Ussery was the most exciting accomplishment at Hialeah today. The hustling rider from bustling Vian, Okla., came through with a $49.80-for-$2 victory with Mrs. Clark Hardwick's Big Art in the sixth race.

Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, in a preliminary annual report for 1961 released yesterday, showed consolidated net income of $27,661,225, or $4.04 a share. This compared with $21,732,560, or $3.16 a share, in 1960.
A short but well-planned program of lovely pieces was offered by Irma Rogell at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. This was the Boston harpsichordist's second New York appearance.

It is time to take the wraps off State Department records of our relations with China during the controversial period from 1942 to 1949, the period that encompasses the Communist takeover of the China mainland. Contrary to normal procedures, the department has not made public its files for this period.
BOSTON, Feb, 1 (UPI)-- The New York Rangers rallied for three goals in the final period tonight to score a 5-3 victory over the Bruins and regain fourth place in the National Hockey League.
A shift of a bus stop caused problems in the municipal family yesterday.
Two school districts in New York State raised funds in the bond market yesterday. Tonawanda, N.Y., Union Free School District 1 borrowed $5,455,000 on serial obligations due from 1962 to 1981.

For a time yesterday stocks gave an uncertain performance, hesitating for more than three hours after a strong opening. At the close, however, they pushed ahead vigorously and for the fifth successive year the month of February began with a gain for the New York Stock Exchange list.

PARIS, Feb. 1--Thirty-two tanks will be deployed in the Paris region by the end of the week to help assure the capital's security against the terrorist activities of the clandestine Secret Army Organization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Two committees of Congress moved today to investigate the Government's stockpiling operations.
The report of the Outdoor Recreation Resources Review Commission well states the problem posed by America's exploding urban population in its impact on the diminishing open spaces of our country.

PARIS. IN France, a restaurateur's most important possession, aside from his chef, is his star. If he has one, he counts himself among the fortunate. If he has two or three, his position in the restaurant world and in French society in general is assured.

The Hamilton Watch Company reduced its quarterly dividend yesterday to 15 cents from 25 cents in previous quarters. Payment will be made March 15 to holders of record of Feb. 23. The company also announced ...
A charge that the "extreme right" was moving to take control of the New York Young Republican Club added fuel yesterday to a heated club election campaign.
ALGIERS, Feb. 1--A powerful bomb explosion destroyed the center of a state radio communications network in Algiers tonight and cut off administrative units in Algiers from Paris and from one another.

QUANGNGAI, Vietnam, Jan. 31--American DDT spray killed the cats that ate the rats that devoured the crops that were the main props against Communist agitation in the central lowlands. The result: the hungry, embittered rural population is tending to support the Communist insurgents.

For those who missed the recent National Motor Boat Show in the New York Coliseum some consolation "prizes" should be compensatory. Hardly an area in the nation exists that doesn't have a boat, sports or vacation show. Close to New York at least ...

The Apache Corporation has expanded its diversified operations into the utility field by completion of the purchase of the Upper Midwest Telephone Company, it was announced yesterday. Terms were not revealed.

WANAQUE, N.J., Feb. 1--A suit for damages has been filed against eight mothers on the ground that their baby-carriage picketing intimidated construction workers and kept them from their jobs on a new apartment house.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI)--Stan Leonard of Canada took the second-round lead today in the 90-hole Palm Springs Golf Classic, but Arnold Palmer became the favorite.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 1--The ruling Christian Democratic party turned to the Left today. The party congress in session here voted by a four-to-one majority for a parliamentary alliance with Pietro Nenni's Left-Wing Socialists.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 1--Judge John J. Mahon of the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court died in Marymount Hospital yesterday of cancer and a kidney ailment. He was 71 years old.
GOOD Lord! Doesn't anyone ever have a joyful experience with the airlines? Probably, contented passengers have no impulse to write.
Miss Damaris Smith and John Rogers Horan plan to be married this May.

Net income of American Metal Climax, Inc., fell 11 per cent last year, the company reported yesterday. The decline reflected reduced earnings from copper, lead and zinc sales as a result of lower prices and stiffer competition in raw material markets.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., expects this year to raise some $343,000,000 of new money. Charles B. Delafield, financial vice president, said yesterday that of the total about $82,000,000 would come from internal sources, with around $262,000,000 to be raised by financing. All three figures are approximate.

Sales and earnings of Burling ton Industries, Inc., for the present fiscal quarter should be close to the record results of the first quarter ended Dec. 30, the company's annual meeting was told yesterday in Wilmington, Del.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--About two years ago Bernard M. Baruch, watching Government activities from one of his eyries, fixed his eagle gaze on what appeared to him to be the excessive growth and imbalance of the national stockpiles of strategic materials and farm commodities.

THIS week-end presages the beginning of the Chinese New Year. In terms of food, however, it augurs little new. Vegetables are still generally expensive and best buys in fruit continue to be limited to apples and citrus fruits. Meat prices are unchanged, with the lone exception of pork; loin pork roasts rose 4 cents to 69 cents a pound this week-end.

With most of the North Country covered with a new mantle of white, recreational skiers were preparing yesterday to make another invasion this week-end of the Catskills, Adirondacks Poconos, Laurentians and the Green and White Mountains.

Few nations do more than the United States to assist their least fortunate citizens --to make certain that no child, no elderly or handicapped citizen, no family in any circumstances in any state, is left without the essential needs for a decent and healthy existence.

Track and field will make its 1962 bow in Madison Square Garden tonight. In the first of five major local meets, distinguished fields of internationalists will run, hurdle, jump, vault and throw in the varied programs of the fifty-fifth annual Millrose Games.

Record sales in the fourth quarter and the year 1961 were reported yesterday by the Union Carbide Corporation. Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer, in a preliminary annual report said, however, that earnings were 10 per cent below those in 1960.

Sales of mortgages by the Federal National Mortgage Association to savings institutions and other long-term investors rose to a record of $521,999,000 last year, J. Stanley Baughman, president, reported yesterday. In contrast, purchases by the agency fell sharply to $624,930,000.

The troubled relations between the business man and the intellectual--a subject that has attracted considerable discussion on Madison Avenue of late-- were analyzed yesterday by the head of one of the nation's largest public relations concerns.

American editions of two books with Australian backgrounds will be issued this month. One is "Four Against the River," by Nancy Polishuk. It is an account of how she, her American husband and their two children attempted to establish a homestead on the bank of the Daly River in Northern Australia amid the aborigines, the Kangaroos and the cockatoos, as well as crocodiles and sharks. Dutton will publish it next Wednesday.
Changes in state housing laws to put limited-profit cooperatives within the reach of many more middle-income families were urged yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

The Real Estate Board of New York announced yesterday that its award for the most ingenious realty transaction of 1961 had been won by Peter Grimm, chairman of William A. White Sons, and Mandel E. Cohen, a salesman for that company. The winners received scrolls at the board's annual dinner last night at the Commodore Hotel.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's rejection of the city's $326,000,000 fiscal program for 1962-63 was "cockeyed."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1-- Strong opposition is building up to prevent the United States Lawn Tennis Association from taking a favorable position, in principle or in fact, to the holding of open tournaments. The association is holding its eightyfirst annual meeting.

THE proudest families in the Pennsylvania coal-mining town of Minooka were the O'Neills and the McNallys. They had boys who had escaped from the pits to the big leagues. If the O'Neills were a mite prouder than the McNallys, numbers did it. Four O'Neill sons made it in the big time but only one McNally.

THE deal shown today is from a tournament in Westchester County. The declarer, Angelo Zuccaro, made his contract of four spades although there seemed to be four sure trump tricks against him. Mr. Zuccaro's partner was Benedict Leerburger.
More than 700 housewives and mothers demonstrated in the United Nations Plaza yesterday as part of a week of protests against the atomic bomb.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 1-- Noah T. Barnes, Corporation Counsel here since 1956, died last night at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown. He had become ill Tuesday in his home at 135 Croton Avenue. His age was 56.
LONDON, Feb. 1--Prices moved irregularly in the stock market here today in a quiet session. Most industrial sections remained firm, however, with net changes generally no more than a few pence.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (UPI)-- The Earl of Snowdon went to work for pay today for the first time since his marriage to Princess Margaret. He put in an eight-hour day as artistic adviser to The Sunday Times.
Thirty-five major concerns in the direct mail industry were closed yesterday morning by a strike of 2,000 office employes.
The appointment of Arjay R. Miller to the new post of vice president-staff group of the Ford Motor Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Miller will report directly to Henry Ford 2d, chairman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, and an advertising executive clashed today over a booklet on the treatment of eye disorders.

More than 100 programs will be broadcast by WNYC, the Municipal Broadcasting System, during its twenty-third annual American Music Festival, which runs traditionally from Lincoln's Birthday to Washington's Birthday, Feb. 12 to 22.

PARIS, Feb. 1--Cristobal Balenciaga's collection this morning was praised by store buyers as absolutely beautiful. When questioned by fashion reporters, who are barred for another month, the buyers could not decide whether it was better than Givenchy's rare collection yesterday.
The conviction of an Air France stewardess on charges of smuggling heroin into this country by concealing it on her person was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) --The chairman of a special House committee investigating American trade with Communist countries said today that the Kennedy Administration had refused to let the committee examine Commerce Department files.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1-- Carey Wilson, retired motion picture producer and writer who was producer of the Andy Hardy and Dr. Kildare film series, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 73 years old.
The American Jewish Congress has withdrawn as a beneficiary of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York and will conduct its own fund drive here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy asked Congress today to permit limited wiretapping by state and Federal officers. His proposals would outlaw private wiretapping and place new and tougher restrictions on such activities by state and local authorities.
A tireless bunch of ball thieves beat a sharp ad lib expert and four other players dedicated to syncopated togetherness at Madison Square Garden last night.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 1--Cuba is expected in March to announce the formal establishment of a collective leadership for a new Marxist-Leninist party.
BERLIN, Feb. 1--The East German Government said today that West Berliners had built a tunnel system underneath an elevated railway line at the intracity border.

Bob Miller is a young man who figures prominently in the pitching plans of the infant New York Mets. On the unqualified recommendation of Solly Hemus, who once managed and now will coach him, Miller was acquired from the Cardinals for $125,000. He was one of four premium picks the Mets made in the special National League draft at Cincinnati last October.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) --The United States must take immediate action to prepare a second haven--perhaps in New Orleans--for political refugees fleeing Cuba, according to a Senate subcommittee staff report.
Two independent Democrats have rejected appeals by Mayor Wagner to withdraw from the four-man race in the special Queens Congressional election on Feb. 20.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, the 71year-old former Foreign Minister who has been sidetracked and disgraced by his party, suffered a heart attack about ten days ago and is in a hospital, informed sources reported today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 2 (UPI)--The annual Tuskegee Institute report on race relations, issued today, said that under President Kennedy the Federal Government had taken the lead as never before in promoting civil rights.
Dannie N. Heineman, electrical engineer, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 89.
LONDON, Feb. 1--Formal discussions on a new constitution providing full independence for Jamaica began here today.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 1-- The intense Soviet diplomatic activity here to bring about direct talks between Moscow and Bonn has entered a new phase involving the United States.
TRENTON, Feb. 1--Gov. Richard J. Hughes sharply rebuked various shipping and labor officials today for denying that a proposed $12,000,000 pier is at issue in waterfront legislation here.
Chief Justice Earl Warren warned the country last night not to let itself become a "garrison state" in which individual freedom might be sacrificed to "coldwar" needs.

The domestic price of lead dropped yesterday by onequarter of a cent, to 9 cents a pound, the lowest level since 1946. The reduction, led by a major custom smelter, was quickly followed by other large producers and smelters. Lead had been selling in New York at 10 cents a pound since Jan. 5.
ALBANY, Ga., Feb. 1--A shutdown of bus service today threatened this city with a renewal of last December's racial crisis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Secretary of State Dean Rusk got a hero's welcome at the White House today when he returned and reported a "great success" against Cuba in the Organization of American States.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP)--Seven persons, including members of the Police and Sheriff's Department, were accused today of attempting to frame a state police investigator and a former assistant district attorney in a vice inquiry.
In a move to meet a growing shortage or qualified engineering teachers the Ford Foundation has set up an $8,000,000 program to prepare doctoral engineering students for teaching careers.

NEWARK, Feb. 1--Three men, including a New Jersey beer distributor and an officer of a teamster union local, have been indicted here by a Federal grand jury on a charge of conspiracy under the TaftHartley Act.

THE twilight descended on the gods for the last time last night when the Metropolitan Opera completed its allotment of "Ring" performances for the season. Fittingly enough, the end came with "Goetterdaemmerung."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Treasury, with its head bumping against the national debt ceiling, announced plans today for an offering of two new issues of Government securities in exchange for almost $12,000,000,000 of issues coming due.

Today's new film is "Sail A Crooked Ship," a Columbia Pictures comedy, at the Criterion second Street Playhouse, between First and Second between First and Second Avedu Maurier short novel and nues. Robert Wagner, Dolores Hart, Carolyn Jones, Frankie Avalon and the late Ernie Kovacs have the leading roles. Irving Brecher directed and Philip Barry produced, from a scenario by Ruth Brooks Flippen and Bruce Geller.

Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, declared last night that the reactionary Right and the radical Left constituted "the most dangerous enemies of peaceful change."
Music masters, performers, patrons and music lovers paid a last tribute yesterday morning to Fritz Kreisler, violinist and composer, who died last Monday. He would have been 87 years old today.

The appeal of James Patrick Gilligan and Albert Will, partners in Gilligan, Will Co., from their suspensions as trading specialists on the American Stock Exchange will be heard by the Exchange's board of governors next Tuesday, Feb. 6.

DALLAS, Feb. 1 (UPI)--Six radio stations in four states started rebroadcasting hourly newscasts from the Moscow radio today. The project is designed to enable Americans to hear the "unrelenting stream of lies and invective" that Russian broadcasters direct against them.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--A witness told Assembly investigators at the opening of public hearings today that he had thought nothing "dishonest" would result from Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino's connection with a fall-out shelter concern.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 (UPI)-- Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks scored four goals in the final two periods tonight in a 7-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

WASHINGTON, Feb.1--Precautions by the National Broadcasting Company to avoid presenting objectionable material on television were described today by Carl Watson, director of broadcast standards, during a Federal Communications Commission inquiry into program practices.

ENCHASS, U.A.R., Jan. 29 --Ahmed Abdul Hamid is one of President Gamal Abdel Nassen's "new Egyptians." He is 35 years old, is married and has two children who attend the modern elementary school in Enchass.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., Feb. 1 --A state-wide survey of public elementary and secondary schools has revealed a major advance in special programs for the gifted in the last four years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Freight volumes last week were markedly higher than in the 1961 period, the railroad and trucking inudustries reported today.

Copper men have opened a fight to regain a market lost years ago because of World War II shortages of the metal. They want to persuade iron foundries to resume the practice of adding copper in quantity to their gray iron castings.
WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 1 --This town's dog warden thinks he leads a dog's life and has submitted a report to the Board of Selectmen to prove it.
Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), at a meeting held here yesterday, declared a quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share, payable on March 12, to stock or record of Feb. 13.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1-- Nominal Christians who fail to practice their faith while subscribing to its principles must share responsibility for the growth of communism, according to a new church "handbook on communism."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a series of proposals designed to collect more taxes from United States corporations for their foreign income.
LONDON, Feb. 1--Britain's commercial television network reported today that comparable self-supporting systems abroad spend nearly twice as much time as it does on advertisements.

Aided by good weather, sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area last month rose 12 per cent above the January, 1961, level. This was indicated by a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

ALTHOUGH their names will never appear on the so called best-dressed lists, there are scores of elegant young women all over New York who have a strong, personal sense of fashion and dress in a manner that fits their lives and their budgets.
Carlton Fredericks, a writer and lecturer on nutrition, declared in a statement last night that charges made by the Government against him on Wednesday constituted a "threat ...
Cotton futures were 5 points up to 3 points off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The fourteen-story Wickersham Building at 133 East Fifty-eighth Street, on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue has been bought by Peter I. Feinberg, real estate investor. The structure contains a hospital, professional offices and stores.

National Boxing Association rules--like records--apparently are made to be broken. Prizefighters account for most of the breakage, but yesterday there were strong indications that the N.B.A. itself was about to get into the act.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --A former foreign-aid official and two business men were indicted today on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government on construction contracts in Laos.
The tax-exempt interest bonds of municipal and state governing bodies continued in brisk demand yesterday at the hands of commercial banks refashioning investment portfolios.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--The Board of Regents made public today its recommendations for further permanent changes in the New York City school system.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 484 persons who passed the examination for admission to the New York State Bar. The test, given early last December, was taken by 772 persons.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 1 --Officials at all-Negro Southern University and Agricultural and Mechanical College moved today to break the student antisegregation boycott.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (UPI)-- If the East German skiers are not granted travel documents to enter France for the world Alpine championships at Chamonix, the event should be called off, a poll of officials by United Press International disclosed today.

The General Tire and Rubber Company had record sales for the eleventh consecutive year and the largest earnings in its history in 1961, according to the report yesterday of T.F. O'Neil, chairman, and M.G. O'Neil, president.

This is a year of utmost importance for improvement of the judicial system in New York State. It is also a year reviving the hope, so long disappointed, of enlarging substantially the number of judgeships so that the courts in the metropolitan area can get abreast of their business and end the intolerable delay that frustrates justice.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The defense ministers of the Warsaw Pact ended today a three-day meeting devoted to "strengthening" their combined armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --The Senate Republican Conference approved today the assignments of Senator Norris Cotton of New Hampshire and Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey to party vacancies on the Senate Appropriations Committee.
The country's biggest commercial vessel arrived here yesterday on her first voyage, carrying the heaviest cargo ever delivered to the Port of New York.

Biology is undergoing a revolution whose meaning and magnitude have become apparent only in recent weeks. The pace has been so swift, in fact, that many scientists do not fully appreciate the potential of the powder keg they are sitting on.
The evening performance of the Old Vic Company's production of "Macbeth" at the New York City Center on Wednesday has been chosen by the Harvard Law School Association for its annual theatre benefit.
Business loans at major New York City banks increased during the week ended Wednesday for the first weekly gain this year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Dwight D. Eisenhower warned Republicans today to overhaul the party's organization and get rid of incompetents if they hope to win in this year's Congressional and state elections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) --The United States expects to step up its economic aid to the Congo and President Kennedy probably will discuss this with Premier Cyrille Adoula here Monday, officials said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)--A late burst of buying rallied wheat futures prices on the Board of Trade today and recovered nearly all the losses of the two preceding sessions. Gains ran to more than a cent a bushel on the old-crop months and to major fractions on the new.
LONDON, Feb., 1--A lively dispute has erupted between the Labor party and The Daily Herald, supposedly its chief press supporter.

DOVER, N.J., Feb. 1-- Howard S. Deck, a civil engineer and former designer of explosives plants for the War Department, died Monday at Dover General Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 26 Central Avenue.
The public's attitudes about television will be examined on telecasts to be presented tonight and tomorrow afternoon by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

From time to time pitchers who could sing--and more infrequently singers who could pitch--have bobbed up in baseball. There were, for example, Al Mamaux and Ralph Branca, who could hit high C or croon a tune almost as easily as they delivered a high hard one to the plate.
What may be the first effective drug treatment for a true virus disease was reported here yesterday at an international symposium on virus research.
Madison Avenue is dotted with consulting concerns specializing in every conceivable aspect of the communications business. There is even one, in fact, that specializes in thinking.

The policies of the United Nations and our relations to the U.N. came under the Senatorial microscope today--and quite properly so--as Secretary of State Rusk presents to the Foreign Relations Committee President Kennedy's argument for buying half of the U.N.'s $200 million emergency bond issue.

ANOTHER chapter in a fashion success story is now being written at 327 East Fiftyfifth Street. This is the site of the Maria Pia Boutique, the newest venture of a shy, retiring Itailan woman, Maria Pia Costantine, and her husband, Carmen.

Mayor Wagner and other top Democrats in the city will be stumping intensively in Queens for the next two weeks in a campaign to elect Benjamin S. Rosenthal to the House of Representatives in a special election Feb. 20 in the Sixth District.
Mayor Wagner served notice yesterday that he would not tolerate any deals for bipartisan nominations for places on the Supreme Court.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 5--Francisco Jose Orlich Bolmarcich has been elected President of Costa Rica for the 196266 term. He will take office in May.
The American Tobacco Company, one of the major domestic tobacco producers, registered the highest sales and earnings in its history last year, Paul M. Hahn, president, disclosed yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--A new and final attempt to persuade Michael H. Prendergast to retire voluntarily as Democratic state chairman was decided upon at a meeting here today.

Variously described by journalistic observers as the greatest thing to come out of Detroit since the self-starter and as the hottest political property to arrive on the Republican scene in years, George Romney makes up his mind this week whether to run for Governor of Michigan. He is generally expected to say yes, and even before he does so is being referred to as a Republican Presidential possibility for 1964.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)--Reflections from the moon and other difficulties caused the United States missile-spotting radar in Greenland to turn in numerous false warnings over a period of five months.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP)-- A fast-breaking rally canceled numerous small losses in grain futures prices today and lifted the market to a generally strong range on the Board of Trade.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--Republican and Democratic legislative leaders reached agreement tonight on a rent control bill that may neutralize rent control as a political issue this year.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 5 --Dr. Kendall Emerson Sr., managing director of the National Tuberculosis Association from 1928 to 1947, died today at his home here. He was 86 years old.
Prices fluctuated in a narrow range on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and ended up a little for the day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The White House will not intervene in the Army's decision to let the Seventh Army Symphony Orchestra die.

ROME, Feb. 5--Gaetano Cardinal Cicognani died today of a circulatory failure in his home outside the Vatican. He was 80 years old and was the elder brother of Amleto Cardinal Cicognani, Apostolic Secretary of State and former Apostolic Delegate to the United States.
FOR Val Coleman the theatre begins and ends in words. He has assembled a mess of them, ranging from purple to raw, in "The Jackhammer," but they make neither sense nor a play.
OFF Broadway has come up with a provocative and exhilarating musical--about segregation. It is called "Fly Blackbird" and it opened at the Mayfair Theatre last night.

RANK SULLIVAN once described Don Marquis' office as "an oasis of disorder." Wisely--and, I imagine, help lessly--Edward Anthony has made his bulging biography, "O Rare Don Marquis,"* just such a refreshing landscape of tumult.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 5--Under Secretary Andrew W. Cordier will leave his United Nations post at the end of the present session to become dean of the Graduate School of International Affairs at Columbia University.
PARIS, Feb. 5--President de Gaulle expressed hope tonight for a settlement of the Algerian problem "very soon" on the basis of Algerian independence in friendly cooperation with France.

Rodney Laver of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, and Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., this country's No. 1 amateur player, were top-seeded yesterday for the national indoor championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
AUTHENTIC woodsmen are great tea drinkers. Perhaps the slogan, "Take tea and see," explains why they often have such superb vision, although I've met some who claim potions of a different kind do it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)--Secretary of State Dean Rusk called on the allies of the United States today to review their dealings with Cuba in the light of actions taken against the Castro regime by the American republics.
The Metropolitan Opera has budgeted this season for a loss of $219,000 but it is banking on losing less. Such a deficit would wipe out the opera's capital reserves.

Charles M. Crooks, president of the nation's largest deck officers' union, decried yesterday a suggestion for a Federal law to require ship lines to replace retired officers with graduates of the United States Merchant Marine Academy.
IN the late winter a young man's (or young woman's) fancy turns to thoughts of summet vacation. This year increasing numbers of adolescents are thinking in terms of foreign travel.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 5--The New York Yankees today opened their advance camp in Fort Lauderdale's new million-dollar stadium and even the ballplayers, usually too preoccupied with their own problems to pay much heed to scenic effects, appeared goggle-eyed as they held their first workout.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5--Top officers of the United Steelworkers of America have drawn up a set of contract demands that probably will be presented to the industry early next month.
Orin Tovrov, who wrote radio's "Ma Perkins" daytime serial for twenty-seven years, has been assigned to write an hour-long original television drama for the "Du Pont Show of the Week."
LONDON, Feb. 5--Prime Minister Macmillan warned today that the United Nations' policies on anti-colonialism would lead to chaos rather than freedom.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 6-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy sat on the counter of a working-class bar in Tokyo last night and discussed world problems with the other ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5-- Commercial planes carrying Dutch troop replacements to Western New Guinea will be forbidden "for the time being" to use United States territory, the State Department said today.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 (UPI) --Roberto Clemente, the National League batting champion today signed his 1962 contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates. His salary was estimated at $50,000.
The qualifications of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes to deal with the parking problem in Manhattan were challenged yesterday by the New York County Medical Society.

The first issue of bonds under a $500,000,000 authorization of the Dormitory Authority of New York State was placed on the public market yesterday. R.Y. Pressprich Co. and associates offered $12,500,000 of the Series A revenue bonds bearing interest at 5, 3 , 3 , 3.6, 3.7 and 3 per cent.

THERE was Mozart on George Szell's program last night, as there generally is; and there was a new symphony by a 79-year-old composer; and Clifford Curzon returned, after a short absence from the local scene, to play the piano part in Brahms' D minor Concerto. It was a fine program that Mr. Szell and the Cleveland Orchestra brought to town as the first concert of three.

The state gave local welfare commissioners a list of legal safeguards yesterday to prevent welfare frauds and abuses. The commissioners were asked to forward any other suggestions they had found useful.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--Democrats continued today to goad Governor Rockefeller to prove that New York City milk had been deliberately soured by vinegar injections.
New Yorkers have become inured, like traveling salesmen, to a habitat that is always changing.
J. Ralph Killgore, publisher of The Rosebud (Tex.) News for thirty-three years, died here Sunday of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.
ALGIERS, Feb. 5--President de Gaulle's television address set off noisy Rightist demonstrations in Algeria's large cities tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5-- President Kennedy entertained Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo at a White House luncheon today and then conferred with him for more than an hour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)-- Between bites, Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, chided the Food and Drug Administration today for ruling against whole fish flour while sanctioning fried ants and chocolate-covered bees.
ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 5--The Community Trust Fund of the Junior League of the Oranges and Short Hills will receive the proceeds of a champagne supper dance at Graulich's here Friday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 5--The United States accused Cuba today of having appealed against the United States in the United Nations in an attempt to "obscure" the decisions against Cuba taken by foreign ministers of the Organization of American States.
CERTAIN remarks here about Sir Thomas More ("A Man for All Seasons" in Robert Bolt's stirring drama) provoked some very interesting remarks from Samuel Eliot Morison, the Harvard historian.

Benjamin Saltzman, Brooklyn superintendent for the Department of Buildings, testified briefly, yesterday before a rackets grand jury investigating a home-building scandal in the Canarsie and Mill Basin sections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5-- President Kennedy will propose to Congress this week that ownership and operation of a communications satellite system be turned over to a broadly owned private corporation.
LONDON, Feb. 5--British Government securities continued in brisk demand on the stock market here today. In the other sections buying was selective and the changes indicated no hard trend.
A new opera association will present partly staged operatic performances next season at Lincoln Center's Philharmonic Hall.

Four acres with a frontage of 300 feet on West Passaic Street in Rochelle Park, N.J., have been purchased by Fanelli Homes, Inc., Bergen County housing developers. The land, which was held at $115,000, will be improved with onefamily dwellings. Milton Goldsmith, Hackensack broker negotiated the sale. The tract was sold by Joseph and Elvira Pache. It had been occupied for more than twenty years by the Pache Landscape Nursery.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The House Ways and Means Committee gave quick preliminary approval today to a $2,000,000,000 increase in the ceiling on the national debt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The head of the American Broadcasting Company conceded today that it had been a mistake to televise a controversial program on its "Bus Stop" series.
PARIS, Feb. 5--The world Alpine ski championship meet crashed down into a political ravine yesterday, landed on its face, and may have killed itself.
BOMBAY, India, Feb. 5-- Acharya J.B. Kripalani relaxed on a sofa today and spoke of India's controversial Defense Minister, V.K. Krishna Menon.

Speaking in an atmosphere of crisis marked by continuing violence and massive military preparations against new insurrection, President de Gaulle has reaffirmed his determination to end the Algerian war on the basis of a "sovereign and independent Algerian state." He has also warned that he will again assume dictatorial powers if necessary to crush Rightist opposition to his plan.
TRENTON, Feb. 5--The Legislature voted overwhelmingly today to extend the scope and powers of the Waterfront Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Two men whose private lives are not very private compared notes at the White House today. Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the astronaut, told President Kennedy that he wished the press would turn its attention ...
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 5. --State and Federal officials began planning today for the unemployment problem that will arise when 5,000 cigar makers are made idle because of the trade embargo on Cuba.

The Common Market possesses the underlying forces for a rate of growth substantially in excess of that projected for the United States, particularly in the Nineteen Sixties, Robert H. Craft, president of Paribas Corporation, said yesterday.
A Board of Education audit has turned up evidence of financial irregularities in the operation of some school cafeterias.
Fabulous beasts of papiermache leaped and swayed in a crackling, sunlit haze of firecracker smoke yesterday as the residents of Chinatown thronged their streets to welcome the Year of the Tiger.
The American Jewish Congress called on the Board of Education yesterday to end the reading of the Bible in the city's public schools.
Steel production last week reached its highest level in twenty-two months.

Yes, we are going through rather tense days and the road is not always an easy one. This is, obviously, due in no small measure to the troubles stirred up by agitators who must be subjugated and punished. Nothing would be more absurd, however, than to let our minds be obscured by this, at the time when we are achieving great things.

AN English newspaper once described Robert Carrier as "the American gourmet who was born with a wooden spoon in his mouth." Mr. Carrier, who is 38 years old and a native of Tarrytown, N. H., is the newly appointed food editor of The London Sunday Times and food editor of the British edition of Vogue magazine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The United States has borrowed almost $25,000,000 in Italian lire and has renewed one-half of an earlier $46,300,000 borrowing in Swiss francs.

A dense fog rolled over the metropolitan area and parts of the Northern Atlantic seaboard early yesterday, hampering transportation and reducing visibility in some sections of the city to less than one and a half short blocks.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP)--A Special committee of the American Bar Association said today that colleges and high schools faced "a pressing need" to provide regular courses on communism.

THE advent of reality, naked and unashamed, is announced in John Chumley's paintings at the Maynard Walker Gallery, 117 East Fifty-seventh Street. His subjects open an avenue to a regionalism that has had a better fate in American literature than in American art.
The first subscription day for the Treasury's $11,700,000,000 refunding operation passed yesterday with a minimum of agitation in the public bond market.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) --Leading economists of two previous Administrations disagreed today on President Kennedy's economic policies.
Dr. Arthur Wilhelm, vice chairman of the board of CIBA, Ltd., of Basle, Switzerland, and of the CIBA Corporation of New York, died Sunday in Basle. He was 62 years old.
NEWARK, Feb. 5--Counsel for the parents of nine Negro children asked the Federal Distric Court today to bar Englewood from "operating and maintaining" racially segregated elementary schools.
A millionaire philanthropist yesterday criticized other philanthropists who "spend millions of dollars for unessential things."

Charges of racial discrimiation against the president and business agent of an International Longshoremen's Association local and the pier industry's eight-man Seniority Board will be heard today before the State Commission Against Discrimination.
A new drive to increase the earnings of the city's pension funds was announced yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame.

THE two Brooklyn spinsters who buried lonely old gentlemen in their cellar returned last night in a performance of "Arsenic and Old Lace" over Channel 4. But somehow the humor of their genteel and thoughtful homicide was not realized very satisfactorily.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 5-- Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison said today he would ask the Board of Supervisors to appropriate $1,000,000 to survey the county's highways.
Eighth Avenue savants had said that one of these nights Tony Fortunato would have to fight another two-rounder or maybe even an eight, and then they'd see "just how tough this cookie is."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara offered today to provide a Senate investigating panel with written explanations for each act of official censorship of speeches prepared by military officers. The Secretary insisted, however, that the individual Pentagon censors should not be called to account for each action, as the Senators have requested.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5--President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province has agreed to a United Nations demand that joint commissions supervise the removal of the remaining mercenaries in the Congolese province.

Yesterday's session of the world interzonal chess tournament at Stockholm was devoted to the completion of five games adjourned from the fifth and sixth rounds, according to a report from the Swedish capital.
American maritime unions yesterday went to the assistance of 130 Argentine seamen accused of mutiny.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino denied the conflict-of-interest charges against him today and implied that his accuser might be a pawn of the Communist party.

Wellesley College alumnae, their families and persons interested in the college are lending paintings from their collections for "Masters of Seven Centuries," the exhibition to be shown at the Wildenstein Gallery throughout March.
The Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will hold its eighth annual Spirit of Achievement Luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria April 9.

CHAMONIX, France, Feb. 5 (AP)--The world skiing championships, which apparently are doomed by an entanglement with politics, were replaced today by a meet that will be known as the world games of the Federation Internationale de Ski.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., Feb. 5-- Employes of the Republic Aviation Corporation were urged today to write to President Kennedy in an effort to save 13,000 threatened jobs.
Potato and world sugar futures advanced yesterday, as did most other commodities traded here. Cocoa continued its slump.
Kirk Douglas has decided to star in the stage as well as the screen version of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest." The source is Ken Kesey's first novel of the same name, published by Viking Press.

W.C. Langley Co. and Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and associates are offering to the public today $9,000,000 of 4 7/8 per cent debentures of Elizabethtown [N.J.] Water Company due on Feb. 1, 1992, priced at 102.799 to yield 4.70 per ecnt. The group won the issue at a competitive sale yesterday on a bid of 101.889.
The Society of Foreign Consuls in New York gave Mayor Wagner a twentieth wedding anniversary luncheon yesterday.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Feb. 6 (AP)-- The Archbishop of Lorenco Marques, Teodosio Clemente Cardinal de Gouveia, died of leukemia today in a general hospital here. He was 72 years old.
DETROIT, Feb. 6--A monthend sales burst sent January new car sales to a five-year high, Ward's Automotive Report said today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 6 --Political leaders studied with considerable astonishment today the changes brought by the Parliamentary elections of Sunday and yesterday in which Finland turned toward the Right.
The Joint Legislative Committee on Court Reorganization has agreed to withdraw its proposal for two separate administrations of three new city-wide courts in New York City.
TRENTON, Feb. 8--Gov. Richard J. Hughes today defended the neighborhood concept in the assignment of children to public schools.

LONDON, Feb. 6--The boom of guns in Hyde Park and at the Tower of London today marked the tenth anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's accession to the throne. The oldest and one of the strangest of political institutions in the Western world, the British monarchy had triumphantly passed another...
CHICAGO, Feb. 6--A proposal to deed seventy-nine acres of Government-owned land to Loyola University was assailed today as an unconstitutional "give-away."

Harrison E. Salisbury was named yesterday as director of national correspondence of The New York Times. He has been a member of The Times staff since 1949, and won the Pulitzer Prize in 1955 for articles on the Soviet Union.
THE American Opera Society, which in other sea sons has presented Handel's "Julius Caesar" and "Hercules," last night at Carnegie Hall presented his "Samson."

Mismanagement of gasoline flow and the resulting exhaustion of a fuel tank were cited by the Government yesterday as a prime cause of the crash in which seventy-four Army recruits were killed last November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- Mayor Wagner of New York called today for Federal control of prescription drug manufacturing, promotion and sales. He said that the step was necessary "to eliminate as much as possible the hazard inherent in the use of potent drugs."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb, 4--Racial segregation laws have confronted officials with a case in which South Africa's relations with Japan are at stake.
The long dreamed-of pipeline to carry coal in semiliquid form from the West Virginia coal fields to giant East Coast utilities has moved a step closer to reality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--President Kennedy's proposal for stiffer taxation of savings and loan associations and savings banks remains in dispute despite the House Ways and Means Committee's tentative vote to adopt it.

A CHILD should be introduced to a toothbrush as soon as he seriously notices his parents using one, according to Dr. Charles F. Beck, president of the New York State Society of Dentistry for Children.

Louis Goldfarb, realty investor, who recently took title to the four-story building at 861 Third Avenue, near Fifty-second Street, has net leased the properly to Bickford's, Inc., the food chain. The lease, which is for fifty-five years, was arranged by the Clinton W. Blume Company, broker.

The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday for 1961 a preliminary net income of $64,500,000, or $3.02 a share. This represents an increase of 4 per cent over the net income of $62,100,000, or $2.91 a share, in 1960.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 (UPI)-- American Metal Products Company filed suit today against the United Auto Workers. The union, in turn, accused the company of having conducted "a savage campaign against its Tennessee workers."
Within the most advanced echelon of Soviet science there is emerging a tendency to seek a nonmaterialist, spiritual concept of the universe.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 6 --President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province asked the Belgian State Council today to declare some actions of the Government of the Congo illegal. Among these actions, he said, was the dispatch of "foreign armies" to interfere with the internal affairs of his territory.
The State Commission Against Discrimination has cleared Columbia University of charges that it was attempting to drive Negroes and Puerto Rieans from the Morningside Heights area.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 6-- Prince Souvanna Phouma, leader of the neutralist Laotian faction, invited Prince Boun Oum, Premier of the Right-Wing Vientiane Government, today to the Plaines des Jarres for political talks, well informed sources reported.
ALBANY, Feb. 6--Governor Rockefeller declared today that it would have been "completely impossible" for Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino to have given tips on fall-out shelter legislation.
Vera Curtis, a soprano with the Metropolitan Opera from 1912 to 1920, died yesterday at a convalescent hospital in Fairfield, Conn. She was 82 years old.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--Senator Seymour R. Thaler charged on the Senate floor today that tactics being used against him in a special Queens Congressional election were "worthy of the worst deeds of Hitler Germany."
THE Old Vic has brought us a "Macbeth" that is ele gant in diction and, alas, sluggish in pace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) --The Port of New York Authority contended today that the contempt-of-Congress conviction of Austin J. Tobin, the authority's executive director, was based on "quicksand."

CHAMONIX, France, Feb. 6 (AP)--Communist-bloc nations began a mass withdrawal from the already politically muddled world games of the International Ski Federation today as the East Berlin-West Berlin controversy spread to the snowy slopes around this resort town in the French Alps.
TOKYO, Feb. 6--A small band of young Japanese Communists turned a warm university welcome for Robert F. Kennedy into a wild demonstration today.

ABDUL WAHAB, an Afghan science teacher in Robin Jenkins' interesting novel, "Dust on the Paw," is both a spiritual cousin and a direct literary descendant of Dr. Aziz, the tormented hero of E.M. Forster's "A Passage to India.' Dr. Aziz, of course, is by now the ancestor of a long line of literary descendants.
PARIS, Feb. 6--The basis for a cooperative drive to develop means of information in Africa was completed here today at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel revived Edwardian elegance in its lobby yesterday, installing red velvet curtains, potted plants and a one-ton crystal chandelier worth $10,000.
A demand that the Board of Estimate order the 5-cent transfer privilege restored on two major bus lines was made yesterday by the City Council's two-man Republican minority.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- Ticket racketeering, tax-free benefit tickets for hit shows, and tax regulations are ruining Broadway and the creative theatre, Congress was told today.

THE first vault was made, it is assumed, by some prehistoric man who trimmed the branch of a tree with his stone axe and used the newly created pole to vault over a narrow stream, going for distance rather than height. If he had waited for the invention of the fiber-glass pole, however, he could have the himself across a river.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- Senate hearings on Pentagon censorship were suspended today pending continued efforts to resolve a dispute between the investigators and the Secretary of Defense over the identification of censors of specific speeches by military men.

PLAINVIEW, L.I., Feb. 6-- New ways to print, along with a variety of new printing devices, were put on display by the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation here today. The occasion was the formal establishment by the company's Fairchild graphic equipment division of its graphic arts technical center.
A special, hour-long television show for young people dealing with the subject of Communism is being planned by the National Broadcasting Company.
The cafeteria manager in a Bronx high school was suspended yesterday and two other employes were dismissed after an investigation by the Board of Education had disclosed a shortage of $27,089.
PARIS, Feb. 6--Jacques Ibert, internationally known French composer, died last night at his home here. He was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The Senate approved tonight a $2,674,500,000 program of grants and loans for college scholarships and the construction of academic facilities.

THE treasurer of the Amsterdam, Chuctanunda and Northern Rail Road, State Assemblyman Donald Arthur Campbell, looks like an advertisement for milk. He is a tall man, solidly put together, thick in the shoulders and neck, and he has a healthy pink glow.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Feb. 6--A political merger under a strong central government has been recommended by the Malaysian Solidarity Committee.
Quiet trading on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday ended with further advances for world sugar and further declines for cocoa.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)-- Grain futures closed in a mostly steady range today, after recovering from an early period of weakness on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) --Congress was accused today of snubbing the Supreme Soviet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) --Vice President Johnson reported today that six major concerns doing business with the Government had recorded "significant and measurable benefits" in a program to provide equal job opportunities for Negroes.

The advertising agency business, like many others, tends to be dominated by a relatively small number of big concerns. Nonetheless, many creative advertisements--and irreverent ideas--continue to emanate from small advertising agencies.

Firm bids were plentiful yesterday for United States Government obligations and the prime-risk bonds of private corporations. But sluggishness began to show up in the market for the tax-privileged bonds of state and local governments, which for weeks were the market leaders.
The Department of Markets said yesterday that many butchers in the city were misleading consumers by putting an excessive amount of fat in hamburger and then adding beef blood to color it.
ALBANY, Feb. 6--Can a schoolboy be expelled for refusing to apologize to the principal after threatening to punch him?

An investing client of Jules Schapiro, lawyer, has bought the six-story apartment house at 30 Clarke Place, corner of Walton Avenue, the Bronx, from 30 Clark Place Associates. The building is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and has fifty-two apartments and two stores. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $210,000 through Leonard, Levities, Schiller, brokers.

MAN IN SPACE," a new presentation of the prob lems of human biology during apace journeys, may be seen at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street. The bassoon is usually a quiet woodwind, content to sit far back in the orchestra, performing its lowly, but essential, doubling duties and occasionally inserting a dry or droll comment.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 6--A trustee of the New Haven Railroad said today that the carrier had enough cash on hand to keep operating its passenger service for the foreseeable future.
Research has established positively the identification of a virus that has been an unwanted contaminant in polio vaccine, according to a report today to an international symposium on virus research.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- President Kennedy called on Congress today to put more than $5,700,000,000 into the nation's schools and colleges in the next five years. He asked no funds for private or church elementary and high schools.

Former President Harry S. Truman's letter stating he would not appoint John L. Lewis "dogcatcher" and two related letters were auctioned yesterday for $850 at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

THE team that will represent North America in the 1962 world championship matches, which will be played Saturday through, Feb. 18, at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, has been practicing against prominent teams.
ARLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 6-- Richard McCandless Gipson, who started the 1925 Rackaway real-estate boom in New York, died here today. He was 66 years old.

Production of paperboard in the nation totaled 340,317 tons in the week ended Saturday, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. This compared with 345,837 tons in the preceding week and 313,152 tons in the comparable 1961 week.

ALGIERS, Feb. 6--Violence flared again in Algerian cities today. At the same time the French Army found itself face to face with a major underground formation of armed and uniformed men of the Secret Army Organization.
LONDON, Feb. 6--Demand for British Government securities again was the feature of the stock market here today. Industrial issues turned dull late in the session.

President Kennedy has put the needs of American education in their proper perspective. In his message to Congress he has cut through the confusion created by a succession of smokescreens with which special interests have obscured the picture. The heart of the matter, and of the President's message, is that "elementary and secondary schools are the foundation of our educational system."

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6--Consider these names: Stirling Moss of England, Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif.; Limes Ireland and Jim Clark of Scotland, Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., Olivier Gendebien of Belgium, Joakim Bonnier of Sweden and Huschke von Hanstein of Germany.
ALBANY, Feb. 6--The Legislature, despite Governor Rockefeller's opposition, is seriously considering the approval of a $100,000,000 bonus for New York State veterans of the Korean War.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to put sharper teeth into the city's local laws against discrimination in the sale or rental of privately owned housing units.

For the first time in its seventeen-year history, the State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday began a formal hearing into charges of racial discrimination against a local of the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP)--Sam Snead held a onestroke lead over his closest rival in a field of top women pro golfers today at the halfway point of the Royal Poinciana invitation tournament, but he lost a boat at the fifteenth hole.
LONDON, Feb. 6--Britain has concluded that she has no alternative but to dissolve the West Indies Federation.

TUNIS, Feb. 6--Saad Dahlab, Foreign Minister of the Algerian Nationalist Provisional Government, is expected to leave Tunis in the next three days for what may be a final secret meeting with Louis Joxe, French Minister of Algerian Affairs, in the undercover Algerian peace talks.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 6 (UPI) --Twenty-nine Memphis stores desegregated dining rooms and lunch counters today to "keep pace with the community."
The Commercial Credit Company, Baltimore, has agreed to acquire the Farmers and Bankers Life Insurance Company of Wichita, Kan., through an exchange of shares.
Sales and earnings of the FMC Corporation in 1961 set a record for the twelfth consecutive year, the producer of machinery, chemicals and defense products reported yesterday.

THE Whitney Museum, carefully husbanding its field of American art, has gathered the fruits of two artists' labor, and presented them in retrospective exhibitions opening today. The artists are Paul Burlin and Karl Zerbe. They are good, if not great artists.
Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, declared from his hospital bed yesterday: "I'm not quitting."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- President Kennedy discussed a broad range of political and military problems today with Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Stockholders of Goldfield Consolidated Mines Company approved yesterday at the annual meeting in Evanston, Wyo., the acquisition of the American Chrome Company. They also voted to change the company's name to the Goldfield Corporation.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 6--All the talk in baseball these days seems to revolve around weight--not of the players, but of the bats they use. Time was when a player's poundage was a manager's greatest concern as another spring training season opened.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) --Republican and Democratic leaders Joined in a surprise drive today to increase the membership of the House of Representatives to 438 by adding three seats.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 (AP)-- Gene Shue and Bailey Howell combined for 50 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons defeated the Royals, 119--118. The National Basketball Association setback was Cincinnati's fifth in a row.
LONDON, Feb. 6--A British silver collection partly recovered from a scrap pile after World War II has been put on exhibition in Warsaw in the hope of recovering missing pieces.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes fixed a jammed parking meter with his pocketknife yesterday, but shrugged it off as a feeble effort to remedy a "terrible condition."

Cassius Clay, a 20-year-old heavyweight from Louisville, told a gathering of New York ring writers yesterday: "Boxing is not as colorful as it was in the past. We need more guys to liven it up and I think I can help."

BERLIN, Feb. 6--Allied experts on Soviet affairs here have discounted the idea that Walter Ulbricht and Premier Khrushchev, the East German and Soviet Communist leaders, are feuding over the Russians' policy for Germany.

Having entered the age of affluence, Italy has now embarked on an admittedly risky experiment with the much-discussed "opening to the Left" in order to bring about social and economic reforms that would spread Italian economic recovery to the still impoverished masses.

One way in which certain virus-caused cancers are fought and ultimately destroyed by natural physiological defense mechanisms was revealed in a dramatic series of photographs at a scientific meeting here yesterday.

Operations of Trans World Airlines, Inc., last year resulted in a net loss of $17,278,000 after taxes but before a special item, the preliminary report disclosed yesterday. In 1960, the airline cleared $6,473,466, equal to 97 cents a share on 6,674,155 shares then outstanding.
The State of New Jersey borrowed $42,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the development of public recreational and park areas and the construction of health institution buildings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Administration forces began pushing harder today for Congressional approval of President Kennedy's controversial plan to create a Cabinet-level Department of Urban Affairs and Housing.
ALBANY, Feb. 6--The Assembly gave final approval today to a bill permitting New York City to increase its financial aid for the rehabilitation of Carnegie Hall by lowering the hall's rent.

Roy Atwell, the former stuttering, tongue-twisting comedian who was a star in vaudeville, musical comedy and radio died yesterday at Veterans Administration Hospital, First Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6--The Kennedy Administration appealed directly today to the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America to start contract negotiations as soon as possible.

Chief Justice Earl Warren has set up a panel of Federal judges to plan for the handling of more than 1,500 damage suits filed against electrical equipment manufacturers. The case load threatens to overwhelm the Federal courts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)--A House subcommittee investigating the Federal highway program in Massachusetts heard testimony today that a brother of an aide to former Gov. Foster Furculo had received a $30,000 fee when the state bought land in South Attleboro.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 6-- Foreign Minister Francisco San Thiago Dantas will go before the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow to answer critics of Brazil's position on Cuba at the meeting last month of the foreign ministers of the Americas.
Now that commercial banks generally have raised interest rates on savings accounts, bankers are looking very sharply at new business potentials.

Cotton futures were 2 points up to 10 off yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market opened quiet. There were no sales made on the opening call, and later, prices held just above the previous closing levels. Small commission house buying absorbed limited offerings.

NICANOR ZABALETA is the kind of artist who would have been an outstanding trombonist or kazoo player if he had turned his talent in any of these directions. Such is the sensibility he shows toward any element of musical performance: dynamic control, phrasing, balance.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 6-- Harold Lahar was reappointed head football coach at Colgate University today to succeed Alva Kelley, who retired this morning.

U.S. Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would establish a foundation to study the impact of automation on employment and devise methods of solving the problems of technological displacement of workers.
Dr. Edmund Bergler, noted psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died last night at Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 62. He lived at 251 Central Park West.
