JARNAK, FRANCE. THE season for "cooking" the wine of the cognac country is now drawing to a close. The last of the raw, white distillate of the juice of the grape is falling drop by drop into the kegs of Limousin oak.

Jon Douglas and Dennis Ralston, two young players from California, were the subjects of a cross-country dispute yesterday between an official of the national indoor tennis tournament and members of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
A deft theft and two lay-ups by Al Butler marked a lastminute rally by the New York Knickerbockers that subdued the Los Angeles Lakers, 116-- 112, at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 8--The Republican counterattack against the violent spokesmen of the John Birch Society is finally beginning to make some progress.

A group of prominent citizens headed by Norman Thomas, President Robert F. Goheen of Princeton, Grenville Clark and Reinhold Niebuhr are seeking a Presidential pardon for Junius Irving Scales, a former official of the Communist party in North Carolina. Scales was sentenced to six years' imprisonment under the Smith Act, even though he had quit the party.
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Feb. 6--Inspectors from the state department of Motor Vehicles and Nassau County policemen halted 200 school buses today and issued forty-two summonses for safety violations.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York is starting an extensive survey of the onset of coronary heart disease in a population of normal individuals.

The formation of a new realty company to be known as the J.M. Brown and J. Clarence Davies Corporation with offices at 565 Fifth Avenue has been announced. The corporation will serve on a national scale as real estate and investor counselors and will represent individuals and groups of investors.
LONDON, Feb. 6--A small, well-lit room in the basement of a London auction house became the focal point this week of the city's art critics and potential collectors.

Eighteen years ago in General Sessions Court, David Jenkins, a 27-year-old machinist, pleaded guilty of attempted assault in the second degree. But he never appeared for sentencing, thinking that his case had been disposed of.
Ted Brkic and Randy Cox, recent additions to the ranks of local independent moviemakers, are arranging for the premiere of "Tracks in the Sand," their first feature-length undertaking.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6--The Congress of Racial Equality said today it had won a victory in its housing dispute with the University of Chicago.
MIAMI, Feb. 6--The Bahamas Stakes for 3-year-olds will have its twenty-eighth running tomorrow. Undefeated Ridan is in the seven-furlong race, and so are Crimson Satan, Rainy Lake and Sir Gaylord.

PARIS, Feb. 6--With remarkable concision General de Gaulle has managed to outline the twin goals of his policy, both, as it were, in the name of grandeur. For the sake of moral grandeur he would have France complete the arduous process...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) --The Army acknowledged today that a number of Reservists were called to active duty by mistake last fall during the Berlin crisis build-up. It said they were being released.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- President Kennedy's proposal that the United States buy United Nations bonds was sharply questioned today as Secretary of State Dean Rusk urged its approval by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Chemical shares made a concerted advance yesterday and the market on the New York Stock Exchange was higher for the seventh successive day.

The American merchant marine continually encounters "lethargy, and sometimes even opposition," from Federal agencies entrusted with the administration of programs in support of United States-flag shipping, Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, charged yesterday.

The Aetna Insurance Company of Hartford, stock control of which is being acquired by the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, yesterday reported a rise in net income last year to $9,373,636, from $8,262,235 in 1960.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) --A Long Island group and New York members of Congress decided today to ask President Kennedy to reverse an Air Force decision that, they said, would virtually end the Republic Aviation Corporation's operations on Long Island.

St. John's University yesterday announced an immediate acceleration in its development program, with an expansion of its present enrollment by at least 30 per cent within the next two and a half years.

The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange refused yesterday to lift a suspension ordered last month against two of its members-- James Patrick Gilligan and Albert Will.
A 49-year-old Bronx housewife was stabbed to death yesterday in a basement laundry room on the eve of her silver wedding anniversary.

The New York Rangers, whose chief task is to beat out the Detroit Red Wings for a Stanley Cup play-off berth, improved their defense yesterday by acquiring Pete Goegan in a trade with the Wings.

The Central Intelligence Agency, under its new director, John A. McCone, is opening a fresh chapter. Though without prior experience in the intelligence community, Mr. McCone is an able administrator. He has already made changes in personnel and methods which are hopeful, and others are impending.

Ever since the Government disclosed that tax officials were investigating and preparing a case against an important broker and governor of the New York Stock Exchange, there has been plenty of excitement on Wall Street. It all centers upon just which of the thirty-four governors was The Man.
A railroad union demanded yesterday that the Department of Justice investigate the financial condition of the New Haven Railroad.

ALBANY, Feb. 7--The state, in response to protests over its plan to build part of the new interstate Route 87 in Westchester through a bird sanctuary, has mapped an alternate roadway that would bypass the disputed area.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb, 8 (AP)--The StudebakerPackard Corporation and the United Automobile Workers agreed early today on a new contract.

CHAMONIX, France, Feb. 7 (AP)--The powerful Austrian team of eight men and seven women hinted at a boycott of the world ski games tonight unless it was permitted to enter a bigger quota of racers in each event.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 (AP)--An attorney, Melvin Belli, obtained a court writ today laying claim to a piece of Willie Mays, highest paid player in baseball, unless the San Francisco Giants pay a judgment of $1,880.96.

MISCHA ELMAN, who was 71 last month, interrupt ed his Carnegie Hall recital last night to pay tribute to Fritz Kreisler.

The Women's Division and the Board of Trustees of the Roosevelt Hospital will sponsor a theatre party at the March 19 performance of Richard Rodgers' and Samuel Taylor's new musical, "No Strings," with Diahann Carroll and Richard Kiley. A leading manufacturer of men's clothing chided the synthetic textile industry yesterday for what he called its failure to test new fibers adequately before putting them on the market.

KEEN bridge players learn that when it is necessary to discard unexpectedly, because declarer is getting an unusually bad break, a card of the same color should be thrown--a diamond on a heart lead, for example, or a club on a spade lead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) --An effort by Republican Senators to provide more jobs and higher pay for the Republican minority on Senate staff payrolls was defeated today, 55 to 30. The voting was entirely along party lines.

Twelve hour-long film shows starring Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz will be repeated in the summer by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The programs, which are separate from the old "I Love Lucy" series, were first televised as specials in 1957, 1958 and 1959.

The White House seems to have done everything except write the contract for the steel industry and the union in the wage negotiations it has induced both sides to begin next week. President Kennedy and Secretary of Labor Goldberg have been exerting heavy pressure to force an early start in the contract talks and to make sure that they result in a peaceful, non-inflationary settlement.
Calling this country "the world's greatest Samaritan," Cardinal Spellman opened the 1962 American Catholic Bishops Relief Fund Appeal yesterday.
Joseph Hacken, a 42-year-old gambler, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to bribing basketball players to keep their teams' points down in intercollegiate games.

LONDON, Feb. 7--Prices moved aimlessly in a quiet ses sion of the stock market today.
PARENTS should use their influence to open doors for children who seek summer jobs. They should canvass their friends and business acquaintances, without twisting anyone's arm.

THE biography "Stanton: The Life and Times of Lincoln's Secretary of War,"* by Benjamin P. Thomas and Harold M. Hyman, is a tremendous one in the grand manner. A crucial period in American history is dramatized with skill and ballasted with scholarship. The Pulitzer Prize judges will do well to start reading it right away.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The United States exported $5,700,000,000 more than it imported last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7--One of the nation's most successful writer-producers sees little hope that Hollywood can avert almost complete destruction as a moviemaking center. Carl Foreman said that the movie industry here could be saved only by Federal subsidy and the establishment of an industry-sponsored school to train new creative and technical talents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The newly created Disarmament Agency awarded today its first scientific research contract on the problems of monitoring a disarmament agreement.
TRENTON, Feb. 7--Governor Richard J. Hughes voiced his determination tonight to end discrimination in housing as a solution to the problem of segregation in the public schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) --The Small Business Administration said today that it would run out of money at the end of this month unless Congress quickly approved a supplemental appropriation of $80,000,000.

The Senate committee which has been investigating the alleged "muzzling" of the military voted unanimously yesterday to require a Pentagon witness--a member of the security review section--to reveal who censored a speech by an Army general. The witness and all others from the Pentagon had been ordered by Secretary of Defense McNamara to refuse to answer questions which would identify specific censors with specific deletions from specific speeches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-- President Kennedy proposed today that free enterprise be extended to space. He called for the creation of a privately owned corporation to operate a global communications satellite system.

The New York Mets received signed contracts yesterday from Ed Bouchee, a first baseman, and Sherman (Roadblock) Jones, a right-handed pitcher. This brought the total of satisfied Mets to twenty-two. There are thirty-five men on the roster.

LONDON, Feb. 7--The National Institute of Economic and Social Research said today that there was a reasonable chance British exports would rise faster than imports this year.

WHEN the Brazilian Government presented to the Chamber of Deputies yesterday its defense of its policy toward Cuba, its spokesman was a man described by his friends as a practical egghead.

Sinclair Canada Oil Company, an affiliate of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, has agreed to purchase the producing properties of Dome Petroleum, Ltd., and substantially all of its undeveloped acreage in western Canada. Consideration is $42,000,000 in Canadian funds. The effective date would be Dec. 31, 1961.
Seven out of ten doctors who get summonses for illegal parking in the city pay no fines because county medical societies back their statements that they were on emergency calls.

Mayor Wagner appealed last night to all communities in the state to join the city in a fight for broader home rule and more equitable state financial aid.

THE PRESIDENT: I have two announcements to make. ALGIERS, Feb. 7--Europeans in Constantine went on a strike marked by violence today to obtain the release of forty members of an extremist underground commando that the French Army had disarmed.

Jack Paar was named yesterday in a $3,431,000 damage action by a sponsor who charged he had failed to promote its product and had made "derogatory and disparaging" remarks about it.
VIENNA, Feb. 7 (Reuters)-- Herbert von Karajan resigned today as director of the Vienna State Opera, protesting that the Government had not consulted him in a wage settlement.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7--Salim Jubran, a Christian Arab, takes great pride in the 30,000 Arab trade union members who work side by side with Jewish workers in Israel's factories and business offices.

Tickets for concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall next season will cost an average of 50 per cent more than they have cost at Carnegie Hall.

SKI SKETCH: When Dartmouth stages its carnival this week-end, Jim Page, a 20-yearold 140-pounder with a shock of dark hair and dark eyes, will receive considerable attention from rivals as well as spectators.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Support is growing in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for the idea of adding Congressional conditions to the President's proposal for buying United Nations bonds.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7--Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, denounced last fall as a member of the so-called anti-party group, was nominated today for a seat in the Supreme Soviet (Parliament).
A theatre party at the March 1 performance of "New Faces of 1962" at the Alvin Theatre will benefit the Recreation Services for Children of Bellevue, Inc.

Twenty-two public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $79,550,000 yesterday in the public bond market on serial obligations due from 1962 to 2002. The bonds will bear interest coupons ranging from 3 to 3 per cent.

David Montagu, violinist, and Mitchell Andrews, pianist, presented four violin sonatas in Town Hall last night, Both artists have been praised highly in previous appearances here.
A $50,000,000 issue of Western Union Telegraph Company 5 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1987 was offered to the public yesterday by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Lehman Brothers.
A day-long campus boycott of the Columbia University bookstore failed to affect the store's operation yesterday.
The new Madison Square Garden Center, planned for the site of Pennsylvania Station, has acquired its major tenant, the American Machine and Foundry Company.
KYOTO, Japan, Feb. 7-- Robert F. Kennedy toured Western Japan today as if he were running for county sheriff.
Mayor Wagner disclaimed any knowledge yesterday of the way a Queens Democratic club rebuffed its own district leader Monday night.

An increase in the week ended last Friday of 3,969,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 210,460,000 barrels, compared with 206,419,000 a week earlier and 214,349,000 a year before.

Sales and earnings of the Corning Glass Works in 1961 were the highest in its 110-year history, the specialty glass manufacturer disclosed yesterday.

The New York Rangers fought back twice last night and gained a 2-2 National Hockey League tie with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden before 13,556 fans.

A reversal in price moves for world sugar futures, despite the fact that it was on a light volume, was the feature yesterday in an otherwise dull day one the New York commodity exchanges.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 7-- The collective emigration of Moroccan Jews has been resumed after a month's suspension.

MIAMI, Feb. 7--Frank Merrill, who trains Puss n Boots, scratched his horse from the Bahamas Stakes this morning. Several trainers had expressed displeasure because of the listing of Puss n Boots in the overnight entries for today's feature at Hialeah.

THE golden age of the whalebone in corsetry vanished with the last whiff of smelling salts. Yet many a woman, faced today with the renewed threat of the fitted dress and the wide belt, will yearn for a wasp waist and rounded hip.

Although the outflow of short-term United States capital in 1961 was almost as heavy as in 1960, there was a gain, rather than a continuing loss, of confidence abroad in the dollar last year, a high Treas.
"One Last Question" is the title of a new courtroom melodrama that A.E. Hotchner is writing for Gilbert Miller. A fall opening is planned at Henry Miller's Theatre, which the producer controls.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)--A Federal District judge placed in receivership today all of the Massachusetts property of Bernard Goldfine, who was jailed eight months ago for taxevasion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--An interagency committees, chosen by President Kennedy today, will re-examine the nation's needs and stores of critical materials and decide what information can be given to Senate investigators.

The Friends of Puerto Rico, Inc., will give a dinner tomorrow evening in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The dinner, planned as the first of a series of annual events, has been named in memory of Eugenio Maria de Hostos, Puerto Rican educator and philosopher, and will mark the 123d anniversary of his birth.
St. Louis, Mo., borrowed $12,676,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements, including the construction of buildings.

Unlike the Congress in neighboring India, the big national coalition party that assumed power in Burma when that country became independent in 1948 failed to remain united. After running the Government for ten years, the Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League split into two factions.

THE present day secular celebration of St. Valentine's Day probably had its origin in Roman times, when two early martyrs are believed to have died on Feb. 14. The pagan festival of Lupercalia, held in honor of Februata at the onset of spring, included a lottery where Roman youth drew names of girls at random from a bowl.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-- President Kennedy turned the weapon of derision on Governor Rockefeller at his news conference today.
A New Jersey builder was found shot to death on West Houston Street last evening. There apparently were no witnesses.
AS rare as it is rewarding, "The Aspern Papers" is a mystery with a heart.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 7--Stu Sherard, Army's high scoring basketball captain, tallied 35 points in leading the cadets to a 70-to-63 victory over Colgate today. It was the cadets ninth triumph against eight losses.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP)-- Grain futures quickly absorbed a thin volume of support today and prices on the Board of Trade ranged toward weakness thereafter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Thirty-one more leading defense contractors signed White House "plans for progress" today. These are designed to give Negroes and other minorities equal access to jobs and promotions.
Henry William Voorhees, $139a-week president of a small upstate bank and admitted embezzler for twenty years, was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to a year and a day in prison.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7--The Rev. Herman I. Storck, who founded the Roman Catholic Loyola House of Retreats in Morristown, N.J., the National Layman's Retreat Movement and the National First Friday Luncheon Clubs, died in Mercy Hospital here yesterday. His age was 84.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The Senate and the House both passed Administration-sponsored bills today to strengthen the protection of 90,000,000 beneficiaries of employe welfare and pension funds. These private funds have assets of more than $50,000,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) --A move to draft Senator Hugh Scott as the Republican candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania was endorsed today by Pennsylvania's national Republican committeeman, Dr. Robert L. Johnson.
Fordham's basketball team snapped Wagner's five-game winning streak, 75--68, as it gained its seventh victory of the season last night in the Fordham gymnasium before a crowd of 1,500.
Prices rose on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the eighth successive day. As an added fillip, The New York Times rail average jumped to a 1962 high.
The Department of Markets told butchers here yesterday they must grind individual orders of meat in public view.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 7 (AP)--Two United States Army air support companies totaling 300 men arrived today from the plains of Kansas to bolster South Vietnam's jungle war against Communist guerrillas.

For if he can give the Marines an intelligence test to see if they know their job, why can't they give him an intelligence test to see if he knows his?

Vincent Baxter of 69 East 122d Street stepped into the State Supreme Court Building on Foley Square yesterday morning for the first time in his life. An hour later he was presiding in a mock trial held in a regular courtroom with fifty-five classmates in attendance.

CHING JOHNSON'S grin is as wide as ever. It glows with enough radiant warmth to melt the ice on any hockey arena within range. It was his trademark when he was a defensive terror on the original New York Ranger team in 1926. He played with such buoyant zest that he was the idol of the galleries and he played with such consummate skill that he has won a niche in hockey's Hall of Fame.

SACREMENTO, Calif., Feb. 7. --It was a gloomy day Finally, after ten days, a dense "killer" fog was lifting--a fog that had closed many schools in California's Central Valley and that had been responsible for more than thirty deaths. A light drizzle was subsiding.

The political discord in the Communist camp between Soviet Russia and Communist China, between Stalinists and Khrushchevists, is being matched by a similar divergence of views in the intellectual sphere that goes to the very root of Communist doctrine.

Steels, motors and chemicals were weak and other groups irregular in an up-and-down session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

IF the name of Larry Gardner is a mite unfamiliar to modern baseball fans, that is understandable. He played third base for the Boston Red Sox in the 1912 world series against the New York Giants. MARITTA WOLFF is a naturalistic novelist of tangible achievement. She has successfully rendered the social and personal tensions of the American small town in several novels, notably "Whistle Stop." Agony was etched on his face as he drove for the finish line and flung his tortured body into waiting arms of wellwishers. How did he feel at that precise moment?

BERLIN, Feb. 12 The Russians backed down today from their attempt to restrict Allied use of the Berlin air corridors and canceled scheduled flights of Soviet military transport planes. The move came after the West had rejected a demand that two of the three air corridors be set aside for the exclusive use of Soviet planes up to an altitude of 7,500 feet for more than two hours this morning.

LONDON, Feb, 12 British Government securities lost part of their recent gains in the stock market here today. Falls of between 5 shillings (70 cents) and 7s 6d ($1.05) were common at the close; many were at their lowest levels of the day. The turnover increased among industrial shares. But losses outnumbered gains in most groups.

ONE of the world's great violinists was heard at the top of her form last night. Erica Morini played the Brahms D. major Concerto with George Szell and the Cleveland Orchestra, and it was a most beautiful performance from all concerned.

Abe Montague, executive vice president of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, died yesterday in Stuart, Fla., at the age of 69. He and his wife, the former Edith Silverman, had been vacationing at the fishing resort since Feb. 2.

LONDON, Feb. 13--A persistent demand for British Government securities was the highlight of stock market trading here today. Industrial shares moved irregularly with most changes small.

FRANCE, being a food-conscious nation, awards Os cars for food rather than screen presentations. Two such packaging awards were won last year by products of the Modern Belin biscuit factory at Chateau Thierry, close to the champagne district of France.

THE world bridge championships being played at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel entered their sixth day yesterday with the two closest contests of the week still to be decided. The results are likely to decide the 1962 championship.
The American Stock Exchange was told yesterday to get tougher with its specialists. It also was urged to abolish all associate memberships in the exchange within an eighteen-month period.

The Anaconda Company cleared $42,100,000, or $3.93 a share, in 1961, compared with $46,112,500, or $4.30 a share, in 1960, Clyde E. Weed, chairman of the big copper concern, announced in a preliminary report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15--According to all well-informed and seasonally adjusted economists, machines are replacing everything in this country, except maybe pretty girls, and President Kennedy is worried about it.
A first-run motion picture theatre is about to be construced on Thirty-Fourth Street near Second Avenue, across the street from the Murray Hill Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)--The Kennedy Administration sent a top official to the Senate today to urge reform of the Federal pay structure. It would add $1,000,000,000 to the annual pay roll.
Turnover was lower but prices were higher on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Leadership improved and the institutional investors were credited with giving much of the drive to the market.
A total general fund of $862,033,000 for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 was predicted yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame. This would be $31,359,000 less than in 1961-62.
The State Education Department informed 16,242 high school students yesterday that they had won four-year Regents scholarships to any college in the state.

The Women's Division of the Metropolitan Chapter of the National Hemophilia Foundation is arranging a benefit luncheon and fashion show, to be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on March 20.

Former Fourth Deputy Commissioner James J. Sheehy, who commanded the Traffic and License Divisions of the Police Department, died Wednesday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He lived at 30 Lafayette Avenue, Bethpage, L.I. His age was 79.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 16 (AP) Lieut. Col. Hulen Dorris Stogner's Congolese houseboy, a 38-year-old cook and personal servant, was arrested today for questioning in the colonel's slaying.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Europe has promised to buy substantially more cotton goods from Japan and other lowcost producers and thus ease the pressure of those textiles on the United States market.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 16 (AP) Charles L. Wright's Timberlane, who passed up tomorrow's $10,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap for today's $5,000 Annapolis Purse, scored by a length and a quarter in the six-furlong sprint. He paid $10.80 for $2.

Oils, with two or three notable exceptions, were strong in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. No other major group did as well and the day closed with a slight loss in The New York Times Combined average of fifty stocks.

THE latest addition to the many attractive decorating houses in the East Sixties is Williamson M. Lyle Associates at 127 East Sixtieth Street. This shop has intriguing accessories and furnishings and also displays a collection of paintings by contemporary French artists.

Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, sought a court order yesterday to prevent his political foes from removing him from office.
MACON, Ga., Feb. 16 (AP) Violence continued in Macon today as officials sought some solution of the problems arising from a Negro bus boycott.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 16 U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, has complained that Belgian authorities interfered with United Nations personnel undertaking humanitarian missions in the Congo.
A music publisher was arrested here yesterday on a charge that he had offered gifts to an employe of an accounting concern in a move to get "inside information" from the company's files.

MIAMI, Feb.16 (UPI) Alvin Dark shot a two-under-par 33, 35 68 today for a 36-hole score of 142 and increased his lead to seven strokes at the halfway mark of the national baseball players golf tournament.
Jimmy Bostwrick of Westbury, L.I., won the United States open court tennis championship yesterday for the third successive time.

The board of directors of the Texas Utilities Company proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock and raised the quarterly dividend yesterday. A dividend of 56 cents a share on the present common will be paid on April 2 to stockholders of record of March 1. The Dallas utility paid 52 cents in previous quarters.

THE play here for the world bridge championship, has developed into a contest between the Italian and North American teams.
The nation's leading retail store chains increased their sales 7.4 per cent in January from the 1961 level according to a survey by The New York Times.

Long Island Rail Road schedules were snarled during yesterday morning's rush hour by a seventy-five-minute work stoppage by engineers. Twenty trains were affected and a large percentage of the 85,000 inbound commuters were delayed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The Kennedy Administration has begun a policy review of Federal grants, particularly to state employment agencies and hospitals, to determine how racial discrimination by the recipients can be eliminated.
TUNIS, Feb. 16 The National Council of the Algerian Revolution will begin a crucial debate Sunday in Tripoli, Libya, on whether to end the sevenyear-old Algerian war.

An experiment in persuading New Yorkers to build familysize fall-out shelters was started here yesterday.

Neither the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra nor its conductor, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, are newcomers to New York. Last night, however, they appeared here together for the first time, in Carnegie Hall.

The Metropolitan Opera Studio will perform in eleven midwestern cities during a sixweek tour beginning on March 1, under the sponsorship of Life magazine. Two alternating casts of six young singers will present scenes from Mozart's "Cost fan tutte" in English.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 16 New Jersey's state colleges are sharing in an $84,352,500 building project that may end what many have considered a long neglect in the state's educational program.

MIAMI, Feb. 17--New York and New Jersey racing fans are in for a treat this spring. No, a new system hasn't been developed by which they're guaranteed to win money. That probably never will happen. But Avelino Fernandez Gomez, a superior Cuban race rider, has decided to campaign in the Eastern United States this year after many years as Canada's leading saddlesmith.
JACKIE GLEASON, who is trying to develop a show for his triumphant return to television next fall, was hard at work with four writers last week at a Florida winter resort.

Miss Virginia Alys Galston, daughter of Clarence E. Galston of Huntington, L.I., and Mrs. Hans von Briesen of Santa Monica, Calif., was married here yesterday afternoon to John Joseph Walsh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh of Mamaroneck, N.Y.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) Customers were scarce in the grain futures trade last week and prices extended their general downward trend almost without letup.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb.18 (UPI) Phil Rodgers sank a 65-foot wedge shot for an eagle 3 on the last hole today and won the $20,000 Tucson open golf tournament.
JANE CARLYLE, a soprano originally from Minneapolis, made her local debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

A total of 782,511 tons of waterborne cargo passed over the docks of the Albany Port District Commission in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1961, the commission has reported. This was up 78,426 tons from the previous year.

New evidence that many thousands of Negro and Puerto Rican workers in this city are cruelly exploited through collusion between their employers and racketeer unions is contained in a report submitted to the A. F. L.- C. I. O. by the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists.
A strike affecting 1,000,000 weekday riders of a New Jersey bus line began last midnight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Senator Prescott Bush of Connceticut proposed today that New York and Connecticut create a bi-state public authority to save commuter service on the New Haven Railroad.

Ground will be broken soon for Grosvenor Neighborhood House's new building. The four-story structure, the first settlement house to be erected in New York in thirty-five years, will be at Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Doug McDonald may not be as popular as his all-America team-mate, Jerry Lucas, but the Ohio State backcourt man rates Buckeye bravos for keeping alive his school's search for its first unbeaten basketball season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Before a Congressional investigating committee rings up its curtain in a Capitol hearing its agents have been quietly asking questions in many plac es, often far from Washinton.
A Roman Catholic priest said yesterday that it was "a bit strange" that only the Catholic Church should be accused of trying to violate "the wall of separation between church and state."

HAMBURG, Germany, Feb. 18 The unofficial West German death toll in yesterday's stormwhipped flood rose to 134 late tonight. Thousands of tired volunteers continued to repair broken dikes and assist the tens of thousands whose homes were inundated.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 The mounting election-year campaign to authorize a state bonus for Korean War veterans is expected to reach a peak in the Legislature this week.

The reorganization of the probation and related auxiliary services in the city's courts was urged yesterday to help prevent the needless detention of thousands of children on charges that are eventually dismissed.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 18 Robert F. Kennedy said tonight that United States troops would stay in South Vietnam until Communist aggression was defeated.

LONDON, Feb. 18 In the face of depressing reports on Britain's January trade figures, an indifferent stock market clung last week to its recent levels.

OLD architects, like old generals, never die; nor, in the case of Frank Lloyd Wright, do they fade away. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence L. Durgin told churchgoers yesterday that tolerance was not the alternative to bigotry.

The Treasury last week invited holders of $18,738,000,000 of United States Government securities to participate in the fifth and most sweeping advance refunding operation of the post-war period. Subscription books were opened today.

With Captain Andy Bathgate and Guy Gendron pacing a fine team effort, the New York Rangers snapped a three-game losing streak last night by walloping the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 2, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The issue of Federal aid to education has been thrown into tomorrow's special election in the Sixth Congressional District in Queens. Votes for Thomas F. Galvin, Republican, are being urged on the ground that he favors aid to students attending parochial schools.

DON NEWCOMBE has just announced his retirement from baseball. An unbidden picture of his departure flashes instantly to mind's eye, a huge man lumbering off the mound with head bowed and shoulders hunched in despair. Every other pitcher has been forced to follow that distasteful routine during his career, but none ever was able to impart to it the impact of stark, unrelieved tragedy that Newk gave it.

Since none of the following exhibitions would be starless by this system, let us keep to it for today.

TUNIS, Feb. 20--The Alge rian nationalist Provisional Government met today and gave full approval to peace accords negotiated with the French by four members of the rebel re gime.

PARIS, Feb. 20--The United States asked its Atlantic Treaty allies today to add Cuba to the list of Communist states with which trade in strategic ma terials is voluntarily prohibited.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in the month to Feb. 15 to 3,162,- 792 shares from 3,024,541 shares in mid-January, the exchange reported yesterday. This was the highest level since Dec. 15, 1961, when the figure was 3,- 406,805 shares.

TUNIS, Feb. 21 Making peace requires even more secrecy than underground warfare in the seven-year-old Algerian conflict.
San Antonio, Tex., borrowed $8,965,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

FIVE artists are emphasizing five different aspects of landscape in separate exhibitions. Hughie Lee-Smith at Janet Nessler Gallery, 718 Madison Avenue, suffuses his canvases with a mellow light in which everything is brought into calm and precise focus.
George Washington, born 230 years ago today was remembered yesterday on the spot where he took the oath in 1789 as the first President.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21 The American Association of School Administrators ended its ninety-fourth annual convention here today with a declaration that school funds should not be used for fall-out shelters.

A crowd that completely filled Town Hall and overflowed onto the stage heard the Dave Brubeck Quartet last night in a concert that included first New York performances of several selections from the group's forthcoming album bearing the fortuitous title "Time in Outer Space."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 President Kennedy will turn his meeting with Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. at Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Friday into a family reunion for the astronaut.

As middle-aged athletes inevitably go, 40-year-old Charlie Conerly went yesterday. He retired as quarterback of the Yew York Giants after fourteen seasons as a stellar passer and a prime target of the opposition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The Federal reserve board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 14:

Premier Khrushchev's congratulatory message yesterday concerning Colonel Glenn's brilliant feat was in the spirit of President Kennedy's similar messages last year after the flights of the Russians Gagarin and Titov. It bore little resemblance to the derogatory remarks about American space achievements which Premier Khrushchev had previously uttered.
GRAND TURK ISLAND, Bahamas, Feb. 21 (UPI) Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter saved the life of a skin diver who had lost consciousness eighty feet under water today.
Producion of electric power in the nation totaled 16,266,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday, Feb. 17, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (UPI Chip Lundy scored 24 points and grabbed sixteen rebounds tonight in pacing Lafayette to a 74-69 upset victory over La Salle in a Middle Atlantic Conference basketball game at the Palestra.

MIAMI, Feb. 21 Sir Gaylord really "belted" his foremost opposition in the 3-year-old division today. Christopher T. Chenery's handsome colt ran to a four-and-three-quarter-length victory over El Peco Ranch's Decidedly in the $30,950 Everglades Stakes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Government transportation for the dependents of military men assigned overseas has been restricted because of the continuing drain on United States gold resources through spending abroad, President Kennedy said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 President Kennedy wrote Soviet Premier Khrushchev today that he hoped representatives of their two Governments could meet "at a very early date" to discuss cooperative space projects.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The Government is about to close the books on a bit of American frontier history.

Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.'s meeting with President Kennedy tomorrow in Cape Canaveral, Fla., and Washington festivities in his honor on Monday will be broadcast by all television and radio networks.
Capt. John C. Carroll, first vice president of the Air Line Pilots Association, has announced his intention to run for president of the 15,000-member union to succeed Clarence N. Sayen.
The Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company announced here yesterday it had developed a push-button autopilot for light planes.
Committee members for the eighth International Press Ball of the Foreign Press Association are proceeding with plans for the event, to be held March 6 at the Plaza.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 The creation of a new State Port Council to coordinate planning of new facilities for New York's six major ports was recommended today by a joint legislative committee.
Sporadic snowfall was mixed with occasional sleet and rain here last night, with a promise of early morning slush today.

The nation's stocks of gasoline increased an additional 1,371,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 213,528,000 barrels, compared with 212,157,000 a week earlier and 218,003,000 a year ago.

The six-story building containing fifty-nine apartments and occupying a plot 133 by 100 feet at 3764 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx, has been sold by the Bronwick Realty Corporation. It was bought by the 590 Corporation for investment, subject to mortgages of $309,000. The Wishnow Horowltz Real Estate Company was the broker.

THE Greater New York Championships, a sectional tournament popularly called the Washington's Birthday tournament because it is played annually at this time, will begin today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel and continue through Sunday.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 21 For two agonizing hours or more, Project Mercury officials had an unverifiable indication of trouble that, however it was handled, could have meant a disastrous finish to the three-orbit flight of John H. Glenn Jr. on Tuesday.

The National Cash Register Company is planning to offer its stockholders the right to subscribe to 319,090 additional common shares. It is believed to be the first rights offering to common stockholders in the company's history.
The destroyer Remey sailed into port yesterday for a week's respite from service in the "cold war."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board absolved two unions today of illegal picketing. It reversed decisions made a year ago when Eisenhower appointees dominated the board.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 21--The Mercury capsule was displayed like a glorious trophy here today, and an air of triumph seemed to prevail everywhere--except within the tiny quarters of the local post office.
The Corn Products Company in 1961 had the highest sales and earnings in its fifty-six year history, William T. Brady, chairman, reported yesterday.
For the first time in history the White House will have a cultural coordinator.

Governor Rockefeller's statement in opposition to a Korean war bonus displayed political courage at its best. Consider the circumstances in the case: 1962 a state election year; both parties at Albany champing at the bit in their eagerness to approve a bonus bill; the state department of the American Legion holding its annual legislative dinner at Albany, with the Governor as invited speaker. This was the background of...
Throwing pearls to swine may still be a silly dietary gesture, but a young woman ruefully discovered here yesterday that pearls plus a diamond apparently make a palatable mix for a horse.
PRESIDENT KENNEDY I have one statement. It is increasingly clear that the impact of Colonel Glenn's magnificent achievement yesterday goes far beyond our own time and our own country.
GRAND TURK ISLAND, Bahamas, Feb. 21 Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. was pronounced by his physician today tq be in "excellent condition." The physician said that the astronaut had suffered...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The Southern Railway Company moved a step closer today to acquiring control of the Central of Georgia Railway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk carried the Administration's fight for broad tariff-cutting authority to the heart of the South's textile industry today.
VIENTINE, Laos, Feb. 21 Two of Laos' political opponents met here for fifty minutes today.
ALBERTO GINASTERA, Argentine composer, is visiting New York, and last night he went to Judson Hall to hear the Paganini Quartet. His presence led to a change of program.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 The Illinois Commerce Commission approved today a reduction in the rates of the Commonwealth Edison Company totaling $4,222,000 a year. The new rates take effect on March 5.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 21 The Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly adopted tonight a compromise resolution that would permit Belgian troops to remain in the African trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi after independence.

The president of the International Paper Company questioned yesterday whether the Federal Government was doing enough to encourage a rise in corporate profits that, he said, would be necessary to assure a balanced budget for fiscal 1963.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 21 Long Island potato growers were told today that their future success hinged on their willingness to organize and integrate the industry.
A PSYCHOLOGIST recently counseled married couples against adopting a "scientific approach" to human relationships. He urged greater reliance on intuition and less reliance on textbook maxims.
Stocks yesterday started the day with a small gain, lost it about noon and ended with a considerable loss. Not a major group was able to show consistent Strength.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 After an emotional and caustic debate, the Assembly gave solid backing today to a committee report clearing Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of conflict-of-interest charges.
NEWARK, Feb. 21--The three-day bus strike by employes of Public Service Coordinated Transport ended tonight when union employes ratified a new contract.
STRATFORD, Conn., Feb. 21 Five children perished, another was burned critically and their parents and two other children escaped in a fire that destroyed a two-story house early today.
Mrs. Mary Largent Brandt, one of the nation's leading home furnishings consultants, died of a heart attack Tuesday at her home at 11 Gramercy Park. She was 62 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 118 116, tonight in a National Basketball Association contest at Convention Hall.

A new political era is beginning in Italy. Premier Amintore Fanfani has formed a Leftward-facing Government which is almost certain to win a safe parliamentary majority next week. The Italian Socialist party, headed by Pietro Nenni, will support a Government of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Republicans.
The Metropolitan Opera's fourth "Salome" of the season, given last night, had two performers new to their roles with the company.
BERLIN, Feb. 22 Huge and emotional crowds greeted Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy today as he began a two-day visit to West Berlin.
PARIS, Feb. 22 President de Gaulle may assume dictatorial powers as soon as a ceasefire agreement is signed with the Algerian rebels, probably next week.

IN MUSIC, a fantasy is often an extended, free-flowing work of quasi-improvisational nature, which allows a composer a good deal of freedom to pour out his feelings and to indulge in poetic musings without too much regard for formal considerations.

Richard E. Berlin, president of the Hearst Corporation, has announced that the company and the Government of Nova Scotia have reached a preliminary agreement for the construction of a newsprint mill at Sheet Harbor, Nova Scotia, eighty-seven miles northeast of Halifax.
ALTHOUGH "A Gift of Time" tells the story of a man's dying, it is a play about living.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Kennedy Administration is optimistic about the prospects for a strike-free, non-inflationary steel settlement. But, it sees some hard bargaining ahead.
The trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange will become a movie set today as production starts on a new motion picture about investing.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP) Tenants in the low rent housing projects still call on Burt Steingruby for aid, but the former project manager cannot help them much now he has lost his job.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Feb. 22 A dispute appears to be in the making between Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan and the British Government over why troops were not sent into Georgetown in time to prevent last Friday's rioting.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 22 (UPI) Edith Zimmerman of Austria swept down an iceslicked course today to capture the women's giant slalom event of the Coppa Grischa ski series. America's only two entrants Linda Meyers of Mammoth Lakes, Calif., and Jean Saubert of Lake View, Ore. finished fifth and seventh, respectively.
Efforts were begun yesterday to head off a strike against the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines and its subsidiary bus companies here and in Westchester County.
Dr. Erich Hausmann, dean emeritus of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 20 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 75.

GENEVA, Feb. 22 The Soviet Union again reversed it self by announcing today its readiness to discuss the deadlocked issue of a ban on nuclear testing at the pending eighteen-nation disarmament conference.

Things are going a little better for our side in South Vietnam. Defense Secretary McNamara has said that South Vietnamese armed forces are fighting Communist guerrillas more effectively, while other sources report a marked decline in guerrilla attacks and increased security in the Mekong delta region south of Saigon.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 22 Conservationists, who usually pride themselves on their solidarity, have become embroiled here in a long-simmering highway feud.

Thomas F. Galvin, the Republican candidate and apparent runner-up in the close Congressional election in Queens Tuesday, called yesterday for Federal protection of the voting machines pending an official count of the vote.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that the United States, the Soviet Union and other qualified nations should pool their space efforts under the auspices of the United Nations.
LONDON, Feb. 22 The Earl of Snowdon found himself and his camera today in the middle of a new controversy on Fleet Street, London's newspaper row.
ALGIERS, Feb. 22 While army tanks were patrolling this tense and fearful city, terrorists stepped up their murderous attacks today and struck in the crowded streets of the city center.
P.D. East, editor and publisher of a Mississippi weekly newspaper, who incurred ostracism by campaigning for civil liberties, received the 1962 Florina Lasker Award yesterday.
GRAND TURK ISLAND, B.W.I., Feb. 22 Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. believes the most significant technical result of his space flight has been to establish man's role as a pilot in space.
Five performances of Paddy Chayefsky's play "Gideon" will be televised from the Plymouth Theatre over a closed circuit to the Auditorium Theatre in Rochester, N.Y., starting March 28.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22 Sons of diamond stars who have followed their dads into the major leagues are more or less a rarity. It seems that the greater the name of the sire the less chance the offspring has of making it. There have been exceptions.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 22 The first section of a pipeline to carry oil from the middle Volga and Ural basins to four East European Communist countries was put in service today near the Bratislava oil port on the Danube River.
Grey Advertising, Inc., which has been picking up new business at a brisk pace in recent months, has now been named by Bristol-Myers Company to handle Trushay Hand Lotion and two new products.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 Representatives of the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads and a group of railroad labor union executives met here today to talk about the effect of the proposed merger of the two lines on jobs. The talks were initiated at the request of the railroads.
THE Greater New York Championships continue today at the Statler Hilton Hotel with one-session contests for men's and women's pairs at 2:30 o'clock and for mixed pairs at 8:30.

A reappraisal of Federal policy on shipping subsidies and other forms of maritime assistance was called for yesterday by Earl J. Smith, on his election as chairman of the American Tramp Ship Owners Association.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 22 For the third time within a month Pennsylvania Democratic leaders failed today to agree on a gubernatorial candidate.
THE one word that seems to keep Sir Roy Welensky a constant target for both whites and Negroes in his Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is the adjective "moderate."
PARIS, Feb. 22 The new franc, as France's currency has been known since the end of 1959, will drop the "new" and revert to its centuries-old name of just plain franc at the end of this year.
The first modern unit of Ghana's merchant marine, the motor cargo ship Pra River, will make her debut here today on arrival from West African ports.

BREVARD COUNTY, Fla., Feb. 22 Ever see a whole county going into orbit? Well, sir, take a look at Brevard County, Fla., the home of Cape Canaveral. It is even shaped like a rocket seventy-three miles long and less than twenty wide on the Atlantic side of the state.
Fog disrupted flights along much of the East Coast yesterday and resulted in the collision of two freighters outside New York Harbor.

The Citizens Committee for Children of New York will benefit from a concert featuring the Brazilian pianist Joao Carlos Martins and the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington on March 11 at Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) The Government has frozen 90 per cent of the deposits in a Pennsylvania bank hit by embezzlement in a maneuver not used since bank failures of the early Nineteen Thirties.

President Kennedy has taken an urgently needed step in his special message to Congress calling for reforms in the salary structure for Federal Government employes. Inability of the Government to compete adequately in the market place for highly specialized and scarce personnel, particularly but not exclusively scientists and engineers, is an increasingly serious problem.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 Gov. Leonel Brizola of the state of Rio Grande do Sul exchanged charges today with the United States owners of the telephone system he expropriated last week.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Feb. 22 Students from sixteen high schools met at the Earl L. Vandermeulen High School here today to participate in the Nine States Youth Citizenship Project.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 22 The United States will submit information on the space flight of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. to U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations.
Grosvenor Farwell, a retired investment banker, died yesterday in his home at 1105 Park Avenue. He was 74 years old.
The gas appliance industry, cheered by strong January sales has raised its estimate of 1962 shipments. The new figure points to a gain more than double that of the earlier prediction.
THE lively proram by Claude Monteux, flutist, and Walter Trampler, violist, in Carnegie Recital Hall last night offered one new work. This was Vivian Fine's "Iconomachy," for flute and viola.

New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors went on a shopping spree yesterday in celebration of Washington's Birthday. Many of them got off to an early start, arriving at some downtown stores even before they opened and braving icy roads and early morning fog to drive to suburban shopping centers.
PARIS, Feb. 22 France will launch several dozen rockets this year.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 The West German Government, apparently determined to remove irritations caused by Chancellor Adenauer's recent call for a Big Four foreign ministers' meeting on Berlin, said today that the meeting should be confined to the Western powers.
Mrs. Alieda van Vessem van Wesep, retired vice president in charge of advertising, publicity and display for Lord Taylor, died yesterday in a Mexico City hospital at the age of 70.
NEWARK, Feb. 22 A 1962 budget of $45,393,571 was adopted yesterday by the Essex County Board of Chosen Freeholders.
NEWARK, Feb. 22 Transportation facilities for most New Jersey commuters and shoppers were normal today.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to set up a commission to revise the state's $100,000,000-a-year per capita aid program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Following is the text of a State Department statement tonight rejecting a Soviet offer to resume negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear testing as part of a general disarmament conference in Geneva next month:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The National Grange today opposed a bill to require that manufacturers make only all-channel television sets, contending it "would definitely encourage further deterioration of already inadequate TV service to many thousands of rural citizens."
MIAMI, Feb. 22 The stock of Frank Bowden's Cavalanche took an appreciable jump today on the basis of his performance in the Florida's Breeders' Stakes.
SAN LEANDRO, Calif., Feb. 22 Friden, Inc., has reported net profits for 1961 of $5,710,184, or $1.49 a share. This compared with 1960 earnings of $5,800,000, or $1.58 a share.
ANKARA, Turkey, Friday, Feb. 23 Mutinous army troops tried late yesterday to overthrow the Government of Premier Ismet Inonu. Their attempt was beaten after a night of uncertainty.

The Narragansett Capital Corporation, Providence, R.I., has acquired the Empire Small Business Investment Company of New York City, it was announced yesterday by Royal Little, chairman and president of Narragansett, and Henry C. Brunie, president of Empire

New alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations will be in effect six days a week instead of the present five days. The new schedule will become effective in the Midtown-Central Park West area tomorrow.
About 200 Boy Scouts who have received religious awards from their churches and synagogues in the last year were honored yesterday at a luncheon of the Grand Street Boys Association.

This country cannot base its foreign policy on the determinations of the United Nations, nor "hide behind it" while others "do by vote what they cannot do by force of arms," John Davis Lodge declared here last night.
The ceremonies honoring Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. on his arrival today at Cape Canaveral, Fla., including his meeting with President Kennedy, will be carried live on radio and television.

Mayor Wagner reaffirmed yesterday that he favored payment of a state bonus to veterans of the Korean War. He thus placed himself on the opposite side of the question from Governor Rockefeller and raised an issue for possible debate in the state-wide election campaign next fall.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP) Wally Lemm, who coached Houston to ten straight victories and the American Football League title last season, was named head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League today. He received a one-year contract.
A brand new, happy program was presented in the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon before an audience as responsive perhaps as any in the long history of the place.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 22 The inauguration of Jefferson Davis, the only President of the Confederate States of America, was re-enacted today just 100 years after the original ceremony.
GRAPHIC art tests two things. It is a test of technical skill. And it tests the artist's ability to sustain his initial vision through many stages before the final work of graphic art is produced.
It is expected that the eightteam field for the Eastern College Athletic Conference's first championship hockey tournament will be named early next week.
Mexico is the subject of two books planned for publication next month.
The C.I.T. Financial Corporation reported a record net income of $45,632,575 for 1961 in its annual statement issued today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 22 The government of the Congo, following the recapture of Kongolo by Katangese troops was reported today to be planning to send troops to northern Katanga Province.

THAT was the summer of 1958. In Juanles-Pins, which is the beach extension of Antibes, the international pleasure seekers and sun worshipers sprawled all day on the sand, as closely packed together as the members of a seal colony.
ROME, N.Y., Feb. 22 Governor Rockefeller suggested today that it was the naivete of New York City dwellers and the lack of fight on the part of farmers that had led to the new milk-dating bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The United States said tonight that it would not negotiate for a treaty to ban nuclear tests in any forum as long as the Soviet Union refused to accept the principle of international inspection.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) George Washington's 230th birthday was observed quietly in the capital today.

Against the background of Lieut. Col. Glenn's achievement in making the United States a power in space, the American Government prepares to test anew not only Premier Khrushchev's professed readiness to cooperate in space exploration but also whether he is more willing now to cooperate in solving two earth-bound problems disarmament and Berlin.
A new plan for New Yorkers of moderate means to establish philanthropic funds through savings banks was announced yesterday by the New York Community Trust.

A WOMAN shopping for laundry equipment today has a right to be confused. In a recent check of five New York stores, seventy-one models of washing machines, twenty-five dryers and six combination washer-dryers were on view.

The Republic Aviation Corporation on Long Island is scheduled to put into effect today the first of the layoffs made necessary by the Air Force's cancellation of the company's contract for F-105 planes. Republic has warned that the layoffs may reach a total of 13,000 in the next two years unless new military contracts are obtained.

CHESTER FIRESTEIN, a youthful vice president of Max Factor, took a long look at make-up trends not long ago and found that the American woman unquestionably is moving toward what he called "the natural look."
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI) Greentree Stable's English-trained colt, The Axe II, demonstrated his liking for a rain-soaked track in the $58,100 Washington's Birthday Handicap at Santa Anita today.
With conditions reported from good to excellent almost everywhere a snow runner could point a ski yesterday, the north country found itself in the midst ends in years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Because George Washington's Farewell Address to the American people (Sept. 17, 1796) was the first important example of the "muzzling" of official orators that now is under Congressional attack, its traditional reading in the Senate to a traditionally empty chamber today should have been entrusted to J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the principal contemporary critic of the practice.
New York City plans to give "one of the great welcomes of its history" to Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. and his fellow astronauts.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 22 (UPI) About 200 persons, mostly Negroes staged a peaceful demonstration outside the Maryland State House today to display their support of legislation for equal public accommodations but the legislation apparently is dead for the current session of the General Assembly.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 The chief rabbi of Moscow and a dozen Jewish lay leaders were imploring the congregation in a synagogue meeting to avoid contacts with Israeli diplomats.
National boat shows, of course, have the trimmings, but sometimes local and regional shows are needed to put the story of pleasure boating across to the landlubbers.
IN the late summer, University Hospital will move into a stunning new building at First Avenue and Thirty-second Street. Everything will be brilliant and efficient.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Premier Khrushchev again urged President Kennedy today to meet him at next month's disarmament conference in Geneva, and was turned down again by the Administration.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 22 (UPI) Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, charged today that the Federal Government was spending millions of dollars to assist segregated colleges and universities in the South in violation of the Constitution.
ROME, N.Y., Feb. 22 Governor Rockefeller will send a special message to the Legislature soon outlining a housing and urban renewal program.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 22 (AP) Algerian rebel leaders held a nine-hour, well-guarded meeting today to consider proposals for peace in Algeria. Paris has approved them.
The Jewish Board of Guardians yesterday authorized the closing of its Hawthorne-Cedar Knolls School for emotionally disturbed children in Westchester County because of a strike.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 (AP) The State Court of Appeals today abandoned a thirty-nine-yearold precedent that a manufacturer's warranty applied only to the first purchaser of a product and not to ultimate consumers. The vote was 4 to 3.

FORT WAINWRIGHT, Alaska, Feb. 17 The Army is trying to teach 8,000 soldiers how to live in the Alaskan wilderness at 40 below zero and like it. This is one of the objectives of Exercise Great Bear, a ten-day field maneuver.
The A.P.B.A. has finished compiling statistics for the highpoint winners of inboard speedboat classes for 1961 as follows (class, boat's name and owner are listed):
THE use of television as an instrument of American foreign policy is a matter of growing philosophical concern in the broadcasting industry.

Gov. Wesley Powell of New Hampshire, chairman of the Governors Conference, inquired into the program of a new citizens' peace group here yesterday to see if the Governors should consider taking part in it.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (AP) Ron Delany said today an injured Achilles tendon would force him to miss the national indoor championships and his showdown mile race with Jim Beatty Saturday night in Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 A Democratic proposal to put legislative reapportionment into the hands of a bipartisan commission was filed in the Legislature today.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 Plans to develop a full-scale heliport passenger terminal on a large county-owned parking lot in the Civic Center suffered a major setback today.
ZAKOPANE, Poland, Feb. 22 Sweden edged ahead of Finland today in the struggle among Scandinavian countries for domination of cross-country skiing at the world Nordic ski championship.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 The Court of Appeals today upheld a $37,500 slander award against former State Conservation Commissioner Louis A. Wehle.
MOLINE, Ill, Feb. 22 (AP) Willis Massingill, treasurer of the First Baptist Church of Moline, admitted today that he had taken $13,800 from the church's funds to pay gambling debts.

WASHINGTON'S birthday may be over, but specially priced offerings of cherry products will continue for the entire week-end. These include readybaked cherry pies; cherry pie filling and pastry mixes; canned cherries and even chocolatecovered cherries.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 President Kennedy brought the Glenn family to Florida today on the way to a reunion with the head of the house Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 22 Long Island potato growers were told today that the National Potato Advisory Committee's market stabilization proposals did not involve Government subsidies or regulations.
The pulp and paper industry has urged President Kennedy to negotiate far-reaching reductions in pulp and paper tariffs with the European Common Market.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 The State Board of Social Welfare voiced concern today over the "steadily increasing domination by Federal authorities and the consequent loss of state and local autonomy."
A survey to determine if plans for Manhattan's downtown civic center conform to long-range objectives is scheduled to be authorized by the city today.

LONDON, Feb. 22 "Will Rhodesia become Britain's Algeria?" This question, posed today by Fenner Brockway, a Labor Member of Parliament, typifies the uneasiness with which the Government and political figures approach the most explosive of Britain's remaining colonial problems.

WHEN Tuffy Leemans originally announced his retirement from the New York Football Giants some twenty years ago, Steve Owen had an innocent look in his eye but ulterior motives in his heart as he invited his one-time backfield wonder to serve as his assistant coach during the pre-season training exercises at Bear Mountain Inn. Owen, an oversize Machiavelli, promptly summoned the equipment manager.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy will be the subject of a filmed documentary to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, March 25, from 9 to 10 P.M. It will be produced with the approval and cooperation of the White House, N.B.C. said.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 22 Halliwell Hobbes, a Britishborn stage and film actor, died in his home here Tuesday at the age of 84.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP) Top Soviet military chiefs declared anew today that Russian rockets and nuclear forces could overpower the United States.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 President Kennedy flies into Cape Canaveral tomorrow to tell Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., face to face, how proud the nation is of him.
MIAMI, Feb. 22 (AP) Althea Gibson, former national and Wimbledon tennis champion, carded an 86 today to keep the lead with a 254 total in the ninth annual North-South Negro golf tournament.

THE flow of anglers interested in fishing in Eastern Canada is, naturally, northward, but occasionally there is a backwash, as there will be next Friday, when the Miramichi Salmon Association holds an orientation dinner for sportsmen in this area.

Today's new film arrival is "Arms and the Man" (Helden"), a German-made adaptation, with English subtitles, of the George Bernard Shaw play, which will be at the Casino Theatre, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

A CRITICISM sometimes leveled at bridge lunches is that they are too "gooked up." Translated into words that can be found in Webster's dictionary, that disparaging remark means that the meals that precede the card games are often poorly planned.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 The chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Court Reorganization struck back today at two critics of the committee.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 22 The European Common Market reacted unfavorably today to Britain's request for a delay of four years before beginning to line up her agricultural policy with the policies of the six member-countries.

The Holy Cross quintet went into its game against New York University at Madison Square Garden last night with a twenty-three-piece band and Jack Foley, who can do almost anything with a basketball except make it sing. Both played exquisitely but, in the end, it was only music to lose by.
Where is Grand Turk Island, the land speck in the Atlantic Ocean where America's man from space, Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. was given physical examinations and went swimming?
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 Hypochondria is second only to romance these days as the prime lure of television series.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Savings and loan associations won a reprieve in part today from the imposition of stiff new taxes on their income.
AMERICA'S right wing movements marched past the "C.B.S." Reports" cameras last night on Channel 2.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 The Soviet Union disclosed to its people tonight that the United States had released the spy Col. Rudolf I. Abel. He was exchanged Feb. 10 for Francis Gary Powers, the United States U-2 pilot.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19 "The people of Little Rock now know that with strong leadership they can meet any challenge," Mrs. John M. Samuel said this week in appraising the city's present racial situation.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 American Protestantism will require large doses of sociological realism if it is to make an impact on today's city dwellers, according to Methodist leaders gathered here for their church's National Convocation on Urban Life in America.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 22 Prince Souvanna Phouma's efforts to form a coalition Government appeared to have bogged down anew today under continued Right-Wing resistance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The United States does not stand alone in the Government assistance and protection it gives to agriculture, the House Committee on Agriculture reported today. More than eighty countries have farm programs covering price supports and export subsidies, it said.

Lane High, favored to win the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship, lost to a poised, scrappy Boys High team, 68 66, yesterday and bowed out of the tournament in the highlight of morning and afternoon double-headers at Madison Square Garden.
The 230th anniversary of George Washington's birth was marked here yesterday in weather so dank, drizzly and unappealing that most New Yorkers stayed home.
The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, which has its main office in Pittsburgh, has leased half a floor in the building at 20 Exchange Place.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP) Pravda praised Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. today for his courage, but said that Americans remembered that two Soviet astronauts, Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin and Maj. Gherman S. Titov, were in space first.

The Eighteenth Annual National Antiques Show will open Wednesday at Madison Square Garden and continue through Thursday, March 8. Exhibits will range from collections of old coins and buttons to pipe organs and a steam calliope.
Mayor Wagner agreed with a legislative committee yesterday to make several changes in his proposed state law for a Transit Authority bond issue secured by transit revenues.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Feb. 23 With two days' notice, or two days' pay in lieu of notice, 151 workers were laid off by the Republic Aviation Corporation here today.

BRENDAN REILLY, a furniture designer and manufacturer, can't let well enough alone. One of his best sellers for the past eleven years has been a round, plastic-topped, pedestal-based table. A versatile piece, it serves in hundreds of households as a dining table, card table, end table, kitchen table or night table.

MIAMI, Feb. 23 The apogee of the handicap racing season at Hialeah will be reached tomorrow with the presentation of the Widener. With Mrs. Jack Price's Carry Back they certain choice, a field of thirteen is expected to compete in the twenty-fifth running of the mile-and-a-quarter classic.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) A slight recovery in the final few minutes of trading left most grain futures within a steady range on the Board of Trade today.

Lafayette's Brooklyn II victors, Richmond Hill and Edison Vocational of Jamaica, (Queens, advanced yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championships at Madison Square Garden before 8,500 fans.

Lethargy ruled a dull stock market yesterday. Many Wall Street brokers and even more of their customers decided to ignore the day between the holiday and the week-end. The result was a market that proceeded without conviction, willing to be blown either way by a breath of pressure.
William Bendix, veteran film actor, has dropped out of the title role in "General Seeger," the Ira Levin drama that completes a two-week run in Detroit tonight.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23 Abraham Prins, a convict in the State Prison here who escaped on Jan. 24, was arraigned in the Passaic County Court House today on ten charges resulting from his flight.
Kitchen windows are not necessary today, according to a builder who is designing an increasing number of windowless kitchens for his new apartment houses. He has
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Feb. 23 Boston College overcame a 10-point deficit with eight minutes left tonight and defeated Seton Hall, 90 86, in basketball.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 (UPI) A Douglas DC-8 jet airliner flew 8,705 miles from Tokyo to Miami today to set a non-stop distance record for commercial aircraft.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Feb. 23 Nuclear testing in the atmosphere was opposed today by high school students from four states attending a youth citizenship conference here.
MIAMI, Feb. 23 (AP) Willie Brown of Houston carded a 70 for 283 today and won the ninth North-South Negro golf tournament by three strokes.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23 A Jesuit priest said here today that Roman Catholics have a "very clear obligation" to join in dialogue with non-Catholics.
The repeal of the twentyfive-year-old Lyons Residence Law was voted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to a 1962 low of 83.3 on Wednesday from the revised mark of 83.4 on Tuesday.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 23 John H. Glenn Jr. gave President Kennedy a graphic personal account today of how "big flaming chunks" outside his space capsule had caused the most anxious moments in his three-orbit flight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Other business units accept credit cards, so why shouldn't the telephone booth? The Bell System received a patent this week for equipment that will read the number on a card, check it, permit a call and record the charges.
LONDON, Feb, 23 Prime Minister Macmillan is understood to be pressing the United States to take a more favorable attitude toward Premier Khrushchev's call for a summit conference.
The Northern Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries saw 1961 as a year "of continued steady growth and progress," with new peaks in sales, pipeline capacity, revenue and net income.

BRIGHT lipstick was once the badge of becoming a teen-ager, but today there is a new status symbol: the exaggerated hairdo.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 23 Drag racers found a new champion for their cause today in Brookhaven Town Supervisor Charles R. Dominy, a sailing and iceboat-racing enthusiast.
