The New York Stock Exchange may know where it's going, but publicly, at least, it seems to be playing a game of East Side, West Side, all around the town.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., proposed today that it settle its antitrust differences with the Federal Government by disposing of its $3,500,000,000 interest in General Motors Corporation in three years.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI) Army engineers recommended today that a deep-water harbor be built at Burns Ditch, Ind. The initial cost was estimated at $25,500,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) The Labor Department asked Congress today for more money and men to help find more jobs in the nation.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Turandot" at 2 P.M. and "Macbeth" at 8; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor, Andre Navarre, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; "Aida," opera-in-brief, Amato Opera, Town Hall, 2:30.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 23 Governor Rockefeller said today he would ask the Legislature for authorization to sell up to $475,000,000 in bonds to provide additional mortgage-money for middle-income housing.

VALLETTA, Malta Feb. 23 George Borg Olivier, Nationalist party leader and winner of the Maltese general elections, said today the result was a "vindication of Nationalist party policy, which is independence within the Commonwealth."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Some Government analysts believe the Soviet Union has developed a system of launching intercontinental missiles, spacecraft and sattelites from manned rocket planes. Such a system would have great military significance.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the Government henceforth would define and assert the national interest when it moved into collective bargaining situations. It will not confine its role to mediating the immediate issues, he said.

THE Roman Emperor Hadrian had an edifice complex. He reigned from 117 to 138 A.D., having been born in the plains of southern Spain in the year 76. A Zeckendorff of the classic world, he was always tearing up the ground and building, building, building.

All of Africa is complicated, but some parts are more complicated than others. The Central African Federation of Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland can claim to be about the most complicated problem of them all with the Congo as an obvious competitor.

I have received your reply to the Soviet Government's proposal that the proceedings of the eighteen-nation Disarmament Committee should open with the participation of the heads of government (or state) of the countries represented on the committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, today described the Kennedy Administration's farm program as a "road to a licensed and regimented agriculture."

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 23 Mrs. Mary Ann Ilett Andrews, the oldest woman Salvation Army officer in the United States, died, yesterday at the home of her son, G. Arthur Andrews, with whom she lived at 1 Park Lane.

ALGIERS, Feb. 23 Moslem rebels and European exremists here urged their followers today to avoid clashes with the French Army when a cease-fire is proclaimed. Military officers appeared far from reassured by these actions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Railroad unions have opened an attack on the Presidential Railroad Commission's report on work rules that will be handed to President Kennedy next Wednesday.
At the press conference in which he announced that New York City would stage a parade to honor the space flight of Colonel Glenn, Mayor Wagner took flight himself but in a different way.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23 The Brazilian Cabinet agreed today to increase civil service salaries by 40 per cent and to reduce federal spending.
BERLIN, Feb. 23 President Kennedy's youngest brother, Edward, toured East Berlin today and the Communist authorities promptly claimed a political triumph in his visit.
School dropouts, unemployment and narcotics are the main sources of trouble for Harlem youngsters, a neighborhood seminar agreed yesterday.

Charlton Ogburn, labor and government attorney and a practicing lawyer for fiftyseven years, died early yesterday at the House of the Holy Comforter, Grand Concourse and 196th Street, the Bronx. He was 79 years old.

Michael H. Prendergast withdrew yesterday a legal move to bar the meeting of the Democratic state committee that has been called Thursday for the express purpose of ousting him as chairman. But he threatened to return to court again.
PARIS, Feb. 23 President de Gaulle held meetings with his principal military commanders in France today as the time for a possible showdown with Right-wing subversive elements approached.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 23 The General Assembly voted tonight, over strong British opposition, to conduct an inquiry into whether Southern Rhodesia has attained "a full measure of self-government."
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 Premier Khrushchev has accused President Kennedy of dooming in advance the eighteen-nation conference on disarmament scheduled to convene in Geneva March 14.
LONDON, Feb. 23 Industrial shares again were irregular in the stock market here today.
Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said yesterday that he was satisfied with the progress the Police Department had made in law enforcement and traffic control during his first year as commissioner.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 23 Turkish Deputies of all parties gave a standing ovation to Premier Ismet Inonu today when he entered Parliament after the collapse of an army mutiny.

TRENTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner will join the Prudential Insurance Company April 4 as one of six public directors. He was named to the twenty-three-man board by Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the State Supreme Court yesterday.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 23 Willard C. Jones, an assistant, vice president of the Singer Manufacturing Company makers of sewing machines, died today in Morristown Memorial Hospital, after a short illness. His age was 50. He lived at 155 Garfield Avenue.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 TransCanada Air Lines confirmed today that domestic fare cuts put in effect a year ago would be revised upward because passengers switched to economy class from first class in unexpected numbers.
A number of television programs about Israel will be shown on the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Accent" in the near future.
Plans to construct a $1,800,000 combined ice skating rink and swimming pool in Central Park were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
PARIS, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Twelve European nations agreed today on a draft convention for the creation of a European Space Research Organization, with a program to cost $280,000,000.

The new management of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, headed by Harry Weinberg of Texas and elsewhere, did not fight its way into control of the company under a misapprehension. It well knew the financial situation of surface transit in this city.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, feb. 23 A request by Australia to present her own case rather than to be represented by Britain complicated today the negotiations over the British application to join the European Common Market.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $2,000,000 to $72,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Hollywood, Calif., Feb. 23 A multi-million-dollar business complex is scheduled to be started next fall in the heart of this city.
BAL HARBOUR., Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) Railway union leaders said tonight the heads of two major Eastern railroads had outlined plans to divide the Eastern states rail system into three giant companies.
THE Cape Canaveral homecoming of Marine Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. was altogether absorbing television, rich in human touches that gave a warm dimension to the historic occasion.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 23 The United Nations charged today that the recent conciliatory attitude of President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province had changed to "calculated opposition" to United Nations policies and actions in Katanga.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 23 A leader of the Israel Bond Organization said today that Israel must receive more investment funds in the next several months to cope with economic problems that have arisen in connection with the European Common Market.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Boys Harbor will be celebrated with a ball in the St, Regis Roof on May 25.

ALFRED WALLENSTEIN has been no stranger to Carnegie Hall this week, what with the Beethoven cycle concert last Tuesday and now a Philharmonic week-end. Perhaps the edifice might be subtitled Wallenstein's Camp for the duration.

Harry Weinberg, the new head of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., doesn't own a home, but he owns or controls more transit lines than any other person in the country. Their worth is estimated at $100,000,000. He has built this empire in nine years.

William Rodman Parvin of 965 Fifth Avenue, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and president and director of the Morgan Guaranty Safe Deposit Company, died yesterday at Midtown Hospital. His age was 64.
In New York's most crowded business district, where everyone complains that there is no room to move, stock brokers are expanding their office space at a surprising rate.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 23 Yale's basketball team virtually clinched first place in the Ivy League tonight by beating second-place Cornell, 48 47.

A number of cast changes and a new conductor accounted for some rough edges in the presentation of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" at the Metropolitan Opera last night. However, the performance had vitality and exuberance, and was given special radiance by the debut with the company of Judith Raskin, who was the Susanna.
The board of directors of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation recommended yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock and an increase in the dividend on the new shares.

The East Side, Ill., Levee and Sanitary District sold $1,835,000 of improvement bonds, due from 1972 to 1981, to a group headed by A.C. Allyn Co. The group bid a net interest cost of 3.3822 per cent, reoffering the bonds at prices to yield 3 to 3.40 per cent.
Johnny Green, who gets up higher without a launching pad than anybody since the Watusis, and his New York Knickerbocker play-mates turned in another pretty job last night at Madison Square Garden.
The Flight Engineers International Association offered a formula yesterday that the union's spokesmen said could bring "peace into the cockpits of the nation's airliners."
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 The labor federation found itself today in unaccustomed agreement with two business groups. All three oppose the Federal tax bill, but not for the same reason.

Whitney F. Harris, secretarymanager of the New York Lumber Trade Association, Inc., died of a heart attack Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 88-03 Eighty-eighth Street in Woodhaven, Queens.

The specter of doom is rising above the eighteen-nation disarmament conference even before it opens in Geneva March 14 to deal with what is literally a life-or-death issue for all mankind. The specter is raised by Premier Khrushchev's latest note in which he in effect warns that unless President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan start this conference at the summit and agree to disarmament on Soviet terms they will "doom" it to failure.
DUBLIN, Feb. 23 An eight-week strike in the only match factory in the Republic of Ireland has lad to a black market in matches.
VICE PRESIDENT JOHNSON My fellow Americans: It is a high privilege to welcome one of the great pioneers of all history, Col. John Glenn.
THE Open Pairs championship of the annual four day Greater New York Championships will be played today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The United States Chamber of Commerce decided today to back President Kennedy's proposal for a new and more liberal foreign trade law.

FORT LAUDERDALE Fla., Feb. 23 The count-down on Yankee contract signers was reduced to one today. Bobby Richardson, the nimble-fingered second baseman of the Bombers, came to terms after only a few minutes chat at the ball park with Roy Hamey, Yankee general manager.

Mayor Wagner signed bills yesterday to limit the amount of fat in hamburger and to restrict smoking in hospitals, effective immediately.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 23 Dartmouth's skiers tonight held an infinitesimal lead in the Middlebury Winter Carnival, in which eleven college squads are competing.

FARGO, N.D., Feb. 23 (AP) A pontifical requiem mass for Aloisius Joseph Cardinal Muench was celebrated today in St. Mary's Cathedral. He had served as bishop for twenty-five years.

Now, at President Kennedy's request, it is the part-time undertaking of August Heckscher, director of the Twentieth Century Fund, an intellectual in the best sense of the word, a man of broad experience in many and varied cultural fields, in Government service, in journalism, and yes in farming.
The new management of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines announced yesterday that it planned to eliminate "all unprofitable night and Sunday service" and lay off 1,500 workers.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 (UPI) Negotiators said they conducted "intense collective bargaining" today as they sought to reach basic steel agreement by their target date of March 1.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 23 Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the first American to orbit the earth, returned to his take-off point today. He was honored by President Kennedy and received the cheers of a grateful nation.

With titles, instead of trophies, at stake, the top performers of the indoor track and field circuit will gather at Madison Square Garden tonight for another prospectively exciting round of running, hurdling, jumping, vaulting and shotputting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) A Government program to guarantee private investments abroad against political risks has paid its first claim in thirteen years, officials announced today.
